TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I present the 15th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Super guarantee: its track record, together with the submissions and the Hansard transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The 15th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation examines the track record of the superannuation guarantee system, which commenced in 1992. In this inquiry, the Select Committee on Superannuation received evidence on the general level of acceptance of the superannuation guarantee by employees and employers, areas of contention, areas of inadequacy and areas where improvement needs to be made. The committee also scrutinised the 28 June statement of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) last year.

PARA.TAB: The focus of the report is on what has become known as the small amounts problem. This is the situation where small superannuation accounts are eroded in a short period by fees, charges and taxation. The employer in the situation feels that it has wasted its time and money and the employee is left with little or no superannuation. I would not have to outline to any of you the nature of the problem, as I am sure that all of you would have received many constituents' complaints upon this particular issue.

The committee has formulated a package of measures that it believes will alleviate the reduction of small amounts superannuation accounts. This package has been formulated in anticipation of the member protection and the transfer protocols announced by the Treasurer last June. None of the three recommendations that comprise this package concerning the small amounts problems actually should be considered in isolation. They stand together, balancing the concerns of the range of people and the groups that came before the committee.

In summary, the committee has recommended, first, that consideration should be given to changing the superannuation guarantee threshold from $450 per month to a quarterly figure of less than $1,350. A move to an essentially lower dollar threshold will broaden the superannuation guarantee net, will move in the direction of removing inconsistencies between superannuation guarantee and the award super, and will decrease the administrative burden that processing superannuation guarantee for short-term, casual workers, such as backpackers doing a month's fruit picking, places upon employers.

Those who are included in the superannuation guarantee system because of this measure will be the permanent part-time or permanent casual type of worker who should not be excluded from the nation's retirement income system because of the part-time nature of their work. On a rough calculation, a person who earns $445 per month for 40 years from the year 2002 would have approximately $20,000 of contributions made on their behalf—without escalation. Although this will not provide a retirement income for the remainder of their life, it is a significant sum to be denied.

However, for those to whom the superannuation guarantee would be extended under this measure, there is the possibility of creating further small accounts. It is for this reason that the measure cannot be taken in isolation; it must be viewed in light of the total package of recommendations of the committee, and in light of the member protection requirements and the imminent transfer protocol.

The second element of the committee's package is the removal of access to balances of under $500. By changing the threshold to include more part-time low income workers in the manner I have just outlined, more small balances will be created. However, the committee sees little use in extending the superannuation guarantee coverage to permanent part-time type workers if the superannuation accumulated is merely withdrawn at a point somewhere before the $500 mark. Again, this cannot stand alone, as the experience to date of small balance holders has been the erosion of their contributions. The member protection rules and transfer protocol are integral to the viability of this recommendation. So too is the third element of the committee's package.

The third element of the package is some tax relief for small balance superannuation accounts. Contributions tax on the first $500 should be removed. The government has required funds to protect small balances under the member protection rules. The government itself should also contribute to the conservation of small balances.

Anecdotally, the committee has heard that this would not be simple. Most tax issues are not. The government, in consultation with the industry, should be able to find the means to protect the superannuation from a higher than marginal tax rate.

I commend this package of measures to the chamber. I ask honourable senators to apply it to a few of the scenarios that they have received from constituents. I think, in undertaking that exercise, it will become very clear that this package of measures will enhance the effective operation of the superannuation guarantee system and promote the long-term goals of retirement incomes on all sides of politics.

I will now briefly convey to you the committee's other findings and recommendations. The committee looked at the factors that contribute to small amounts. It was in this area of its inquiry that the committee heard from many ordinary Australians whose so-called nest egg—albeit a small amount—has disappeared.

Of interest to many of you will be the table in the report that details the effect that fees, charges and tax has had on these people's small superannuation amounts. In this context the committee scrutinised the Treasurer's proposals and concluded that, whilst the ATO scheme will provide one facet of the solution to the small amounts problem, its role is a specific one: the ATO scheme should be limited to those employers unable to find appropriate funds offering member protection or unable to use existing employee accounts.

The committee recognises the importance of the transfer protocol in eliminating the small amounts problem. It has therefore recommended that the government ensure that appropriate transfer protocols be adopted by all participating funds. It also supports the extended use of tax file numbers for superannuation purposes—again, subject to member consent.

A group adversely affected by the superannuation guarantee is some non-resident workers who generate relatively small amounts of superannuation guarantee whilst on contract in Australia and meanwhile lose certain superannuation advantages in their country of residence. The committee has recommended that exemptions to non-resident workers be extended.

A large volume of evidence was received on the interaction, or lack of interaction, between the superannuation guarantee and the award superannuation systems. This causes grief for all parties: employers, employees, fund administrators. It is imperative that, if superannuation is to be accepted by the community, the inconsistencies between these two systems be removed. The industrial parties must all work to this end.

For this reason the committee recommends that the government be proactive in seeking uniformity by submitting to the review of awards currently being undertaken by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The government's submission should outline the means by which the inconsistencies can eventually be removed.

Finally, the committee continues its keen pursuit of consumer education. It calls on the government to maintain the education programs and target them appropriately. The committee has identified one means by which information on superannuation guarantee requirements can be propagated to small business in particular, and that is via the BizHelp software package that was launched by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) in November last. I commend the report to the Senate.

I would also like to take this opportunity of commending to you the very hard work by all of my five colleagues on the committee—in particular, my deputy, Senator Sue West, who has taken a very keen interest in this whole matter. Senator Chris Evans from Western Australia has a deep knowledge of superannuation arising from his involvement in superannuation through the union movement, and I value his support.

Senator Bruce Childs has an abiding interest in low paid workers and is determined to assist in getting superannuation to benefit such people. Senator John Woodley from the Australian Democrats was relatively new to the committee but has shown commendable interest and introduced a number of issues which the committee has taken on board, and I thank him. Last but not least, my colleague Senator Ferguson, who has come from the industry, has some extensive knowledge, and I value his loyalty, support and the technical contributions that he makes.

I would like to thank the committee secretariat, headed by Ms Krista Gerrard, for their dedication, for the amount of extra duty that is involved in a very busy committee and for responding to the literally hundreds or thousands of letters that we receive on these important issues. The committee is an important one for the Senate, and I thank all those who have participated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some remarks to the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation. Perhaps I ought to start on the note that the chairman concluded on by thanking the chairman, the members of the committee and the staff for the work that they put into the report. It is the most constructive committee that I serve on in this parliament, and this report reflects that constructive approach.

PARA.TAB: I must say that, on this occasion, there is some disagreement among the members—small as that may be—within the text of the report, but I think the committee has had the maturity to deal with some different approaches to the issue while still continuing the good work started by my colleague Senator Sherry. He brought a constructive and intelligent approach to the committee's work and really contributed to the superannuation debate in this country.

I see this report as an endorsement of the superannuation guarantee scheme. There has been a lot of criticism directed at some of the problems associated with the introduction of the superannuation guarantee and superannuation generally, but the spread of the benefit of superannuation throughout the work force is one of the great achievements of this Labor government. This report essentially endorses the policy that has been pursued, and it endorses the approach soon to be taken by the government in introducing the tax office mechanism for the collection of small amounts.

I believe that that legislation will be introduced into the Senate shortly, and I think it will be a useful addition to the legislation which seeks to regulate the superannuation system in Australia. That legislation will deal with a number of the problems that the committee has been made aware of in its hearings.

We are extremely concerned about the criticisms and the evidence given to the committee about the erosion of small amounts. It is fundamental to the success of the system of superannuation in this country that young people, and people generally, do not see their contributions to superannuation eaten away by fees, charges and taxation. You cannot expect people to feel positive about a system if, for instance, $100 of their money per annum goes into a superannuation fund, and they find that at the end of the year there is $1 or $2 left once all the charges, taxes, et cetera have been taken out of their fund. That problem must be fixed.

The committee has made some constructive suggestions to build on the government's proposals for member protection rules and the ATO mechanism to make sure that we get that right. I think it is absolutely essential that we deal with those problems because they are undermining support for superannuation and undermining people's confidence in the system, and quite rightly so.

I think the Australian Taxation Office mechanism proposed by the government is necessary, but, hopefully, not for too long. I think gradually superannuation funds are beginning to be more responsive to the need to cater for the lower end of the market—those people with small amounts and those people who have low paid jobs or a number of part-time or casual jobs. I think gradually superannuation funds are responding to that need, but they continually have to be driven by the parliament and the government to be responsive. Some of the recommendations we have made in this report seek to drive them along that path.

The superannuation funds have been granted an advantage in that they have access to these funds virtually exclusively. This report supports that policy. Certainly from the government members' point of view, we have opposed the extension of superannuation accounts to banks and credit unions on the basis that we do not think that that would benefit the system but rather would add to the complexity. To be quite honest, we believe the banks have shown by their recent decisions in relation to transaction fees for accounts with small balances that they are not really serious about wanting to get involved in the problem area of superannuation, which is those accounts with small balances and the accounts of people on low incomes.

The evidence of what has occurred in the last year or so in relation to transaction fees in the banking area really blows out of the water the argument that somehow the involvement of the banks is going to improve the situation. I think the government's proposal to introduce member protection rules is sound. I would hope that eventually those rules will be all that is necessary, but I think in the short term the ATO mechanism for the collection of small amounts will probably be required. I am anxious that the government introduce that legislation as soon as possible to protect those small amounts.

The committee also looked at the question of whether or not there should be some taxation relief for small accounts or for those persons who maintain small balances. I think the recommendations in the report are a little stronger than I would have wanted, but they flag the problem that it is not purely charges and fees imposed by the superannuation funds that eat away at balances. It is, in fact, the tax on contributions as well which makes a significant contribution to the erosion of small amounts. A very plausible argument can be made that the taxation on superannuation, for low income earners in particular, is at a higher marginal rate than that which is normally applied to their income because of the 15 per cent contributions tax.

Some people so affected would not be paying any tax at all or would be paying very low marginal rates if it was treated as income. I think there is an argument for looking at that problem. The harsh reality is that, even if you remove all fees and charges imposed by superannuation funds, small amounts will continue to be eaten away by taxation. It will not be to the same degree, but it will continue to constitute a problem. This report flags to the government that it needs to look at that area as well.

Our other recommendations—and I will not go into the detail of many of them—really go to the committee's philosophy—it is certainly my philosophy—that underlines this report: that is, that while the superannuation system has some problems, those problems can be fixed; the system can be made to work effectively for low paid workers, workers in casual employment and people who come in and out of the work force; and it is not beyond our wit to make it work. We have supported the changes the government is proposing and we have proposed some additional changes that we believe will make the system work better.

We do not support the principle that low paid workers should somehow be excluded from the net of the superannuation guarantee or from superannuation generally in this country. People will never be able to rise above the disadvantages of being low paid or in casual employment if they are excluded in that way. My attitude is to support the principle that every dollar earned ought to be assessed for superannuation purposes and that contributions ought to be retained in superannuation accounts. The challenge for us is to make sure that that money is protected, that it grows and contributes to people's superannuation and their retirement income.

So our challenge is not to try to find some way of excluding those people from the superannuation system but to make sure that it works for them and that the money they put in is protected and they have a chance to benefit from that contribution. This is preferable to trying to strike some arbitrary line in the sand that says, `These people are excluded; they are not entitled to superannuation' or `They are too disadvantaged currently to be able to contribute to superannuation.' The fact is no-one will accumulate large amounts in a superannuation account without starting with a small amount. The reality of working life is that people move between income levels, between part-time and full-time employment, between casual and full-time employment. The current reality is that people over their working lives have a variety of experiences in the employment context. What we have to do—and this is the subject of an inquiry the committee is commencing—is make sure the system is much more adaptable to those with different working patterns to the traditional male 40-year working pattern. We have to be much more conscious of the needs of women workers, in particular. Hopefully, the committee will add to that debate in its next major report. I commend the report to the Senate and again thank all committee members for their efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak only very briefly on this report and will seek later to have time to continue my remarks. The first thing I want to do is return the compliment from the chair of this committee, Senator Watson, and to say that, of all the committees in this parliament that I have been on, I have not yet been on a committee which has had such a fair chair. Other committee chairs, I must admit, have done an excellent job but this particular chair not only commends his own position in the Senate but also the position of the party that he is part of and is a credit to the Senate itself. I am not saying that simply to scratch backs because mine has been scratched; I really believe that. In working through this report, where there were differences of opinion he was able again to demonstrate his ability to pull different opinions together and to find a middle ground and, where that was not possible, to allow both opinions or even more than two opinions to be held in tension. So I return the compliment, Senator Watson. You have been an excellent chair of this committee. Part of the credibility of the committee is due to the quality of the committee and certainly to that of the chair.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to add my thanks to the staff, who are really quite remarkable in the amount of work they do, in the ability they have to get on top of the various issues which are canvassed and also to know the subject, particularly Krista Gerrard. Her grasp of superannuation is quite remarkable. I would like to add my thanks to those of the chairman.

There are a couple of outstanding issues for the Democrats which later I will speak more about. One of them is the whole issue of a contributions tax. Although we have gone some way, at least in the first instance, to giving a one-off discount of $500 for this, nevertheless in continuing years those people on an income of, say, $6,150, which is the tax-free threshold, once the super is fully implemented at nine per cent, would attract a super guarantee charge of about $550 a year, which would attract a contributions tax.

I know that there are great administrative difficulties in what I am suggesting. But the principle that a person who pays no tax on their income should pay tax on their superannuation contribution is a bad principle. I do not know how we would fix it. But I signal that the Democrats still have some problems with it.

One issue which I admit would be an administrative nightmare, particularly for employers, but which would solve a lot of our problems is member choice. In other words, employees would have the choice of superannuation funds. Obviously, the committee could not recommend that. But I signal that in the end that would, at least from the employees' point of view, be a solution.

I acknowledge what Senator Chris Evans said about superannuation savings accounts, particularly in relation to the banks. In the report, the coalition and the Democrats have proposed a framework for superannuation savings accounts which I believe would enable at least some of the financial institutions to come up with a proposal within that framework. I suspect that only the credit unions and building societies would be able to fulfil those conditions. But I believe that if they are able to fulfil the very tight framework that we have proposed they ought to be allowed to compete in the market.

I concur with what Senator Evans said about the banks, but other financial institutions could offer a product that would be very helpful in solving this small savings account problem. I need to place on the record that I do not think it is totally solved by the government's proposal for collection through the Australian Taxation Office. With those few remarks, I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time.

SPEECH.PARA: In this special year of Remembrance of the fiftieth anniversary of the end of the Second World War, it is my great honour to introduce into this Parliament a bill providing for Anzac Day to continue to be observed on 25 April each year and to declare Anzac Day as the National Day of Commemoration.

The object of the bill is to ensure that, for current and future generations of Australians, the contribution of all those who served Australia in time of war is commemorated and remembered, so that Anzac Day will continue to hold an important and special place in the hearts and minds of all Australians.
The significance of Anzac Day in forging Australia's national identity in a very special way is known to us all. It is timely, however, to recall the legacy of Anzac and what it symbolises.
One newspaper editorial of the time described the meaning of the achievement of Anzac in the following terms—

Before the Anzacs astonished the watching nations, our national sentiment was of a flabby and sprawling character. We were Australians in name. . . but we had been taught by our politicians not to trust ourselves—we were constantly admonished by our daily journals to remember that we were nothing better than a joint in the tail of a great Empire. There were patriots who protested against [this] slavish and sycophantic doctrine. But, generally speaking, it was assumed that Australia only lived by the grace of England, and the Empire Day orators had a better hearing than the faithful souls who clung to Australia Day and gave special honour to their own starry banner.
Anzac day has changed all that. . . . No matter how the war may end—and it can only end in one way—we are at last a nation, with one heart, one soul, and one thrilling aspiration.

There can be no doubt that the Anzac achievement signalled the fulfilment of the promise of Nationhood in the fledgling Australian Federation. The deeds of Australian soldiers at Anzac gave birth to a belief in the capacity of all Australians to attain for themselves a uniquely independent and proud national identity. The Anzac tradition embodied a true sense of National character. For the first time, it set Australia and Australians apart by demonstrating their willingness and capacity to have Australia's voice heard in its own right in the community of nations of which it was a part.

There is no question either that the Anzac tradition is the unifying symbol of the sacrifice made by Australian servicemen and women. Nor is there any doubt about its subsequent influence on later generations of Australians who continue to uphold that tradition. The willingness to meet this sacrifice instilled in Australians a sense of pride in themselves and their achievements.

This bill ensures that, as time slips by, the courage, fortitude and selfless sacrifice of the Anzacs and those who followed them, will not be forgotten, but remembered in a special way. By declaring Anzac Day as the National Day of Commemoration to be observed on 25 April each year, their deeds, and those of all Australian servicemen and women and others who have served the nation in time of war, will not only be remembered and commemorated, but serve as an ideal which will inspire and guide future generations of Australians.

I am mindful also that, in focusing attention on the significance of commemoration and remembrance, the tragic aftermath of war should not be forgotten. In this sense, I believe that this bill symbolises the debt owed by the nation to those whose lives were affected by war. It is, therefore, a timely reminder of the continuing commitment of the Australian Government to honour and serve veterans and their war widows through programs of care, compensation and commemoration.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will remind honourable senators and the audience what the Senate is now doing. The Senate is considering a motion by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, to exempt the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) from the order of the Senate which was adopted on 29 November 1994. This bill has caused considerable controversy amongst the people who have had a chance to look at it. People have had a chance to look at this bill since only Thursday of last week. From memory, that is when the bill was introduced into the chamber. The bill seeks to do certain things. It seeks to give retrospective effect to the regulations which made the People's Republic of China a safe third country for the refugees in question. Notwithstanding that, after 15 years their concern is not about the persecution they suffered at the hands of the Vietnamese authorities but about what they are allegedly suffering at the hands of the PRC authorities. The order of the Senate of 29 November 1994 states:

SPEECH.PARA: For the reasons set out in this resolution, where, during a period of sittings, a bill is first introduced into the Senate by a minister or received from the House of Representatives, and a motion is moved for the second reading of the Bill, debate on that motion shall be adjourned at the conclusion of the speech of the Senator moving the motion and resumption of the debate shall be made an order of the day for the first day of sitting in the next period of sittings without any question being put.
That is the principle of a bill being introduced one session and debated the next. That is what Senator Gareth Evans said would be the approach of the government.

PARA.TAB: It is a proper way of doing things. It not only allows us to get across the legislation and its implications, and to consult with the community, but also allows the community itself and those specifically affected by the legislation to have their say. Thus it allows us to exercise our representative function in the way that we should be exercising it. It is a principle of a bill being introduced one session and debated the next so that proper time is allowed for that purpose, not introduced one week and debated the next, as is the case with this particular bill. It was introduced on Thursday of last week and now we are expected to debate it on Wednesday of this week. The order of the Senate continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . where the Government wishes the Senate to depart from that general chronological priority, the Government should justify each such departure in debate which concludes with a resolution of agreement by the Senate.
I remind the Senate that this is the very first occasion that the government has sought to depart from the general principle. That is another reason why we have to test it.

PARA.TAB: What did the minister do? He put forward a certain justification. Last night he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Were the Senate not to deal with this bill until the next session, a number of the recent arrivals who have lodged refugee claims since my announcement of 30 December would be able to pursue those claims, notwithstanding the fact that they had already been granted protection by the People's Republic of China and had already been put on notice of the government's intention that the safe third country provisions should apply to them.

PARA.TAB: It is important for the processing and implementation of the agreement—

SPEECH.PARA: that is to say, the agreement between the Australian government and the PRC—
that this legislation pass at this particular stage.

That is all he said. That is no justification at all for providing the type of exemption that the minister seeks. In particular, might I say pointedly, it is no justification for the matter to be debated only three sitting days since it was introduced. At least the minister might have come in here and said we will have this debate when we come back after having been two weeks in the electorate and debate it at perhaps the end of this month or the beginning of next month. But, no, he is trying to force it through today. That is another reason why I am right.

PARA.TAB: It may have been another matter had the minister made out a case for having the bill perhaps dealt with next month rather than three days after it had been introduced. That sort of activity is obscene. In fact, that was referred to time and again by the people who heard about this particular legislation and who rushed to give evidence and make submissions to the Legal and Constitutional Committee. First of all, let me read to the Senate what the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, Sir Ronald Wilson, said in respect of the bill that the government is seeking exemption for.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the wrong bill. He made comments about the other bill. Just get it right. You come in here full of bloody puff. Tell us about the other bill.
—Thank you, minister. Sir Ronald Wilson said:

SPEECH.PARA: A related concern is attracted by certain provisions of the No.2 Bill (for example, s. 4(2)(a)) . . .
Minister, are we talking about that bill?

TALK.START.PARA: —His concern was about the other bill.
—Are we talking about that bill? You have traduced me and traduced the Senate—and indeed Sir Ronald Wilson. Are we talking about that bill or not?
—You know what you are talking about.
—We are talking about that bill.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Senator Harradine, address your remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will. Sir Ronald Wilson said:

SPEECH.PARA: A related concern is attracted by certain provisions of the No. 2 Bill (for example, s. 4(2)(a)), which reflect a failure to respect the rule of law.

We are talking about this bill! He is talking about this bill! I repeat: `which reflect a failure to respect the rule of law'. He is saying that this bill reflects a failure to respect the rule of law. He continues:

The practice of authorising an arbitrary interference with the existing rights of an individual coupled with a denial of any judicial review might be thought to be inconsistent with the fundamental practices and policies of a civilised community.

That is what he was saying. It is quite clear that the minister has not even read, let alone contemplated the implications of, the statement of the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Sir Ronald Wilson, in respect of this bill.

PARA.TAB: People are most concerned about the way this particular measure is handled and, indeed, about the way the whole refugee situation is handled by the government. I will not take the time of the Senate to quote all of the evidence that has been given to us, but let me simply indicate that the vast majority of the people who spoke to us were very concerned about this measure and complained to the committee that they had insufficient time to study the total ramifications of the bill. However, they were able to make submissions that the bill should be rejected. The Law Council of Australia, in its submission to the Legal and Constitutional Committee, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty with this prescription—
under statutory rule No. 3 of 1995, which this bill seeks to make retrospective until the announcement—

is that the Vietnamese refugees who have arrived in Australia and have been permitted to make applications for refugee status, may be making claims of persecution within the terms of the Convention definition against China rather than against Vietnam. It follows that it is logically and factually difficult to regard China as being a designated safe third country for these asylum seekers. Rather China should be regarded as their country of former habitual residence.

That is clearly the case. The allegations of persecution which have fallen from the lips of these people who have come to our shores seeking asylum are against China, not against Vietnam. I put them as allegations because I am not here to judge the case. Apparently the government can judge the case and whack in this legislation to deal with the specific concerns of individuals on a group basis. Apparently the government can be judge and jury in the case; but I will not be. The opportunity for these people to have their cases properly adjudicated by the due processes of the law in this country is being taken away by the designation of China as a safe third country.

PARA.TAB: The provisions of the Migration Act require the government to table in the parliament an explanation of why the government has designated a particular country as a safe third country. The act requires the minister to address the compliance by the particular country—in this case, the communist government in China, the PRC—with relevant international law concerning the protection of Vietnamese refugees settled in the PRC. It also requires the meeting by the PRC of relevant human rights standards for the Vietnamese refugees settled in the PRC and the willingness of the PRC to allow the Vietnamese refugees settled in the PRC who have subsequently travelled illegally to Australia to return to the PRC and to remain there. If you have a look at that you will see that it is pretty well gobbledegook.

It is very interesting in respect of where they deal with human rights. It is accepted that there are gross and continuing violations of human rights in China. I will deal with this matter later because, under standing orders, I cannot really deal with it here. But at some stage or another there will be democracy in the PRC.
I will quote from the document that the minister has tabled in the parliament pursuant to the Migration Act requirements. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the human rights accorded the Vietnamese refugees in China, Australia is satisfied that the refugees are treated essentially as Chinese nationals, and that their living standards are in the main similar to those of local Chinese nationals. We understand that they have the same rights and obligation as Chinese nationals, which includes the obligations under the household registration system and that they enjoy the same civil rights as Chinese nationals—
That is an interesting statement, isn't it—
with the exception of the right to participate in elections.
I do not think that has been picked up by anybody, but it is interesting to reflect that the government says that so blandly and designates China as a safe third country.

PARA.TAB: We are being asked by the government to push this through without giving it the consideration that it deserves. That is what concerns me. We are talking about issues of life and death. They could affect the lives of these people who have made application. They are not all necessarily refugees who went to China after being kicked out of their own country in 1978-79, though this bill says they are in that category. This bill covers not only them but also their close relatives. So this bill could deny refugee status to a person who has come to our shores from the People's Republic of China—a person who was born in the PRC and never left it—just because that person happens to be a close relative of the Vietnamese refugee, as classified.

We are being asked to deny the due processes to these people, these individuals, which are required of us by our international obligations under the status of refugee convention and the protocols. That is what we are doing here. It is a very serious question and a very serious issue for our international obligations, and also for our proper consideration of applications for refugee status.

We are not even prepared to allow the due processes of the Senate to be observed. As I was saying last night, the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee has not even had time to consider this legislation. The Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee is charged under our standing orders to report whether bills that come before us, by express words or otherwise:

SPEECH.PARA: (i)trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;
(ii)make rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers—

which, by the way, this bill does because the minister will have a discretionary power to consider refugee applications from this group, but it is a non-compellable discretion and it is not subject to any judicial or independent scrutiny—
(iii)make rights, liberties or obligations unduly dependent upon non-reviewable decisions;
(iv)inappropriately delegate legislative powers; or
(v)insufficiently subject the exercise of legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny.

Clearly, what Sir Ronald Wilson was saying was that the bill fell short of that. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee had not even had the opportunity to look at this measure by last night. I understand that the committee, with pressure from its other work, was able to give it some consideration this morning. I understand that that consideration will be included in a report for us to have this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: Again, I come back to the point that I made and I ask the minister to listen to this. Thus far, the minister has not given the Senate proper justification for the exemption of this bill from the order of the Senate on 29 November last year, that is to say exemption from the principle that you introduce legislation one session and you debate it the next. Furthermore, the minister has gone further than that. He has introduced legislation one week and we are debating it the next; he introduced it on Thursday and this is the third sitting day since then. That is just obscene when this measure deals with such vitally important issues.

He has not even—and I raise this again—suggested that we might be able to give this further consideration and perhaps delay it until the end of this month or maybe the beginning of next month, which would give us an opportunity to have further consultations around the community and to look further at the implications of the bill. It is unfair, I believe, for the government to ask us to vote for this motion which will exempt this bill from that particular order and which will not give us the opportunity to properly and maturely examine the bill which we, as representatives of the people, are required to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Harradine has dealt very clearly with the content issues of the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) that deserve a much more thorough and detailed analysis before the Senate can responsibly do its job in relation to the legislation. I am going to dwell mainly on the rationale for the original procedural motion and why I believe this bill should not be an exemption from it.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that the history of the procedural motion goes back to 18 August 1993. I introduced a cut-off motion at that time for two reasons. The first reason was that prior to that time we had at the end of each session a very irresponsible log jam of legislation that was simply rushed through from the House of Representatives and pushed through at such a pace by the Senate sitting into the late hours, or early hours I should say, of the final days of the session.

This really was a shameful abuse of the legitimate powers of the Senate. We have a responsibility to review and scrutinise legislation which is passed to us by the House of Representatives. The Senate has a legitimate view and it cannot do justice to that view if it has 20 or 30 bills to consider, of which it has had no prior notice and which are pushed through. That was the first reason for that cut-off motion—simply a procedural matter that allowed us to do our jobs.

The second reason was that the government had been taking advantage of that log jam to perpetrate a shameful pushing through of legislation which it knew to be controversial, which it knew to be questionable and which it knew the community had very strong views on that had not had a chance to be expressed or be regarded in any way.

The main reason for my proposing that procedural motion in the first place was that I felt it was shameful to be a member of the Senate on 5 May 1992 when, by dint of numbers, migration legislation was pushed from the House of Representatives through the Senate within the space of, I think, five hours to pre-empt an appeal to the High Court, to actually obstruct the judicial access of people within this country. I was absolutely appalled that I had to be part of a debate conducted, I remember well, between Senator Harradine, Senator Coulter, me and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus). We demanded to know why that bill was to be rushed through when it was of such dubious validity. As a result of that, detention which could have been found to be illegal and which allowed people some legitimate avenues for concern was made legal from that date, 5 May 1992.

The second scandalous example of that kind was on 17 December 1992. Once again it was migration legislation. That bill was to close the loophole that had been provided by legislation rushed through on 5 May 1992. Mandatory detention of unauthorised arrivals on our shores was rendered legal only by this parliament and not by the courts. The courts were not given an opportunity to voice a view on that. They actually said that prior to that date there was a period of illegal detention. In December 1992, we passed a bill that said that if any detention prior to May 1992 happened to be illegal, people would be given compensation of a dollar a day. That was a scandalous bill and it has been challenged in the High Court—quite appropriately so. That is the second occasion. Those two occasions led to my procedural motion.

On 18 August 1993 we heard an assurance from Senator Gareth Evans that the government thereafter would introduce legislation on an `introduce one session, debate the next' basis. I regret to say that, having been made in August 1993, that assurance was not adhered to in any considerable fashion. In August 1994 we had to reassert that principle and remind Senator Evans of his commitment. As a result of that, we obtained the procedural motion, which is under consideration today, to exempt this particular migration legislation from it.

I remind senators of the reason why we should respect that procedural motion. It is not simply that I believe it is an abdication of the responsibility of this chamber, but also that there is a useful purpose. I quote the reasons for this `introduce one session, debate the next' basis from my notice of motion of 10 November 1994. It states:

(a)there should be an orderly debate of bills in accordance with some general chronological priority based on the principle that bills introduced in one sittings should preferably be debated in the next sittings;
(b)such a priority reflects and ensures effective use of the time available:

TAB.TAB: (i)to Senators to research the implications of the bills, consult the community, prepare speech notes and draft any necessary amendments, and
(ii)to the media and the public to become aware of the possible effects of proposed laws . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is a very good illustration of why this bill that we are proposing to exempt from that procedural order should not be exempted. It was introduced only on 31 January by Senator Ray. At that point in time it was deferred to the first day of the next sitting, quite appropriately, in accordance with the motion, but it was simultaneously referred by Senator Ray to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. It was referred for a reporting date—which at the time I felt to be unusual and, I might say, suspicious—which was, I believe, 6 February. Why would we need such a quick reporting date when, quite clearly, a procedural order had been put in place to defer it to the first day of the next sitting? We know, because the minister has been attempting to explain why they want to rush this bill through in the same way they rushed the previous bills through.

PARA.TAB: I might add that there was a moment when the opposition actually demonstrated a progressive view in relation to migration bills. That, sadly, has passed. We were notified yesterday that the opposition's genuine role to challenge the indefensible attitude of this government in relation to asylum seekers has gone. The opposition challenged it last year and it is to be congratulated for making that stand. It is a shameful thing that, because an electoral nerve has been twitched by the government in threatening a double dissolution, the opposition has moved from that stand.

I believe that is one of the problems we have in relation to all these bills. They can be pushed through without adequate scrutiny and debate because the numbers are there when the government and opposition vote together. It leaves 10 members in this chamber—the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine. Now, of course, it will be 11, hopefully, but I do not know that we can have any assurance of that. Senator Devereux is independent and he can vote in his own right, but it leaves those 10 to consistently maintain the genuine role of opposition to what is a shameful government stance.

That bill was referred by the government to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. The report was tabled yesterday. In fact, it was tabled fractionally ahead of this motion being debated and brought into this chamber. I happen to know, having glanced at that committee report, that there are two minority reports. There is one from Senator Spindler and one from Senator Harradine. I have not had adequate time to read that through, to understand the implications of it towards the debate, and I think it is an insult to this chamber that we are being rushed through once again in relation to that bill when the committee has only just handed down a view.

I might add that the committee has been under considerable stress because it has been required to cooperate with a ridiculous timetable. Also, it had to give consideration to Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). The committee had to do that in an extraordinarily short time, which I think is an indefensible thing to ask of honourable senators who participate in those committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The secretariat has done an extraordinary job.

—I thank Senator Harradine for drawing that to my attention; the kind of burden this places on the secretariat is enormous. The secretariat has done an extraordinarily good job in abiding by the unreasonable time line which was placed upon it—and I commend it. I also commend the senators who have taken the time to attend those committee meetings. But we, the members of this chamber, cannot do justice to all the hard work that the senators and secretariat have put in because we will not have time to give it due consideration. Because the numbers are here, I believe that, once again, we are about to push this bill through into its second reading stage. I will be speaking on the second reading debate and, at the same time, trying to understand the complexities that were unveiled in the committee's report. That state of affairs is hardly one that I or anybody else in this chamber could be proud of; in fact, I am ashamed that this is coming up in this way.

PARA.TAB: The rights of human beings are at stake here. It is not simply a government with its need to tidy up the edges and polish up its policies. There are human lives that hang in the balance. There are lives that will have their fate determined by this legislation. It is irresponsible for senators in this place to go through this as though the existence of a procedural order and the necessity for us to exempt bills—bills that the government feels it has to rush through for its own personal or business agenda—is merely a matter of inconvenience, especially when there is a rightful place within the parliament for proper review and scrutiny of those decisions that we are being asked to rubber stamp.

I therefore submit that the Greens in no way accept that this bill should be exempted from the procedural motion. I will certainly be debating the content of the bill at the first opportunity I get. But I would place on the public record that what is happening is a repetition of what, in relation to migration legislation, has been happening on many occasions. It is appalling that we are part of that process at this point in history.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating whether the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 should be dealt with forthwith, thereby making an exception to the procedural motion which the Senate passed which would require that the bill be dealt with in the next session. At one stage I was fairly relaxed about when this bill would be dealt with because, on the face of it, after I examined the provisions of the bill, I was very confident that the Senate would throw it out. I was confident that senators would see the injustice of this particular bill. I thought there probably was some benefit in giving those people—people who are currently extremely uncertain of their fate because they might be, holus-bolus, as a group, sent back to China, the country they have fled—quick certainty as to the position the Australian parliament would adopt on this bill, which I believe should be thrown out. I thought the case was fairly clear.

PARA.TAB: However, as the debate developed and the committee—under considerable difficulties, as has been pointed out by Senators Harradine and Chamarette—examined the material; and with it becoming apparent that the coalition parties were wavering on this particular issue—and I still find it difficult to understand how they could do so—we then heard last night that they are now prepared to pass the bill which previously they characterised as retrospective and chastised as being unjust. They now are prepared to pass it and turn up their bellies to be tickled by the government simply on a procedural matter they perceive to be to their electoral advantage and benefit: to deny the government the possibility of having an early election brought on by a motion for a double dissolution.

I believe that the issue is now one that needs to be examined at much greater length and in much greater detail. Senators in this house as well as community groups outside need more time to make the point that the decision that this parliament is about to make is a low point in Australia's treatment of refugees. Certainly it will be opposed by the Australian Democrats.

I will very briefly touch on some of the points that the bill makes. The bill recognises China as a safe third country for the purpose of Sino-Vietnamese people—and that is a loose definition—fleeing China. That will mean that these people, as a group, will be sent back to China—the country from which they have fled—without the assessment of their refugee status on an individual basis, as required under international law.

In earlier boatloads—and I think we should look at what in substance this might mean—most of the asylum seekers were found to qualify as refugees on the basis that they had a well-founded fear of persecution. Despite the fact that a significant proportion of people on this and subsequent boatloads is likely to reflect a similar proportion—in other words, there will be people who will fall into the international definition of being a refugee, and that is not denied by the government—we are prepared to simply say, `Well, that may be so, but we are not going to assess them. We'll send them back as a group, as a boatload. We are going to deny them asylum in Australia because we find it administratively convenient to deal with it that way. We are finding it costly and administratively inconvenient to meet our international obligations and to assess each person's refugee status.'

Many of these refugees who have come on previous boatloads—and there is no reason to suggest that the boatload that has prompted this bill is any different—were refugees who had been expelled from Vietnam. Once in China, they were denied Chinese nationality and, as a result, they were denied housing registration; in some cases, they were denied adequate food; they were certainly denied education; and they were denied medical services. Most recently, many have had their houses demolished.

This government is prepared to send back all such asylum seekers; moreover, it is prepared to do so by retrospective legislation to make sure that we include those people who arrived even before the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) thought of this legislation, let alone announced it by press release.

There is, of course, a suggestion by the government that the provision in the bill which gives the minister non-compellable discretion to deal with individual people in that group is sufficient to discharge our obligation under international law to assess each asylum seeker as to whether or not they are a genuine refugee. Let us just look at that.

For a start, the minister is not obliged to exercise that discretion. Worse than that, the asylum seeker is in a position where he or she does not even know that that avenue is available to them, because all they will be given is a brief identification interview where they will be asked, `Who are you? Where are you from? Why are you here?' It will be entirely up to the discretion of a public servant employed by the immigration department to determine whether a particular case, on the basis of that scant information, should be referred to the minister for the possible exercise of the minister's discretion. I might add that, even if that happened, there is no judicial review of the way in which the minister exercises that discretion.

On the basis of how immigration department officials have dealt with refugees in the past and the lengthy legal wrangling that was gone into to enable the refugees to achieve at least a modicum of fairness in the assessment of their status, one must say that one cannot have a great deal of confidence that any of these refugees will be advised clearly by the immigration department officials that this avenue of discretion by the minister exists and what they should do to access it. The bill is silent on providing any access to this particular avenue which might be the last life raft that is offered to them. Basically, the bill simply says, apart from this one inadequate exception, that we are going to send them back in one boat load and we are not going to bother to consider their individual circumstances.

The position that has been foreshadowed by the coalition parties to ignore this extremely rough treatment that we are prepared to mete out to refugees who reach our shores is extremely disappointing. I think we need to point out that these are Vietnamese and Chinese refugees. For some reason we seem to be prepared to treat them willy-nilly in this particular way. I wonder whether the position of the government and the coalition would be different if we were dealing with a boat load of refugees from the UK.

I think it is a point that should not escape the notice of this house. We have had evidence of extreme concern amongst the Vietnamese and Chinese communities expressed to the committee. We have had evidence of concern from organisations like FECCA, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils, that are concerned about what they see as the discriminatory treatment that is meted out to these refugees.

For all these reasons, the Australian Democrats believe that it is inappropriate indeed to rush this bill through the Senate today—and may I add my personal view—at a time when the opposition is apparently prepared to forsake principle for what it perceives to be electoral advantage, as demonstrated last night when it said that it is now prepared to pass a bill which last year it characterised as a bill that should not be passed because of its `totally retrospective character'. The opposition has also quoted objections raised by the Law Council of Australia. It has taken a very firm view in words, but, unfortunately, this is not followed by deeds.

I believe the coalition parties, if no-one else, should be given another chance to examine the evidence. They should be given another opportunity to examine the material that advocates of the refugee organisations have placed before us and can still place before us. They all said at the proceedings of the committee inquiry that they have had inadequate time to prepare their cases. I believe it is unseemly and contrary to good parliamentary practice for the government to try to rush this bill through today and for the coalition parties to support the government, if they do. I hope they do not.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate relates to whether the Senate order of 29 November 1994, which allows for the exemption of its application, should be permitted in this case. So it is a procedural debate. I will not go into the substance of the bill as some of the other contributors to this debate have done because I think the appropriate time for that is the second reading debate on the bill, which we will presumably come to next.

PARA.TAB: No-one in this Senate chamber is more concerned with the need for proper, due process than I. The coalition has scrupulously observed and called for due process in the handling of Senate proceedings and parliamentary proceedings for a long time. Indeed, one of the basic and major criticisms the coalition has had of this government, the Keating government, is that it so often prostitutes the proper parliamentary processes and does not observe them. Having said that, I do not believe that in this case the government is doing so because we are having a debate on whether there are legitimate reasons for the exemption from the Senate order of 29 November to apply. The coalition believes that there are. I say so for the following reasons, and in doing so I set aside the content of the bill and the substance of the bill because that is a matter for subsequent debate.

The government announced at the end of December that it would be taking steps in the form of negotiations with the Chinese, with the PRC government, to reach an agreement on the return of those people who have arrived here in the last couple of months by boat and who are not judged to be genuine refugees. The government announced that, and the coalition supported that at the time. Indeed, I was very critical of the government—and I continue to be critical—for not having taken action much earlier when it had forewarning of what was going to happen months and months ago, that is, that those boats would arrive.

It would be hypocritical for the coalition to now delay the passage of the legislation which is required to enable the negotiations which have concluded in a memorandum of understanding between the two governments to proceed. As Senator Harradine knows, as Senator Chamarette knows and as Senator Spindler knows, the bill provides for the return of those people who fall into this particular category if they cannot bring forward a genuine refugee claim. I interpose a bit of substance in the bill. Some speakers, in particular Senator Spindler, said that there is no access at all—if I got him right—or no opportunity for a Sino-Vietnamese who arrived here by boat in the last two months to put in a refugee claim. That is simply not correct. Let us go into that in the second reading debate. It is not a correct statement.

The government having signed a memorandum of understanding with the PRC government, a bill being required to give effect to that memorandum of understanding, and there being an important time constraint on that, in the interests of the Sino-Vietnamese themselves, in the interests of the whole of our migration program and in the interests of our refugee component of that program, if we really believe in an orderly, fair and equitable program for refugees to Australia—as the coalition certainly does; I do not know about the Democrats, but we believe that fairness and equity is all important in a refugee program—then it is necessary to deal with this bill expeditiously.

The Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has had a considerable debate on this bill. Most of the main players in the field appeared before the committee. We had very lengthy proceedings the other day, which Senator Spindler, Senator Harradine and I participated in. It is certainly true that this bill is being rushed in the sense that, in an ideal world, we would all like more time. There is no doubt about that; I agree with it. But I believe that the circumstances that I have described do indicate and support the need for its early passage.

If we were sitting in the next two weeks, I would have quite a different view. But the fact is that parliament is not sitting for the next two weeks. The next sitting week that would enable the passage of the bill takes us to the end of February and the early part of March. By that stage, as I understand it and as the government has explained to Senator Spindler, Senator Harradine, Senator Chamarette and me, we would really have a major problem with the processes that are involved. I believe that the parliamentary program pattern is an unfortunate contributor to this situation.

Senator Harradine made the point, which I fully support, that this bill should not be passed until the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills report on the bill is available to the parliament. My understanding is that the bill was considered by the scrutiny of bills committee overnight or early this morning and that the committee will be reporting to the parliament this afternoon. It is reporting on a bill which is no different from the bill on which it reported in some detail last year. I am not privy to what is in the scrutiny of bills report that will be tabled today, but to say that the scrutiny of bills committee has not had an opportunity to look at the bill until the last couple of days is obviously not correct.

I do agree with Senator Harradine that proper process requires that the scrutiny of bills report be presented here before the bill is passed. That will happen, because the second reading debate will not conclude prior to the scrutiny of bills report becoming available. I am not sure how the timetabling process for this afternoon will go in relation to the Senate. However, one would hope that the processes and the logistics of the time pattern will certainly mean that the debate cannot be concluded until the bill has been received and people have had a chance to look at the scrutiny of bills report.

I will not hold up the Senate any longer, because some of the very important points about the bill that have been raised in this debate by Senator Chamarette, Senator Harradine and Senator Spindler are valid points that need debate. It seems to me that the appropriate time for that debate is the second reading debate on the bill and not this procedural motion. We will be supporting the government in its wish to have the bill considered at this time. Let us get on with the debate on the substance as soon as we can.

PARA.TAB: Having put that on the record, let me put one other matter on the record for Senator Short.
