TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which we have been debating procedurally but about which we now move into the substantive second reading debate, is a bill to enable the recently enacted safe third country provisions of the Migration Act 1958 to cover Vietnamese refugees who had already been successfully resettled in the People's Republic of China but who lodged claims for a protection visa in Australia after 30 December 1994.

PARA.TAB: The minister said that in his second reading speech. He also said that, more generally, the bill is also to enable the safe third country provisions of the act to have effect from a specified date preceding the date of commencement of any future agreements and relevant regulations. He also pointed out that in the last session of parliament the government introduced safe third country amendments to the Migration Act—I think they were in the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.4) 1994—to ensure that certain non-citizens in relation to whom there is a safe third country or who are covered by the comprehensive plan of action for Indochinese refugees known as the CPA should not be allowed to apply for a protection visa. The purpose of that legislation, which the coalition supported at the time and which of course was carried, was to prevent forum shopping by people who had already found a country which offered them protection or whose claims for refugee status had been rejected under an appropriate determination system.

The first application of that legislation was in respect of people who arrived in Australia from Galang, Indonesia, where they had been assessed as not being refugees under a refugee determination process approved by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. In passing that legislation last year, following an amendment moved by the coalition, the Senate required the government to report to the parliament on the screening procedures in Galang. The minister conformed to that requirement with material presented to parliament last week. We have not had a chance to go into that in the Senate since then, but we certainly will be doing so in the very near future.

The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks specifically to amend the Migration Act to create a safe third country agreement with the People's Republic of China to facilitate the return of Sino-Vietnamese boat people, particularly the approximately 700 people who have arrived here on eight or nine boats since the middle of November last year. The bill provides that Vietnamese refugees who have already had protection afforded to them by the PRC will not be permitted to make an application for protection in Australia, unless they can produce substantive evidence to suggest that they are in a genuine refugee situation. I will come to that matter in a moment. The bill also provides that if an application has already been made, after 30 December 1994, that application will cease to be valid. That date of 30 December is the date on which the minister made the announcements which foreshadowed this legislation.

The bill also states that, in relation to future safe third country regulations, certain visa applications will cease to be valid if made during a transitional period before the safe third country regulations take effect. That transitional period may start at a time specified by the minister, usually in a press release following the safe third country agreement, in the Gazette or a maximum of six months before the regulations take effect. This effectively means that, in the future, when the government wishes to set up an STC agreement, it does not have to go to parliament in order to backdate the provisions of the agreement. But it is important to note that it would be doing that instead by way of regulation which would be disallowable by the parliament.

As I said, since 13 November almost 700 Sino-Vietnamese have arrived illegally in Australia from the port of Baihai in southern China. The persons we are talking about started to arrive in mainland China in 1978, after the conclusion of the China-Vietnam border conflicts that preceded. That movement was stimulated by the border conflict between the PRC and Vietnam. Those refugees were issued with papers and, under the supervision of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees—and I think this is important—were resettled in both urban and rural China.

The UNHCR was actually invited by the PRC government to supervise that resettlement process. I think the UNHCR has had a presence there since 1981. Approximately 284,000 persons moved from Vietnam to China in this way between 1978 and the late 1980s. The Chinese government has spent an estimated $US760 million on projects to assist resettlement and the UNHCR has contributed an additional $82 million.

The movement of the Sino-Vietnamese people from China that we have witnessed in recent weeks is not, of course, the first time that such people have left China in search of a better life—a very understandable search for a better life. They were involved in movements from the PRC to Macau in the early 1980s and, more recently, to Japan and to Hong Kong. Similar third country agreements to that now being envisaged in this bill, the third agreement between Australia and the PRC, were signed between the PRC and Hong Kong in 1991 and between the PRC and Japan in, I think, 1993. They were to allow for the return, under the protection of the PRC, of about 23,000 people who had gone to Hong Kong, and about 1,500 that had gone to Japan. They were returned under that safe third country agreement.

What is proposed here is not new. As I understand it, it basically follows the pattern that was followed in at least those cases. The available evidence from those cases that was presented to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee in its hearings on this bill last week suggests quite strongly that the people who returned from Hong Kong and Japan were accepted back, have had the protection of the PRC and have not been persecuted in any way as a result of their return. The available evidence also suggests that the Sino-Vietnamese arrivals in recent weeks left China in search of a better life rather than because they are genuine refugees within the meaning of the definition contained in the 1951 UN Convention on the Status of Refugees, as amended by the 1967 protocol. The definition of a refugee, contained in the convention, is a person who:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . owing to a well founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, is outside the country of his nationality and is unable or, owing to such fear, is unwilling to avail himself of the protection of that country.

PARA.TAB: The reasons for persecution enumerated in the 1951 convention, usually termed `Convention reasons', constitute the exclusive reasons for persecution that will entitle an individual to a claim for refugee status.

SPEECH.PARA: We are a signatory to that agreement, as are many other countries, including the PRC, and it is very important that the actions of a country such as Australia—particularly Australia, from our point of view—accord with that convention.

PARA.TAB: I certainly would not—I do not think anyone would—blame the latest boat arrivals for wanting a better life. So they should. The point is: taking to the boats in this way is not the way to do it because of the impact it has, not only on the people, but on other refugees and on Australia's excellent refugee program.

The coalition will not be opposing this bill, and we have taken that view for several reasons. That is not to say that we do not have some concerns about the bill. I know my colleagues Senator Abetz and Senator Ellison, who will also be speaking in this debate, will take up some of those concerns, so I will not go into them in detail here, but I will leave it to my colleagues.

I point out that the bill has nothing to do with China's one-child policy. There has been some confusion in the public mind on this. China's one-child policy, which is the subject of a separate bill which will be debated and considered in the Senate in due course, essentially does not apply to Sino-Vietnamese. That is a point that needs to be made clear.

The coalition has also taken account of the fact that there is scope provided in the bill for a Sino-Vietnamese boat person to make application for refugee status. That is done through the minister's non-compellable discretion contained in proposed new subsection 91F(1). The report by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee states:

The proposed Subsection 91F(1) allows for the Minister, if he believes that it is in the public interest, to exempt persons from the STC provisions proposed by the Bill. An exercise of the discretion in an individual's favour would allow that individual to lodge an application for the determination of his or her refugee status.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to the government that we place considerable importance on that point. If this bill is to be applied fairly and equitably, taking into account Australia's responsibilities in the area of refugees and humanitarian care, then there must be a mechanism which will enable genuine applicants for refugee status to have their situation brought to the attention of the government and the minister and to have that discretion exercised. We accept, of course, that it is a non-compellable discretion. But we were told in the committee hearings that mechanisms and provisions would be put in place to ensure that proposed new section 91F does have practical application. The Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, in its conclusion, said:

They believe that it would be appropriate if the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs emphasised the procedures to deal with claims by Sino Vietnamese for refugee status and to deal with identification and with verification of individual's status as Sino-Vietnamese.
I believe we should go further than that in the sense of seeking a clear undertaking from the minister in regard to that. I am sure my colleagues will pursue that point at some additional length.

PARA.TAB: In not opposing the bill, we have placed much weight on the views of the UNHCR. According to the regional representative of the UNHCR for Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific, Mr Fontaine, who was a UNHCR representative in China for two or three years in the early 1990s, there is no evidence, as I said earlier, that once returned the Sino-Vietnamese will be subject to persecution. He told the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee at public hearings into this bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as a former chief of mission in China . . . I crisscrossed southern China between October 1990 and December 1992, both to monitor the implementation of projects which are financed by UNHCR, and to ensure that the protection of these people was properly carried out . . . What I can say and what UNHCR knows, is that we do not, as a group, have any information that would lead to the conclusion that, as a group, that these people have protection problems in China of any great significance.
He also went on to say:
I happened to be in China at the time of the return of the 1142 Vietnamese refugees who had gone to Japan, and I can guarantee you that there were no
reprisals taken against those people. There was no persecution of them.

Nothing could be more categorical than that from the UNHCR's official representative. I say again: the coalition has placed a great deal of weight on the evidence from Mr Fontaine. I have also mentioned the fact that the bill continues to permit the consideration of genuine refugee claims by way of ministerial discretion. I will not comment further on that.

PARA.TAB: Having dealt with the bill in that sense, I say in the strongest possible terms that I believe the situation this bill is designed to arrest should never have arisen. The Keating government and the responsible minister, Senator Bolkus, have been quite culpable in their failure to act earlier and in their continuing procrastination.

In December, the minister admitted publicly that he had been warned as long ago as April of last year that the influx we have seen of boats in recent weeks, particularly in that period of six or seven weeks from mid-November, would occur. He was told about it last April and did nothing at all about it. The minister must be held responsible for a large part of the concern that is now being felt by the general Australian community, who are concerned about the situation, and for the very real concern that has been generated on the part of the people who have come here and those who are aspiring to come to Australia as refugees generally. That is a situation that this minister will wear as a cross for a long time. It has led to great hardship and great concern on the part of a very large number of people including very genuine refugee seekers and refugee applicants.

The coalition has been drawing attention to this matter and these concerns for a considerable amount of time. It was only after the inflow had occurred that the government decided to take action. It is all very well for the minister to say now that he really could not do anything about negotiating before boats came along. What he did was fail to send the necessary signals to prevent this situation arising in the first instance. So we hold the minister very responsible for the regrettable situation that has arisen.

In saying that, I repeat that the coalition will not be opposing this legislation. We do believe it is necessary that this legislation be passed to get the clearest signal possible to the Chinese authorities and to impending boat people that, unless they are really and truly genuine refugee applicants, they will not be accepted into Australia if they come in a way which undermines Australia's orderly, case by case, offshore migration program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The bill does mark a low point in Australia's treatment of refugees. It is a shame and a black day for this parliament that the government is able to pass it—in fact, to rush it through—with the assistance of the coalition parties.

PARA.TAB: The bill amends the safe third country provisions in the Migration Act 1958, firstly to invalidate applications for protection visas made by Vietnamese refugees presently resettled in the People's Republic of China between 30 December 1994 and the taking effect of statutory rule No. 3 of 1995, which prescribes the PRC as a safe third country, and more generally to invalidate visa applications made during the transitional period before the commencement of an agreement between Australia and a safe third country. The regulation was made possible by a memorandum of understanding signed with the government of China on 25 January this year and has been prompted largely by the recent arrival in Australia of Sino-Vietnamese boat people.

The most significant policy aspect of the bill is to recognise the PRC, China, as a safe third country. The safe third country concept was introduced into Australian law in last year's Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994. It provides that certain people who have a prescribed connection with a country either covered by the comprehensive plan of action or with which Australia has a safe third country agreement cannot be allowed to apply for an individual protection visa. The Australian government argues that because the PRC has provided a community of Sino-Vietnamese refugees with housing, land and access to other facilities it is appropriate to prescribe the PRC as being a safe third country for the purposes of that community. Obviously, this argument is seriously flawed.

In view of the PRC's well-known, unsatisfactory human rights record, it is cynical in the extreme for the government to now seek to designate the PRC as a so-called safe third country. When appearing before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, Mr Dennis Richardson, who is from the department, conceded:

SPEECH.PARA: The expression of concerns about China's general human rights record is a very legitimate point to make. Successive Australian Governments have consistently expressed concern about aspects of China's human rights record . . .
That, apparently, does not appear to worry the government in introducing a bill that, nevertheless, describes the PRC as a safe third country.

PARA.TAB: The President of the Indo-China Refugee Association, Mrs Marion Le, added that her association strongly objected to the prescribing of the People's Republic of China as a safe third country for a particular minority group, saying:

SPEECH.PARA: China continues to be . . . a totalitarian dictatorship with an appalling human rights record.

One can only say, `Hear, hear!' I believe that the government as well as the coalition parties will have to live with what they do in this particular bill when we continue to receive news of human rights violations in the PRC. We might just briefly reflect on the fact that the United States has in recent times taken a much stronger stand, as far as China is concerned, on the human rights issue. It is a stance that, to our shame, we do not seem to be prepared to emulate.

PARA.TAB: I must also say that, for a number of reasons, I am not convinced by the arguments put forward by Senator Short that we should place great reliance on the observations made by Mr Fontaine, the UNHCR commissioner, who has spent some time in China. Firstly, I think his presence in China is now some time ago. Secondly, Mr Fontaine is only one person. He is not individually affected by what happens to the people who are living in China as refugees from Vietnam. I believe it is our obligation to assess what the people themselves have experienced. In fact, we have the record, our own record, of that having been done, inasmuch as we know that substantial majorities of previous boat loads of people who have come to Australia have been found to be refugees under the United Nations' definition.

Why all of a sudden this painstaking individual assessment of the people who have arrived here in Australia seeking asylum should be discarded, just because an official says that, according to his observation, they have not as a group experienced any persecution in China, is beyond me. I do not think that is a sufficient ground at all. Even though they as a group may not have been singled out, that does not exclude individual members of that group having been exposed to persecution and having a well-founded fear of further persecution. I believe it is that point we need to consider.

There is considerable evidence of discrimination, on the part of the PRC government, against certain Sino-Vietnamese. Evidence of this was presented to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. Ms Phillipa Martin, who worked in Port Hedland for the Refugee Council, explained that Sino-Vietnamese were not given the same rights as Chinese nationals. She gave an account of one family, who arrived on a boat named the Dalmatian, having been expelled from Vietnam in 1979. After spending time caught in the war between the Chinese and the Vietnamese, they were transported to a remote arid area and left with a small amount of rice; they indeed found it difficult to survive. As they were not given household registration, they were forced to work for very low pay and were unable to move. They were also forced to pay higher rates for education.

Another account was given of P who was born on Cat Ba Island. He was eight years old when he was sent to Beihai to meet up with his mother; he did not meet up with her. But on arriving at Beihai he was placed in the care of an old lady who survived by scavenging in refuse dumps. He was unable to attend school, was not eligible for food coupons and was not able to get free or subsidised health care. His house was demolished in June. He wanted to marry, but without household registration he was unable to get a marriage certificate. He sought a new life in Australia—and was, indeed, characterised as a refugee. He and some other people were successful in their application for refugee status in Australia. Indeed, all seven people on board the Dalmatian and 46 out of 53 people on board the Pluto were accepted as refugees by Australia. Of the Sino-Vietnamese on board the Toto, six were accepted as refugees, and all 51 people on board the Unicorn were accepted.

However, if this bill becomes law, people in similar circumstances will be prevented from being granted refugee status, with the one exception that was outlined: a non-compellable discretion to be exercised by the minister—and I will come to that a little later. Our obligations under the convention relating to refugees will remain the same, the only change being the limitation of the application of international law in Australian courts.
However, as the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Sir Ronald Wilson, has argued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the fact that the government did not appreciate the reach of the convention . . . [at the time of its signing] cannot change the meaning of the convention nor the obligations assumed under it.

Mr Manocha said on behalf of the Ethnic Communities Council of the ACT that, if Australia does not consider it has an obligation to specifically consider the claims of those people persecuted or in fear of persecution owing to their membership of a particular group, it should either withdraw from the 1951 refugees convention or limit, by reservation, its interpretation of its obligations.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it is a rhetorical challenge to say that the Australian government, in passing and proposing to pass legislation such as this bill, is not meeting its obligations under the convention. China cannot be a safe third country since the Sino-Vietnamese applicants for refugee status are not making claims of persecution against their country of origin, Vietnam, but rather against the designated country itself—China.

The Law Council of Australia has responded that, in these circumstances, it is logically and factually difficult to regard China as being a designated safe third country for these asylum seekers. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Vietnamese are making claims of persecution against China, it would seem totally inappropriate and an abdication of Australia's international obligations to persons seeking refugee protection on our shores to designate China a safe third country in respect of these people.
One can only say, `Hear, hear.' Another witness before the committee, Mr Pierre-Michel Fontaine, agreed, arguing that this bill:

. . . purports to decree that any person in a defined category is, by definition, someone who cannot possibly have a valid refugee claim, simply on the basis of the consideration that their fear of persecution by the Vietnamese authorities 10 or so years ago were satisfactorily taken care of through the UNHCR supervisory element in the PRC.

There is another element in this bill which is causing concern; that is, its retrospective effect. It was designed to invalidate visa applications which had been made before the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) even announced this legislation. These applications were made on the basis of the law as it stood when these asylum seekers arrived. People who make such applications have, I believe, a legitimate expectation that the procedure will not change before the application has been assessed on its merits. As noted by the Law Council of Australia:

The idea of legislation of a retrospective nature dealing with matters raised in a media release made by the Minister is abhorrent, particularly in circumstances where the Minister may well be reacting to the political pressures of the time.

I now turn to the non-compellable ministerial discretion. In proposed new subsection 91F(1)(b), the minister may determine that section 91G does not apply if it is `in the public interest to do so' to a particular non-citizen. This discretion is put forward as a safeguard against genuine refugees being refused access arbitrarily.

PARA.TAB: However, its practical effect is obviously limited. For example, the committee has had evidence that the recent processing of 26 applicants for refugee status within 48 hours left no real opportunities for ministerial review. It would be even more difficult if the department's maximum estimate of 5,000 boat arrivals ever eventuated. Eve Lester, from the Refugee Advisory Casework Service, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not actually accept that the suggestion of 5,000 is accurate, but if that is the case, and the minister is faced with a large number of people, how can that in all reasonableness, be described as a safeguard? It is simply not.

Applications for refugee status are sometimes made from overseas, and there is no provision for any procedures to deal with that eventuality. Further, the criterion of public interest, as defined by the minister, does not necessarily equate with Australia's responsibility to assess refugee status according to the international convention on refugees or on the basis of humanitarian considerations.

PARA.TAB: Finally, there is obviously no clear provision on how the asylum seeker can trigger consideration of his or her case by the minister. I hope that the minister and the department will take note of the observations made by the committee in its report, which suggests that clear procedures need to be laid down to ensure that asylum seekers are made aware of this possibility. I add to that that there should also be a clear obligation on the part of the department to inform people arriving on Australia's shores of their legal rights, something that on the basis of evidence received has simply not happened in the past.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats believe that this bill is so faulty, both in its objective and in its execution, that the Senate should accept its responsibility to throw it out. It does mark a low point in Australia's treatment of refugees. I believe that, as in a number of other areas—and I will just briefly mention East Timor—we are giving up a claim to being a champion of human rights in the region, a claim which at one point may have been justified, but, increasingly, we are wasting it. Increasingly, this government and, in this case, the coalition parties are putting their names to legislation which can only be described as contrary to the principles of human rights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a contribution to the debate on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. At the outset, let me say that I speak on this bill with some mixed feelings. Most witnesses that came before the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee looking into this bill complained about the shortness of time the committee had to consider the impact of this legislation. Similarly, I join with them and indicate that I share their concern.

PARA.TAB: As the shadow spokesman on immigration, Senator Short, has indicated, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) had ample notice of this evolving problem. Indeed, on 30 December last year the minister made a statement as to what his intentions would be once the parliament resumed. Whilst I accept that the situation that faces Australia is an urgent one, I would have thought that the ethnic communities and those organisations that seek to assist refugees and those people that come to our shores could have been provided with an exposure draft of the legislation and further information a lot earlier than they actually were.

Having said that, I will turn to the bill. In my view the bill deals with a fundamental issue of principle—that is, the conflict between dealing with a difficult situation and yet looking after individual needs at the same time. That is the balancing act that has to be undertaken by all governments from time to time. It appears to me that the government has approached this issue on the basis that it will deal with the 99.9 per cent as being basically, in its terms, the problem and then hope that it has a mechanism to look after the 0.1 per cent who may be treated harshly as a result of this bill. My own prejudice is that I would seek to have greater protection for the 0.1 per cent rather than try to deal with the so-called problem of the 99.9 per cent.

Clearly, Australia is in some difficulty when it has had arrive on its shores since 13 November last year nine boats containing some 676 Sino-Vietnamese. It should not be forgotten in this debate that these people started arriving as early as 1978. It has been an ongoing situation for our country to consider and tackle, if it were seen as a problem.

The threshold question really is: how do we assess and provide protection for an individual who may well have a reasonably based fear of persecution despite coming from a so-called safe third country? The safe third country legislation, as has been indicated by previous speakers, was inserted into our migration legislation towards the end of last year as a mechanism that could be applied, but there was no direct application of that mechanism until the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1995.

This bill seeks, in effect, to limit the status of `safe third country' not to all people coming from the People's Republic of China but only to those who are classified as Sino-Vietnamese. So in general terms it has a fairly limited global application. My concern, as I indicated earlier, was that whilst we, sitting comfortably in Canberra, may say that it has a very limited application, I dare say that if you were one of the refugees at Port Hedland you would not be saying that because it would have direct application on you personally. That is the concern I had with the way this legislation is structured.

The legislation seeks to declare the People's Republic of China, or the PRC, as a safe third country for the purposes of the Sino-Vietnamese people. I have some difficulty in accepting the logic that the Sino-Vietnamese are in a safe third country because, as Senator Spindler pointed out, these people allege that they are fleeing from China and not from Vietnam. When you are fleeing from China it would be somewhat galling to be told by a country such as Australia that you will be sent back to a `safe' third country—the country that you are fleeing. I have very real difficulties with that. Legally and technically I am advised that the Sino-Vietnamese are still classified as Vietnamese nationals and, therefore, having originally fled or left Vietnam—albeit ten or 15 years ago—they are now in a third country which we are now going to describe as safe for them, despite the fact that because they believed China was not a safe country they fled to Australia.

That to my mind provides a very real problem in this legislation. Indeed, it may well cause a problem for the government if this legislation is ever tested. I would have thought that those Sino-Vietnamese, whom this legislation is intended to target, would be able to assert, and assert forcefully, that the PRC is their country of habitual residency. The Law Council of Australia submitted in its submission to the legal and constitutional committee at paragraph 3.5 the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The questions which arise and which should be addressed in any proper and fair system of refugee determination include whether or not these people have a nationality or are stateless and whether or not, considering the definition of refugee, they should be treated as being nationals of Vietnam or habitual residents of China. These issues are fundamental to their proper treatment by Departmental decision-makers in Australia and relevant to a consideration of the purpose and effect of the amendments proposed.
The Law Council's representative, Mr Peter Rose, said at page 102 of the Hansard of that committee:
The view that we have at the moment is that it—
referring to the People's Republic of China—
appears to be a country of habitual residence rather than a third country.
The New South Wales Bar Association also expressed its concern at page 2 of its submission:

In our view the retrospective operation of the safe third country provisions of the Migration Act in the manner proposed by this Bill is unjust. The right of persons to apply for refugee status is fundamentally important for the maintenance of human rights. If this right is to be retrospectively removed, there should be compelling reasons to do so. We do not believe that questions of administrative convenience and the fact that there will be `some savings in onshore refugee determination processing costs' constitutes such compelling reasons in the present circumstances. Nor do we believe that the provisions of the bill enabling the Minister to waive the retrospectivity provisions in an individual case will operate to overcome effectively any injustice.

PARA.TAB: Dr Fonteyne, a doctor of law at the Australian National University, said the following in his submission:

SPEECH.PARA: This bill clearly illustrates the dangers inherent in the `safe third country' concept incorporated in the Migration Act late last year. Based on a rather simplistic and formalistic Memorandum of Understanding reached with the PRC Government, the bill purports to decree that any person in the defined category is by definition someone who cannot possibly have a valid refugee claim—simply on the basis of the consideration that their fear of persecution by the Vietnamese authorities 10 or so years ago were satisfactorily taken care of through UNHCR—supervised resettlement in the PRC. What it of course ignores is the possibility that the resettled refugees may now in turn have become a target of persecution at the hands of the authorities in their country of refuge—which may or may not be the case in fact.

I interpose that on all the evidence it would seem that they are not being persecuted by the People's Republic of China. I want to acknowledge that. But, nevertheless, just in case there are some among these hundreds of people who are genuinely suffering, I do have concerns. Dr Fonteyne goes on to say:

The important point, though, is that the Government is seeking to make such a determination as a matter of general finding, thereby precluding (other than, once again, through discretionary ministerial dispensation) consideration of an individual's particular circumstances.
So on the face of it there are very real concerns about this legislation. We need to rely on the goodwill of the department, the minister and the administrative processes that are to be applied.

PARA.TAB: I have been advised by departmental officers—I thank them for giving me that understanding of how the system works—that when these boat people arrive in Australia they will be held in the appropriate camps and that the appropriate checks will then be made with the Chinese authorities to ascertain whether these people are known to the Chinese government. If they are known to the Chinese government, safe third country status will apply to them.

Checking that out will take a matter of weeks. During that time, one would imagine that those organisations and groups that do such a marvellous job for the refugees and other boat people that have arrived in Australia will also be able to sort through them and talk to these people to ascertain whether any of them have genuine refugee status.

Each individual boat person is submitted to an individual interview by a departmental officer. One would hope that those departmental officers are at all times fully alert to the possibility of one of these people—in other words, each individual—being an appropriate person to submit to the minister for the purposes of going through the normal channels, if I can so describe it, to seek refugee status. But if that public servant who interviews fails to do so, that person's chance of being provided with that status may well fall. If that happens, there would be a great injustice. As I understand it, the system would also require the interviewing officer to send his or her report on each individual interview to another departmental officer, who will also check the written version of that interview to ascertain whether there are any hints within the documentation that might indicate an appropriate refugee status.

Unfortunately, all we can do is rely on the goodwill of the minister and the department. I have difficulties with that. I see Senator Chamarette frowning at that, and I must say that in my heart of hearts I share that concern. Whilst the legislation on its face is very harsh, once you look at the way it is actually implemented there is the possibility that the minister, undoubtedly not in person but once again through a public servant, would provide status to allow them to go through the refugee assessment process.

Unfortunately, the minister's discretion in this is non-compellable. We were told at the committee hearing on this bill that the reason for that is it is basically how it is in other parts of the legislation. I am not sure that that in itself is a compelling reason as to why the minister ought to be granted the same power in this particular circumstance. Non-compellability basically means that if the minister does not make an appropriate decision there is no recourse and the person will simply have to accept the outcome.

We are confronted with a government that fiddled whilst Rome was burning. Government members fiddled whilst the problem, as they describe it as a problem, developed and then all of a sudden, when they were overwhelmed by the nine boats that had arrived since 13 November, the minister decided to take action, and quick action. Whilst the taking of quick action is to be applauded, there are different ways of going about that sort of action. For example, if this legislation had been delayed another fortnight I do not think we would have seen a flood of boats from Beihai coming to Australia. I have some concern as to the overwhelming urgency with which this matter has been treated.

Undoubtedly, it does play to a sentiment within the Australian community that the Australian community has basically been targeted as a soft spot for people who are seeking economic refugee status in Australia simply because they want a better life. If that is the case, I would argue we have basic problems with the total administration of the system. We should not simply target the Sino-Vietnamese and allow the minister, by simple regulation in the future, to declare more and more safe third countries.

I should point out in fairness to this debate—this is another one of those safeguards that has enabled me to feel somewhat more comfortable with this legislation—that whenever the minister makes a regulation in adding another country, or another group of people from a country, to safe third country status that regulation is subject to disallowance by this Senate or, indeed, the House of Representatives. There is once again another safeguard.

I think this whole process has been rushed. I know the people of Australia clearly are saying in relation to those seeking economic refuge that enough is enough and the government ought to act. The government has acted, and it has acted quickly and promptly, but I think it has rushed too much.

As I indicated earlier, delaying this legislation for another 14 days to allow other groups to have the full opportunity to consider the impact of this legislation would not have led to a rush of other boat people to this country. We may have been able to deal with the legislation, the committee system and all the other aspects of this bill in a more orderly fashion and possibly have come up with a conclusion which would have been a safeguard for the Sino-Vietnamese boat people and also future categories of people who may be provided with STC status.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I very much appreciated the comments by Senator Abetz that I was able to hear. I regret that, being engaged in a discussion on another matter, I did not hear all of them. I agree with him that it may have been far better to have had a further fortnight to look at this legislation. I note for the public record one of the rare occasions when Senator Abetz and I are in almost complete agreement. Unfortunately, because his party did not vote a certain way, we are not on the same sides of the debate at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 is yet another bill in a long line of disgraceful pieces of legislation in the area of administration of Australia's onshore refugee program. Of course, I use the term `onshore refugee program' in the broadest construction possible because this government does not have a program as such. It has a shambles of a system which lurches from one crisis to another and from one policy change to another, basically plugging up loopholes that have appeared. I will not recount the sorry tale of misery which the government has inflicted on asylum seekers who have arrived unannounced. We all know the story too well. Neither will I recount the shameful trail of legislation which has marked each new repressive step in the government's response to these groups whom we have now all come to know as `boat people'.

I think there is perhaps one small Pyrrhic victory or kind of black comedy in this bill for those of us who have opposed the government's refugee policies over the years, and that is that it demonstrates once and for all that detention does not work as a deterrent. When we consider the sad history of the past five years, we see that hundreds of people have had their fundamental rights to liberty and due process systematically abused by this government. It is apparent that sending a strong signal—that phrase so much loved by this government—has been a dismal failure. Providing, in my view, a repressive measure directed towards the Sino-Vietnamese will send a signal, but there is no evidence whatsoever to suggest it has any impact on those people who, for reasons apart from the ones that have been implied here in earlier debate, are driven to flee their countries, seek these shores and seek asylum—for which we, in all conscience, should be giving them a due process by which they can be considered to warrant it.

Why should the government ever have thought that detention would work? Of course, people facing physical danger and uncertainty in the aftermath of the Cambodian peace process would choose to flee. Faced with the coercive family planning policies in China, of course people would flee. The government has so far not dealt adequately with allegations of corruption in the refugee assessment process in Indonesia but wants to declare those who come here after Galang to be not eligible to apply for a protection visa. Where will it end?

The government is very proud of its record in making 13,000 places available in its refugee and humanitarian program this year. I do not want to minimise the significance of that. It is a credit to the government and it is certainly to be supported. But, when the same government claims to be a champion of human rights throughout the world while it denies the existence of some human rights abuses to suit its own convenience, the government shows itself for what it is.

I think Senator Abetz referred to the need to move away from these short-term ad hoc changes to a long-term view that demonstrates where the government is coming from in relation to its onshore program and also its response to asylum seekers. I would venture to suggest that the reason why it does not do that is that it is playing with a double standard. On the one hand, it wants to be seen as very enlightened, very progressive and a protector of human rights throughout the world. On the other hand, it is absolutely paranoid about people who approach our shores without pieces of paper. If it actually provided a policy that laid that on the line, it would be exposed to ridicule and humiliation because it does place itself in a double standard position.

I have some specific comments on the bill, but I have already made them quite clear in the previous debate. The information that has arisen from the committee process has been very valuable. I have read it. I have not had the time that this issue deserves to analyse its impact. I am grateful for the comments from the various speakers, including the minister's, that have added to my information about that. In response to the minister's accusation that I am speaking from ignorance, if that is a genuine concern of the minister, then he could clearly have allowed time for those of us whom he considers to be ignorant to gain the information we seek or need to be less concerned about the approach that the government is taking. I do not think it is ignorance; it is that we have a different analysis of what is occurring.

I will have further questions in the committee process. I do not assume that I have been able to grasp the full implications of this bill. There are various matters I want to raise. Firstly, there is the matter in this bill which relates to the PRC gaining safe third country status. I believe evidence was presented to the committee that this is highly questionable. Mr Matthew Zagor of Amnesty International Australia produced evidence to the committee. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Amnesty is unaware of the safe third country definition being applied to the very country where the alleged violations which are the grounds for a claim are occurring . . . This is a misuse of our legislation and it refuses to recognise legitimate concerns about the human rights situation in the People's Republic of China. The use of the safe third country legislation will exclude an entire group of people from making claims on any grounds. In other words, if you are a Vietnamese refugee who has settled in China, no matter what may have happened to you in China, you will be sent back . . . The government is deciding and implementing that decision in law that no Vietnamese are facing persecution of any kind whatsoever in the People's Republic of China.

I know there is one escape clause there which lies in the discretion of the minister, and I will raise that possible safeguard in the committee stage with the minister. The second aspect of grave concern is that of the retrospectivity impact of this bill. We see that two areas are affected by retrospectivity. One is in relation to the Sino-Vietnamese who have already been granted status. This bill will backdate the granting of the safe third country status to the PRC to 30 December 1994, which, as somebody pointed out, is the date of the minister's press statement. So here we have legislation enacting a press statement. The bill, by that effect, will basically take away the status that has already been granted to some people. Therefore, we have an injustice that will be apparent in its effect on numbers of people who have already received some kind of acceptance into the refugee application process.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the bill is retrospective in that it sets up a legal regime where the minister can announce in the Gazette a cut-off day prior to a safe third country being gazetted in the usual manner in accordance with the principal act, the Migration Act. That means that at any point, if the minister chooses, the granting of an STC—or safe third country status—will immediately blank out and have an effect on those people who may have already been granted their refugee status. I emphasise that this is a question I want to ask the minister so, if there is an error of assumption on my part, I would be very glad to have it cleared up.

I will sum up the concerns about the retrospective operation of STCs in a quote from the New South Wales Bar Association at the committee's hearings. It criticised the retrospective operation of the STC provisions of the Migration Act, in the manner proposed in the bill, by saying they were unjust. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The right of persons to apply for refugee status is fundamentally important for the maintenance of human rights. If this right is to be retrospectively removed, there should be compelling reasons to do so. We do not believe that questions of administrative convenience and the fact that there will be "some savings in onshore refugee determination processing costs" constitute such compelling reasons in the present circumstances. Nor do we believe that the provisions of the bill enable the minister to waive the retrospective provisions in individual cases will operate to overcome effectively any injustice.

Thirdly, it seems to me that the group, rather than the individual, is receiving a determination. That seems highly undesirable. I will quote from the minority report put forward by Senator Spindler, noting that he did not refer to it earlier. It said:

As Marion Le argued before the Committee, the measures in this bill appear to have been designed to act as a deterrent to would-be applicants, irrespective of their merit, and that the legislation represents an attempt to turn refugee processing back into an ad hoc decision making process by the minister.
Ms Le asked:
What is the point of a refugee definition that gets narrowed every time it looks like there may be too many refugees?
Finally, the bill is discriminatory against Vietnamese nationals. I will quote Ms Angela Chan, Chairperson of the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales. She said:

We also believe that the proposed legislation is discriminatory: it discriminates against people from the PRC and the Vietnamese. It also opposes a general policy of access and equity and Australia's general commitment to multiculturalism. Is it a subtle return to the white Australia policy?

I know that they are strong terms and I think the minister has to respond to a very strong case that this bill is discriminatory in its operation and in its design. I will quote from the submission of the Catholic Bishops Conference to the legal and constitutional committee. It said:

Now the Australian Government has declared China a Safe Third Country and made a pact with that country to trade off what appears to be one human rights abuse for another. Australia agrees to overlook the asylum seekers claims of human rights abuses in China if the Chinese government will cooperate with Australia in denying the people's right to seek relief here and on condition that Australia pay all the costs.

We heard the minister say that people are horrified that we are offering, or even being seen to offer, protection to people on whom, he says, $1 billion has been spent by the UNHCR and the PRC. I wonder how the public will react to the government's agreement with China to pay costs involved in repatriating the boat people? What costs and compensation has the government agreed to?

PARA.TAB: I know how the phone lines in my office rang hot when the possibility arose that those boat people who have been detained illegally may be able to claim compensation. I recall the abuse heaped on those who support the asylum seekers' rights in this matter by government senators at the time. Perhaps those same government senators might now like to put the same arguments to the cabinet.

This bill is a disgrace. It shows conclusively what the government thinks of the rule of law in relation to asylum seekers. It once again shows that the government cannot bear to lose in the courts and that it wants unilaterally to change the entire corpus of international law in relation to refugees. We will oppose this bill as we have opposed its predecessors.

When it employs people such as Tony Fleming, and in particular Simon Balderstone, as its senior environmental advisers, then it is obvious the agenda will be distorted. This Mr Balderstone is the one and the same who wrote in approving terms of the environmental terrorist organisation `Earth First'. As stated in the editorial part of the column by Simon Balderstone, the top adviser on environmental matters to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when discussing this issue and talking of his interview with Mr Foreman, the founder of the `Earth First' movement in the United States, and the way that these people campaign:
And unless anyone is directly injured as a result of an Earth First! piece of `ecotage', he has a very good argument.

SPEECH.PARA: And listeners ought to be aware that `ecotage' is the way that extremist Greens refer to sabotage. Let me just repeat that: Mr Balderstone said that, unless anyone is directly injured as a result of an `Earth First' piece of ecotage, he, Mr Foreman, has a very good argument.

PARA.TAB: I pose a very simple question: what about indirect injury? By implication, Mr Balderstone, the senior adviser on environmental matters to the Prime Minister and this government, is saying that indirect injury to forest workers is okay in the defence of the forests. That person is employed by the Prime Minister. As a little aside, I ask a hypothetical question of the media—and of course it is completely hypothetical. Let us imagine if our former Leader of the Opposition, Alexander Downer, had addressed a League of Rights meeting; how would the media have treated that—such a terrible organisation? Of course, that question is purely hypothetical.

But where has the media been on this issue? Where has the media been? Other than for John Laws and Glenn Milne, there has been a conspiracy of silence perpetrated by the media. All I ask of the media is that, if they are going to treat somebody like Alexander Downer in the way they did just because he happened to address a League of Rights meeting, surely they ought to deal with other extremist groups in exactly the same way.

At a pathetically attended rally in Hobart yesterday, organised by the greens, the assembled were invited to a little puppet show later that week—undoubtedly, to raise money for the greens. But I say to those people: if ever anyone wanted to watch a display of puppetry, they should have been in Canberra over the past weeks. There they would have been entertained by the Rolls Royce of all puppet shows. It was a four-act feature, highlighting the four different positions held by the government over the last seven weeks. The script, narration and cast were supplied by courtesy of the greens. The problem and the tragedy is that it was played out on the taxpayer funded stage of Canberra.

The puppet show was a classic Punch and Judy between Ministers Beddall and Faulkner. We had Beddall starting off on the stage alone, allowing people to go about their normal business in the forests, except in 85 coupes. Then at the other end of the stage, we see this hapless puppet of the green movement, now commonly referred to as Forrest Gump, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), regurgitating his lines which had been scripted by the greens. So along came Mr Plod, the policeman, trying to restore order to this scene of domestic violence. But Mr Plod, alias the Prime Minister, was being pulled about on strings by none other than Simon Balderstone, to whom I have referred earlier, who comes from the Prime Minister's own office. So the Prime Minister, in his role of Mr Plod, tried to settle the domestic and announced that only 509 coupes were to be taken from the people of Australia and given to the greens. The high farce of that decision has now been exposed. As to those 509 coupes, when counted, there were 511. In our state of Tasmania, out of the 72 coupes on the list, 12 that ended up in the 511 were not even on the original list of 1,300.

Yesterday Senator Alston asked questions about the Glenbogg State Forest in Victoria, which had previously been logged and has powerlines going through it. We have had examples all over Australia about quarries, airfields and clear-felled areas being included.

After that debacle, Labor has introduced further farce into the play by calling in another character. Senator Collins, of pay TV debacle fame, has been given the impossible task—like that given to `all the king's horsemen and all the king's men' who were trying to put Humpty together again. The fact is that, much as Senator Collins will try, he won't be able to put the pieces together of our flourishing forest industry. He won't be able to put the pieces together of the families and the communities. He won't be able to put the pieces together of regional Australia. He won't be able to put the pieces together of our sawmillers and veneer makers. He won't be able to put the pieces together of our economy. He won't be able to put the pieces together of our forest industry.

The policy paralysis, the backflips and the `one step forward, two steps back' policy development of Labor under its part-time Prime Minister, unfortunately, is not a fairytale. It is a real and living tragedy for thousands of Australians who have had their lives disrupted unnecessarily.

In this debate, we have seen Labor having more faces and masks than Marcel Marceau. Indeed, it has been the greens, in concert with Labor, who have so selfishly—through their blind ideological bent and from the comfort of their suburban armchairs—fought, and won for a while, against the real interests of Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have obviously been to the theatre lately—Marcel Marceau, Punch and Judy, Humpty Dumpty.

—Some people would say, Senator Sherry, that Senator Collins could be described as a Humpty Dumpty, but I won't be as rude as to do that. If you want to interject with inane interjections, I will respond and do you each time. I would have thought that you would have had enough of that in student politics, Senator Sherry, but if you want to keep it up here, I will engage you again up here.

PARA.TAB: The simple fact is that the greens have adopted an approach that the end justifies the means. We now know that they distorted those 1,300 coupes in their seven weeks, recommending a coupe per hour, 24 hours a day, seven days a week. Then we had the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), still struggling to retain some credibility, talking about `ground truthing' during question time yesterday—in other words, gobbledegook for saying that the greens and the conservation movement did not check the coupes before they made the recommendations. They did not engage in ground truthing. I suggest to the minister that they ground the truth into the dirt, and the minister ought to have the guts to say so.

The Democrats have pulled the same stunt. It seems to be one of these things from the green movement in recent times: just plead wide, make all sorts of outrageous allegations and hope that you are never checked up on. The Democrats, during the Christmas break, engaged upon a campaign of exposing the `dirty dozen'—Australia's 12 worst beaches—and they picked on a Bundaberg beach. When questioned by the media in the Bundaberg News Mail, Senator Woodley said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the city was chosen because of its position at the centre of a sugar cane growing area . . .

He went on to mention concerns about other things. In credit to Senator Woodley, when it was pointed out to him and he was fully exposed, he at least had the decency to apologise for the disruption that he had caused to that community.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we might often see the Democrats and the greens as Tweedledee and Tweedledum, in this debate it is really Tweedledum for the Democrats and Tweedle-very-dumb for the greens, because the greens have had the opportunity, but they have not had the stomach, to apologise for the absolute disruption that they have caused the forest industry.
