SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Acting Deputy President and the Senate would be aware, the East Timor situation has been a running sore in foreign policy for 20 years—the invasion of East Timor being in 1975. Over that 20 years, there have been many notable peaks that have gained high public profile in the Australian press. The accusations in the Sydney Morning Herald against the Suharto family's wealth was one of those peaks that angered our nearest northern neighbour, Indonesia. The Dili massacre in 1991 was another one of those notable peaks gaining public profile. The issue has not gone away over the 20 years, regardless of the Prime Minister's claim last year on his travels that this is a 1970s issue that is over and done with. It is far from that.

PARA.TAB: The media has played a vital role in keeping Timor on the agenda. That probably has much to do with the unsolved murders of the television camera crew in 1975. As reported last year, they were grotesque murders. They were not killed by a bullet to the back of the head—the murderers went further than that. The issue has peaked again in today's paper, if anyone has read the paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which paper?

—In all papers. Pick up the most widely read newspaper in this country, the Melbourne Herald-Sun, and you will see two feature articles—one editorial and one cartoon—and a page 5 article. That is what the Herald-Sun, has dedicated to the latest East Timorese issue. As Senator Sherry would know, it is a battle being fought in the International Court of Justice in The Hague, where I should note that a former senator from Tasmania, Senator Tate—
—He is doing a very good job, too.
—He has not finished yet, I should imagine.
—No.
—Senator Tate always does a good job representing Australia and he is doing a good job on this occasion. A good representative will never let you know where his heart truly lies.

PARA.TAB: I am not surprised at the bile—as it has been described—from both sides. I visited Portugal last year and met with many representatives to talk about this matter of East Timor. In fact, I met the parliamentary committee overseeing East Timor. It was their summer break but the full committee came to meet me. I was quite taken aback and even offended by the Portuguese bile and insults towards Australia at that meeting. On many occasions they overstepped the mark.

TALK.START.PARA: —How? Tell us.

—No, I will not tell the Senate. They were just insulting towards Australia and our position on East Timor. Even I—and Senator Sherry well knows my position on East Timor—was not going to take that from the Portuguese, and that is on the record!
—The Portuguese have a very poor record.

—They are a lot more hot-blooded and vicious about this issue than what I had originally thought. Of course, it is now all coming out in the international court. I do not want to dwell on the point as I have other points to make. However, the bile, as it has been described in the newspapers, does not surprise me. I think it is unnecessary and I do not think Australia deserves that form of attack.

PARA.TAB: Without going into the intricacies of the case or the history of the whole dispute, Australia really needs to update its argument for the court and show some really concrete results that its foreign policy has brought to the issue. After all, Senator Evans walks into this parliament time and again and at question time, in answer to the Democrats, really pleads with us just to wait and see that this even-handed approach will have a greater effect than the approach the international community is taking, no less the United Nations.

We have to put on the table the concrete results of our foreign policy position. But it does seem that the argument from Senator Tate in the international court has begun and ended with no more than a condemnation of Portugal's colonial role—that old hackneyed argument. It truly needs to be updated. In today's Australian, Greg Sheridan runs that argument and nothing more—nothing more than an attack on the Portuguese colonial role. Now for the very lazy observer it is always the first and only argument used to defend Indonesia's invasion of East Timor. There is no other argument put forward as to why Indonesia had a right to invade East Timor than that the Portuguese were lousy colonists. I am not going to defend the Portuguese role in East Timor—

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—Look, I think they would concede that after 400 years they could have done more, but that is not relevant to today. It has nothing to do with justifying Indonesia's invasion and subsequent human right atrocities since then.

PARA.TAB: The Portuguese, in coming to the most current, modern-day defence of the East Timorese, do not seek to re-colonise East Timor—they do not seek sovereign rule of the East Timorese people. Rather, they seek the self-determination of the East Timorese people. So what is the point of running the line that they were lousy colonists when today all Portugal wants is that the East Timorese have self-determination and are independent of Indonesia? Whatever the past sins of the Portuguese, they are today doing the right thing.

Secondly, as Australia pontificates on the Portuguese role, it forgets to mention that the Timorese people themselves seek the defence and support of the Portuguese. They do not want Indonesian rule. They do not support Australia's position. They want the Portuguese to carry out their defence in the international courts and in other arenas such as the United Nations. So the very people that we are debating about seek the comfort and support of the Portuguese people. They do not want to be in the Indonesian camp. I think that is a pretty potent argument to say that Portugal does have a legitimate role in this debate.

Further, the argument run by Greg Sheridan is another tired old one which, by the way, is all pre-1975. Both arguments are pre-1975. He runs the argument that the Fretilin group was a communist group out of control. Again, I will not go into the intricacies of that claim except to say that that needs new analysis. The Cold War has collapsed. That is no longer a relevant argument. It was once an argument run against the ANC or the IRA.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ran it against us too, I recall.

—Still true today. That is another debate. No, Senator Sherry, that is still true today. If Senator Sherry had his way and did not have the pressures and realities of the market he would be a tired old socialist. The point is that there is laziness of debate on this issue and the debate needs to be upgraded. By the way, that applies not just to Senator Sherry's side of the house, but to this side of the House also. There are too many lazy politicians who trump out the old `They were communists and they were bad colonists.' They are all pre-1975 issues and, with the collapse of the Cold War and the fact that East Timorese people want the Portuguese to play a role, I just cannot see how they are a defence. Yet that is the defence and, it seems, the only defence we are running in the international court.

PARA.TAB: By the way, the East Timorese certainly have more friends on this issue than Australia has. They have got the support of the United Nations, they have got the support of the European Community and they have got the support of the United States Congress and Senate. They do not only have the support of the former Democrat held Congress and Senate, they also have the support of the Republican Congress and Senate of today. They have got a lot more friends than Australia has on this issue, so again I cannot see how that argument stands up.

The claim that the Indonesians have done more structurally for East Timor is also very dubious. It does require a visit to East Timor to verify that, and I do not think there have been enough visits to East Timor to be able to verify it. Besides, any asphalt road may be of more benefit to transporting the military than the people; because East Timor still has a great number of people living at a subsistence level. An asphalt road does not repay the people for physical oppression and the oppression of their spirit of freedom.

Two matters have arisen from the Australian defence in the International Court of Justice. The fact that we ran our case and our arguments past the Indonesian government seems to have galled everyone in today's papers. By the way, I happen to support the Australian case in the International Court of Justice. That might surprise the likes of Senator Sherry, but I happen to think we have a right to explore the Timor Gap oil fields. We often go into joint explorations. We have done it with the Chinese and the Vietnamese. BHP is in Vietnam. It is our sovereign area, and there is no argument with that. I have no argument in taking up the cause of the East Timorese in our trade relations with the Indonesians. I hope that the judgment is favourable to Australia. But it seems that both sides, with all their bile, have taken it further than the commercial considerations.

The fact that before we even turned up to The Hague we ran our case past the Indonesians was colourfully described in the Herald-Sun today as `boot-licking'. Most Australians would know what that would mean. It seems to fit the pattern of the present Australian foreign policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are running the same case, you usually do consult with the other party.

—Indonesia is not the other party. Can we not stand alone? Can we not even go to an international court, put up our case and have pride in our case without first running it past the Indonesian government? The question has to be asked: were there any points that the Indonesians did not agree with in the case? If there were, did we change anything? What sovereign right do they have to review our case before the international court? It is boot-licking at its best. I will read this from the Herald-Sun's editorial:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans says that by providing Jakarta with our legal arguments "we wanted to be sure there was no misunderstanding by the Indonesians about the nature of our case and the way we were presenting it".
But given the Government's dismal track record in defence of East Timor's oppressed people, Jakarta should have no illusions about our true position.
I recommend that people buy the Herald-Sun today and have a look at the cartoon on the editorial page. That really does sum up the situation.

PARA.TAB: Australians have not really got their minds focused on foreign policy; they have got other economic problems. But there is one thing Australians do not like, and that is boot-licking. If it looks like a duck and walks like a duck, it is a duck; and this is boot-licking. This is so typical of the perception of the Indonesian authority over Australia. It may just be a perception, but it is a very strong perception, and it is very embarrassing before the international community. It certainly shows weak character from the government that it would think that it had to do this, and is it infinitely unpopular with the Australian people.

In the short time I have left I would like quickly to mention the second notable point to come out of the case. That is: what is Australia's foreign policy? It seems to have been taken into a greater shade of grey and confused everyone, because in the Australian—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to highlight the importance of the momentous events that we saw last week in this parliament. Indeed, the entire parliament was under siege. It was momentous because angry voters proved to all of us that Australian democracy is alive and well, and effective. Timber workers and their families from rural and regional Australia came to Parliament House to express a variety of emotions to this government. We now have proof that we have a functioning and robust democracy.

PARA.TAB: Workers and families in the forest industry are hurting. Their industry has lost 25,000 jobs since 1980, and they came to say to the Labor government last week that enough is enough. They came to say that they were not going to stand for the loss of any more jobs. It was their democratic right to come to the doors of the parliament, and inside and outside they made their case in a very orderly manner. It is to the credit of the organisers and of the people involved that they behaved so impeccably.

I remember the President of the Senate last week, after a day of clapping in response to some of my colleagues' speeches, asking the gallery not to clap. Right through that whole Question Time there was no clapping at all from the gallery. It showed that in a democracy we can have a situation where people who have a real grievance can come and actually put their case in a very powerful way, without any threats of violence or action. Their very presence was powerful and actually started to turn this government around from some of the inappropriate decisions it was making on forest policy.

They were supported by industrial organisations like the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union, which formed with the forest workers a coalition for action—action to have the national forest policy, which the government signed in 1992, adhered to. In the galleries of the Senate and outside the parliament they exerted subtle pressure to have their grievances heard.

Let me outline the extent of this democracy in action. Four thousand protesters from south-east New South Wales, Gippsland, in Victoria, Tasmania, northern New South Wales and Queensland attended. Three hundred and fifty trucks and hundreds of cars, buses and mini-buses also came. The size of their number and their persistence with their pamphlets and conversations with members and senators was very effective. On a number of occasions I went out there and spoke to them. Because of a back problem I was in considerable pain. Honourable senators would recall that the protesters had two picket lines, about 300 yards apart. One of them brought up a Pajero and drove me between the two picket lines. The very nature of the way in which they acted and reacted to what was going on was a great credit to them and to democracy in this country.

They turned the lawns of the parliament into a real bush carnival, with country music, sausage sizzles, chainsaw competitions and kids swimming in the fountain outside the parliament. Whole towns, such as Bombala and Orbost, closed business and came to Canberra to take part in this exercise of participatory democracy. Democracy Australian style, therefore, has come out of the towns and has come out of the bush in big trucks and in blue singlets. One of my Senate colleagues said on one of the days, particularly the day that Orbost came up, that what he saw out there was very moving.

This blockade is not just a tactic. It is part of the democratic process, and it is part of a process which between elections is something we hope will make the Labor government stick to its election promises. The forest industry and the families that support it have a lot at stake—thousands of jobs and an industry worth $450 million. As the Labor government has reneged on the national forest policy statement signed only three years ago, they feel cheated by this government.

Many supporters of the ALP went on voting for the ALP in the last election thinking that this forest policy not only protected the old-growth forest areas but also provided them with resource security and therefore with jobs. We are dealing with a government that does not even know the definition of `old-growth forest'. I have heard that the department of the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) has one definition and the department of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mr Faulkner) has another definition. I believe that both of these definitions are completely different from what was agreed in the forest policy statement of 1992.

How can people trust a government that, internally, is disagreeing with itself, running two or maybe three totally separate agendas as it tries to appease different interest groups which support it? Compared with what the government promised at the election, it has done nothing short of electorate fraud. When we get to the ballot box next time I am sure the workers will not overlook it. The government even got support for their cause from the trade union movement. The President of the ACTU, Martin Ferguson, called on the Labor government to develop a decent industry policy covering Australian forest products. This is not an issue that came up on the lawns last week. I can remember it being an issue as far back as 1968. The government has been here 12 years, yet it is still muddling around, fighting internally and trying to come up with a policy that works.

The coalition has called for assurances from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that the jobs of these timber workers will be safe. This Labor cabinet is on notice to keep faith with the voters on fundamental promises like forest policy and resource security. Any government needs to make policy changes at the margins as changes occur, but outright electoral fraud and deception will bring back the people who encircled this parliament last week if the government does not get its act together and get this policy straight. The arrogance of this Labor government has been dramatically challenged, not only within this parliament but outside the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. We have read in the newspapers that the initial cabinet submission on the so-called carbon taxes contained a range of proposals. I think they were your submissions, Senator McMullan. One was a tax of $1.25 a tonne on carbon dioxide emission to raise $960 million over three years. Another was to raise $1.3 billion over three years. Since neither option will significantly reduce emission rates, doesn't this demonstrate that the motive for additional fuel taxes is simply revenue raising, not protection of the environment at all? Or is it the intention of the government to substantially increase the tax take after introduction as it has done with both the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax?

—It would not be surprising to anyone—even someone from Mars, which is the way the opposition sometimes behaves—who was been following the debate that the government is considering a range of options to address the greenhouse emissions target. Australia was one of the first countries to sign and ratify the framework convention on climate change. A major element of that ratification was the national greenhouse response strategy which did contain an interim planning target to stabilise greenhouse gas emissions at 1988 levels by the year 2000 and to reduce those emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005. That interim planning target was endorsed by the states and by the Commonwealth within a no regrets framework.

PARA.TAB: Against that background, of course it is the case that the government is considering a range of greenhouse measures. Those measures have been thought about and further developed over the course of the last eight months. It is the case that a small environment levy—and I emphasise the word small—not designed in any way to be a revenue measure is one of the many options that are on the table. Those options will be considered in the lead-up to the conference of the parties to the framework convention on climate change in Berlin in March.

No decision has yet been made to introduce an environment levy of any kind. A judgment will be made by the government as to an appropriate mix of policy instruments, including the possibility of a levy, after full consideration of the views of all those interested. There is, of course, an enormous interest in this matter from Australian industry which does stand to suffer some disbenefits as a result of any swingeing imposition of a tax or a levy in this particular area. We will certainly be considering those arguments and we will certainly be considering the costs and benefits of other alternative strategies for greenhouse gas emissions for Australia as a whole.

There are a number of different models that have been employed by researchers to assess the impact of a carbon tax of any kind or any level on emissions as well as on revenue. The estimated impact of any such tax would obviously depend on the design of the tax and the assumptions about behavioural responses that are employed. That is the background; that is the foreground; that is the beginning and the end of it. The government has made no decision. We are very conscious that you cannot go down the track of revenue raising in this particular area, as distinct from other policy objectives, without having adverse policy consequences for an industry whose recovery we do want to sustain. The government will, as always, behave with complete responsibility in its approach to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. It relates to the issue of United States export subsidies, and specifically those on dairy products. This is a matter that has attracted considerable media interest and industry concern in this country. It is apparent that these subsidies cost Australian farmers millions of dollars in lost export revenue, but, as you have already mentioned in the parliament, the subsidies also represent a major cost to taxpayers in the United States. That view was repeated only this morning on radio. Minister, in this regard can you explain further to the Senate what the effects of these export subsidies will be on United States taxpayers?

—I thank Senator McKiernan. What happened this morning was very important. For a long time Australian government and industry and parliamentary representatives of all parties have been telling the United States administration that their export subsidy programs on dairy and grains are very opposed to our interests and articulating that, but also saying that it is not even in their intelligent self-interest—not their taxpayers, not their consumers and not even the efficient sectors of their agriculture industry. But we have always known that such an argument would have much more impact inside the United States when effective United States advocacy of those issues emerged.

PARA.TAB: For what, I think, is about the first time today we heard a representative of United States consumers through the Nader organisation speaking out on the need to drastically cut back on the money poured into these programs. They said on ABC radio this morning, quite correctly, that these programs represented a major diversion of US taxpayers' money away from the pressing social problems to the coffers of large international corporations both American and foreign. They claimed that the United States administration is throwing money at these international corporations, and they are fundamentally right.

The recent case of the subsidised US sales of skim milk powder to Australia's key markets in Asia provides a graphic example. The subsidy was 8,000 metric tonnes of skim milk powder. Firstly, they subsidised $100 a tonne more than was necessary to make the sales. They forced the price down. The dairy industry's advice to us and to the US government was that they could have made the sale with a subsidy of $100 less. That is a waste of about $800,000 of US taxpayers' money—that is US dollars, about $1 million Australian. But it gets worse. Consistent with the Nader organisation's story, trade sources tell us that it was not even United States trading companies that picked up this windfall gain—it was a European company, what was explained to me as a `large Swiss dairy company'—

TALK.START.PARA: —Nestles.

—I would not say who it was. It traded the subsidised US products and made a profit, the United States taxpayers' money going straight into that company. It is not that company's fault. They would be silly not to do it. You cannot blame them. Somebody came along with a cheque and they took it. You would be a mug not to take it. But you would be a mug to offer it. There is yet another downside for the United States. By artificially depressing the price in the Asian dairy market they are damaging the longer term prospects for their efficient dairy farmers such as those in California. It is not even in their own agriculture industry's long-term interest.

PARA.TAB: The point about all this is that we have a big message to sell in the United States but it will be much more effectively done now that the voice of the United States consumer is starting to be heard. We will be reinforcing the argument that no government can rein in its budget deficit while it is wasting money in ways such as this. They cannot address their social equity issues while they are spending their money on priorities like this. They undermine their efficient industries while they do it. It is a classic vicious cycle because, as they undermine their efficient industries they have to subsidise more, the equity problem gets worse, the efficient industries suffer more and they have to subsidise even more. This is the message we will be trying to put through directly and with the other countries of the Cairns Group. It is a very good year to do it because it is a year when there is a lot of deficit pressure in the United States and it is the Farm Bill year. We will be putting a lot of pressure, with the Australian industry, on the Farm Bill right throughout this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me wish Senator McMullan luck in his venture. My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the environmental tax presently under discussion by the government and ask: since an environmental tax will impose extra costs on industry, including primary industry, putting them at a disadvantage in international markets, will the assessment of the tax also take into account the efficient absorption of carbon dioxide by plants and crops, for example, in the forestry industry and the sugar crop, which absorbs more carbon dioxide than it produces? Considering that the tax has always been directed at the greenhouse gas emission levies and that your colleague Senator McMullan believes it should only be raised based on greenhouse merits, and if this were a genuine environmental measure, not simply another revenue raiser, would this not mean there should also be a system of greenhouse credits—and then some Australian farmers could expect to receive a cheque rather than a tax bill?

—On a number of occasions I have provided the Senate with details of the process that the government is engaged in to develop its next phase of response on the greenhouse gas emission issue. Let us be clear about this once and for all: the government is still in the process of developing its position. I outlined this in an answer earlier in the week when Senator Margetts asked me what the government's position was.

PARA.TAB: At this stage, options are on the table. I think that is very appropriate. I also believe it is appropriate that the government discuss these options with interested stakeholders. To that end, I, Senator Cook, Senator McMullan, Senator Collins and Mr Beddall held discussions yesterday with environment and other community groups and today with industry and trade union groups about their views on what would be an appropriate response for the government to the very important issue of reducing the level of greenhouse gas emissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. The minister would be aware of my interest in the welfare of Australians who are held in foreign prisons. In this regard, I have become aware of schemes which many countries have in place to allow international prisoners to be transferred to their home countries and serve their sentences there. Against this background, is the minister able to inform the Senate of the current status of negotiations being undertaken with the states and territories to institute an Australian system of transfer for international prisoners, including both Australians held in foreign prisons and foreign nationals who are imprisoned in Australia? In particular, can the minister advise whether the necessary federal legislation to effect a transfer system is likely to be introduced this year and whether there is any expectation of how soon such a system could be operating in this country?

—Senator Colston is quite right: I am well aware of his interest in this area. I think this is about the fourth or fifth question that he has asked me over the last two or so years and I can say to him that his interest in and support for an initiative in this area is starting to pay dividends.

PARA.TAB: I am advised by the Attorney-General that significant progress is being made in this area. There is now strong state government support for the federal government initiative for Australian participation in the international transfer of prisoners. The Commonwealth and all the state and territory governments, with the exception of the Northern Territory, have made a firm commitment to proceed with the scheme.

The government is well aware of the strong humanitarian and rehabilitative advantages and possible financial benefits of participating in international prisoner transfers. Such schemes have been operating quite well in other countries for some time and the matter is therefore being expedited as quickly as possible.

We have had extensive consultations with the states and territories, and it should be recognised in this context that it is particularly important that states and territories are involved here since the services in question are those provided by state and territory governments and not by the Commonwealth government. As a result of these consultations there has been substantial and very pleasing progress. Agreement has now been reached on the scheme's core legislative and administrative details and Commonwealth and state and territory legislation is in the process of being developed. We anticipate that the Commonwealth legislation will be introduced in mid-1995, and present indications are that the states and territories will be able to progress their legislation at approximately the same time.

The Attorney-General also notes that he is pleased with the cooperation and commitment of the states and territories in assisting the Commonwealth to progress the matter. He looks forward to further cooperation and the finalisation and implementation of an international prisoner transfer scheme and, with such cooperation, a prisoner transfer scheme may in fact be operating as early as 1996.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans in his capacity as both Minister representing the Prime Minister and Minister for Foreign Affairs. Given the admission of the minister for the environment that it is now impossible to meet the greenhouse targets of stabilisation at the 1990 levels by the year 2000 and a 20 per cent reduction below those levels by 2005, and given also the report of the Auditor-General that one year into the greenhouse gas reduction program the government's program was already one year behind, will the minister confirm that these, nonetheless, remain Australia's targets? Is the government attempting in any way whatsoever—here I use the same legalistic circumlocution which the minister loves—to influence other countries to water down greenhouse targets and/or is Australia seeking the international acceptance of a lesser target for Australia on the grounds that we are a fossil fuel producing and exporting country or on any other grounds?

—I think that was a very unkind cut from Senator Coulter about circumlocution. I am always very precise and direct on these occasions. In fact, I will be impolitely precise and direct at the outset and say that Senator Coulter unfortunately seems to have muddled his statement of the targets. The domestic interim planning target is a reduction to not 1990 but 1988 levels by the year 2000 and with a 20 per cent reduction by 2005. The target implied in the convention is stabilisation at 1990 levels by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: As to the substance of his question, the government has acknowledged, and continues to acknowledge, that on the basis of current programs and projections Australia will not be able to fully meet the stabilisation targets set out in either the convention on climate change or the domestic interim planning target. For that reason, as I have already indicated in answer to an earlier question, the government proposes to consider soon a package of further measures that will improve the level of Australia's performance and carry us closer to our objectives.

I should add that Australia is by no means the only country in this situation. Quite a number of others in the OECD, for a start, are unlikely to meet the targets and will need to consider further steps. Countries in this category include the United States, Canada, Japan and a number of member states of the European Union.

I assure the Senate, however, that the targets remain operative for us, as indeed do all relevant provisions of the convention on climate change. Australia is certainly not trying to influence other countries to reduce the targets contained in the convention. Likewise, we are not seeking a lesser target for Australia on the grounds that Australia is a fossil fuel producing and exporting country. In this regard, however, I should point out that the convention provides, quite correctly in our view, that parties shall take into consideration the situation of parties with economies that are highly dependent on fossil fuels.

Although we are not seeking to water down existing targets, we are adopting a considered approach to the question of new commitments which takes into account the range and diversity of Australia's interests. As we approach the conference of the parties on the convention, which is to take place in Berlin at the end of March/early April, our approach to proposals for strengthening commitments is this: in the first place, it would be premature to consider further proposals until parties have agreed on the principles on which further negotiation should be based and the procedures for conducting such negotiations—that is a necessary basis for acceptable and effective outcomes; secondly, negotiations by the parties on a protocol should not begin until after this first conference of the parties; and, thirdly, further international action should be based on equitable burden sharing arrangements and on greater involvement over time of developing countries. Australia's aim continues to be the achievement of an effective and equitable convention which will deal with global environmental problems of climate change while, at the same time, protecting our economic, trade and foreign policy interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction and relates to the national space program. I refer to reports of plans to launch Russian ex-military rockets from Australia. I understand that there have been claims that there will be no direct Australian involvement in such activities due to military secrecy provisions. Can the minister inform the Senate about the status of this launch option and of progress more generally with the national space program?

—At the outset I can say that the story that appeared in the press as a result of a press statement by Senator Chapman is without foundation. There has never been any proposal to have secret Russian rocket launches from Australia. I suspect Senator Chapman went back to the 1950s and sought a reds under the bed style of statement.

PARA.TAB: What is happening is that the Australian Space Office and the Australian Space Council have presented a report to the government outlining the possibility of launching from Australia certain types of rockets on a commercial basis and involving Australian industry. This was part of their five-year program which they presented to the government in accordance with legislation carried by this parliament with support from both sides.

As part of those discussions by the Australian Space Office, Russian interests—in particular, two Russian companies: STC Complex and Energomash, a Russian rocket producer and a Russian rocket engineer manufacturer respectively—have indicated strong interest in looking at Australia's capability to launch rockets, particularly in view of the open space we have and our geographical position in the world, to see whether there would be suitable opportunities with which they would like to be involved. They have indicated that they have access to many rockets that have been now made available because of the nuclear disarmament treaties that Russia has signed with the United States and that some of those rockets can now be used for peaceful purposes.

As a result of that indication, the Australian Space Office and Space Council will be conducting a study with the Russians about the possibility of having these rockets launched from Australia. That study will be done in conjunction with an industry reference group from Australia so that Australian industry is fully able to participate in any such program that may eventuate. I emphasise that this whole process will be led and controlled by the Australian Space Office and nothing will be entered into unless Australia's sovereignty and Australia's international obligations are fully met and there is no compromise to them. I believe these studies will take up to the middle of this year to complete. I hope by the middle or latter part of this year to be able to report to parliament that those studies have been successful, but we will have to await their outcome.

So far there has generally been bipartisan support for the development of Australian space activity going back to the Senate transport committee report of some years ago. It was very unfortunate that Senator Chapman—for purposes I suspect more related to his preselection opportunities or chances in South Australia a week ago—put out a bizarre statement saying that we would be involved in allowing any country, let alone Russia, to carry out secret launches from Australia. I want to put on the record that that is a bizarre suggestion with no foundation. We will continue to work with the Russians and with the American interest and any other country that wants to have an open and transparent discussion with Australia about developing rocket launching facilities within Australia.

If we add to outlays in any area, you will have to say whether you are going to reduce them, and you will have to say how you are going to meet other outlay reduction targets. If you want to get any credibility at all, you will have to be specific. Get that message loud and clear because you are not going to be allowed off that hook at any stage during the course of this debate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: what powers does the Commonwealth intend to use to ensure the protection of forest areas which are identified as being worthy of protection in accordance with the Prime Minister's recent statements? Specifically, how will the government make sure that identified forest areas are not logged or roaded by or with the permission of state governments?

—The Commonwealth's constitutional capacity to actually control timber policy or forest policy in this area is obviously limited. The export control power, regulations under the trade and commerce power, are obviously important but that power cannot be decisive given the fact that most of the value extracted from forests is not in the form of exported woodchips but rather non-exported logs and other timber products.

PARA.TAB: Against that background, the truth of the matter is that the government has to rely upon a cooperative strategy with the states if sensible policy results are to be achieved. It is that cooperative approach with the states that the Commonwealth is committed to rather than trying to use Commonwealth powers to manage what is quintessentially a state responsibility.

The main aim of the Prime Minister's statements has been to exclude, as you know, future logging from high conservation value native forests and, at the same time, encourage the development of a truly sustainable and value added wood products industry. As the Prime Minister has pointed out, it is state governments who have primary responsibility for forest management with the Commonwealth's powers in this area being limited to very indirect control mechanisms such as approval for export licences for that proportion of the forest product which is in fact exported, which is the minority of it.

Mr Beddall has written to the states to request the withdrawal of logging operations for woodchip exports from the 509 areas, as you know, identified by the government on the interim list for protection. I am aware that some states have said that they are going to continue to log those areas, but people should realise that all mainland governments have signed up to the national forest policy statement, which clearly states that all activities that may significantly affect areas of old-growth and wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value should be avoided. The responsibility is upon those state governments that have so committed themselves to honour that particular obligation. It is not one that we can force down their throats.

Under the NFPS, we are seeking to move to regional forest agreements to enable the government to move away from this annual coupe by coupe analysis that we are currently involved in. That again will involve necessarily a cooperative strategy rather than a compulsive one. That is the way the Commonwealth wants to go. I wish to goodness the states would actively participate in that particular process and enable all of us, on the basis of full and accurate information, to produce the policy results that are so obviously necessary to balance out the competing claims in this very sensitive area.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services. Can the minister inform the Senate of progress that is being made in implementing appropriate income support for Australian families?

—I am very pleased to put this on record again in this place because this government's record on families is unmatched but it often goes unknown and overlooked. The other thing we have done during our time in office is make sure those payments are regularly reviewed so we can make sure that they are most appropriately targeted and most appropriate and efficient.

PARA.TAB: The other thing to recognise is that the income support we provide for families is provided within both the social welfare and the social justice frameworks—our policies in Medicare, in education, in housing including the introduction of rent assistance, and in expanded superannuation coverage.

Probably the most important thing to have assisted families with income support is the creation of over 1.8 million jobs since we came into office. In particular, looking at payments for families, I mention the very significant stages of, firstly, benchmarking payments to families on behalf of children and, secondly, indexing them. All family payments by this government are indexed. Particularly the additional family payment, as it is now called, has been of huge benefit to families of Australia. Those payments have increased since we came into office by 83 per cent and 157 per cent, depending on whether that family payment is to children between 0 and 13 years or 13 and 16 years.

As I said, for the first time ever we have actually indexed all those family payments and in 1987 we introduced rent assistance to low income families. By way of flexibility of payments, too, in 1993 we allowed the basic family payment to be taken as a lump sum for the projected six months. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. I refer the minister to his department's own paper on the tariff concession system. I ask the minister: when is he going to take action to stop importers getting duty concessions through the back door on goods which compete with products made here in Australia that are entitled to the benefit of existing tariffs? Secondly, is the minister aware of claims that import agents are actively touting their ability to obtain tariff concession orders on a fee for success basis, so sure are they of getting approvals? Thirdly, how much did tariff concession orders cost the Commonwealth government in lost tariff revenue last year. Finally, how much did they add to the current account deficit by allowing imports of goods that could have been supplied by Australian firms?

—First of all, Senator Spindler, you would be aware that the government announced in the Working Nation statement that there would be a review of the tariff concession system. That review is now taking place. It will be completed and a report made to me by the middle of this year. You and anybody else who wants to make a comment about the operation of the tariff concession system are quite able to make such a submission. If you want to make one, you will make one, and so be it.

PARA.TAB: However, I do not agree with your premise that the tariff concession order automatically is costing Australian industry opportunities. The tariff concession order operates to provide Australian industry with the opportunity to import goods, particularly capital goods that are not already made in Australia or, where they are able to be imported, to provide an opportunity to develop an Australian industry. There is a proper and detailed process laid down in legislation by this parliament as to how those concession orders are applied and how they are investigated. The argument is open and transparent. Anybody who feels that they have not been successful in their particular case can appeal to the Federal Court—and many do—and the court will, in the end, decide whether they have a case or not. So I think that the premise you raise, that there is something untoward about the system, is just not correct.

I would also point out that many of the items that are imported under the tariff concession orders go into capital investment for Australian manufacturing in particular, and become part of value added export industries. So, in effect, in the long run they improve the current account deficit rather than being a detriment to it.

I know that this does not accord with your view generally about what we should be doing with tariffs, but that is the case. Many of the applications for tariff concession orders are for capital goods that add to the productivity of Australian industries and make them internationally competitive when they become exporters. You asked about the duty forgone; I am advised by Customs that in 1994 it was approximately $630 million on the tariff concession order—

TALK.START.PARA: —A fair amount.

—Which is a fair amount of money, I certainly agree. However, we do not see that as a loss of straight-out revenue. We see that, in terms of the tariff concession order and in policy terms, as enabling Australian industries to get capital goods, in particular, at the cheapest possible rate so that they can become internationally competitive. Though it may be a loss of $630 million in terms of revenue, there are many benefits in accordance with government policy.

PARA.TAB: I conclude on one point: in my many visits to small and medium size enterprises over the last couple of years—particularly in the manufacturing sector—I have come across many small businesses who are in favour of no tariffs. They want to be able to import some of their semi-processed raw inputs. They want to be able to import their capital equipment at the cheapest possible price, which makes them internationally competitive.

So there is now a growing culture in Australia to be world best, internationally competitive and not rely on high tariffs or quotas as we have in the past. I think that culture change in Australian industry is one of the unsung changes that this government's policy has led to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer and the expounding of the general principle, and there is no real disagreement with that. What we are attacking is the application and the process, mainly by bureaucrats. There is not even a charge that there is political interference. The way that the process is being administered clearly shows that it is awry, because there is a 70 per cent increase and the total amount of imports under concessional orders is $10 billion. Minister, the question really is: are you prepared to look at that before you get the long awaited report of the inquiry?

—I will certainly wait for the review. That is the appropriate process announced last year, and I think I would be criticised if I did not wait for the review so that all interested parties who want to make a submission have that opportunity.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler, in relation to the other aspect in your supplementary question and also in your question about agents putting out advertisements, it is certainly true that there are always elements in the community—agents and consultants—trying to drum up business for themselves by saying, `If you employ me or my firm, I can find a way of getting you a tariff concession order. And if I get it, I get a percentage of the saving.' That in no way implies changes in any way to the strict procedures which are laid down by law of how the tariff concession order system is to apply and be administered. We cannot stop people putting out those advertisements; if they choose to do so, that is their business.

I would also tell Australian business and Australian industry to be very careful about consultants telling you one thing and promising the world, when in fact there is a proper process to go through which the consultants are just trying, in some cases, to drum up. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

QUESTION.PARA: Australia will continue to use old-growth timber for many years. It will come from disturbed forests containing some old-growth trees and from old-growth forests that are not required for the nature conservation system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do support the national forest policy statement, as does the government. I also might say that, if we are going to talk about the issue of old-growth forests and how we preserve and ensure that we are able to establish a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system, we have to take into account the fact that degraded forest also is needed to ensure that we have a genuinely comprehensive, a genuinely adequate and a genuinely representative reserve system.

PARA.TAB: That is recognised, for example, by the Resources Assessment Commission. It acknowledges that some 36 per cent of those areas currently contained in reserve systems has been previously logged. That has been recognised by RAC. The biodiversity values and the endangered species values, which are so important, can be well represented in forests that have been disturbed.

You have to remember that once you have destroyed a forest, you have destroyed a whole ecosystem—that is the reality—and you cannot magically replenish an ecosystem like that overnight. You just cannot do it and you have to recognise that. Your attitude on this particular issue will not be forgotten. Your position on the protection of these very important remnant forests in Australia will not be forgotten. Your response on the issue of protecting these areas of wilderness will not be forgotten. Your response to these areas which are important to the conservation of our endangered species—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, what the minister is saying cannot possibly, under any criteria, be said to be answering Senator Crane's question, which was quite simple. —As I was saying, your position in relation to the very important issue of our endangered and threatened flora and fauna will not be forgotten. Do not forget that Australia is the only megadiverse developed country in the world. Your position will not be forgotten.

PARA.TAB: It is worth remembering that throughout Australia 79 species of plants, 20 mammal species and nine species of birds are already extinct. We do have a responsibility to future generations in relation to the protection of our forests. This government is committed to ensuring, as we move to protect these high conservation value forests, that we do it in a way that ensures we have a balanced approach, that we take into account the needs of local communities who are dependent on the forest industries and that we look genuinely for a balance between jobs and conservation. That is what this government is doing. But what you are doing is ripping down the forests and supporting the logging and destruction of these areas and you will stand condemned by ordinary Australians for doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I take note of your comment that the government supports the national forest policy statement. I presume you are familiar with the consultancy brief prepared by your department which gives you advice on a strategy and plan of action to phase out the harvesting of old-growth forests by the year 2000. —Mr President, I take a point of order. We have been trying not to take points of order today. My point of order is on relevance. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Today we have seen the sad spectacle of an incompetent minister trying to defend the indefensible. If you needed any evidence at all of why this censure motion must be moved and must be carried, it is the way Senator Faulkner has attempted to answer the three questions that were asked of him today about these issues. To see Senator Faulkner so incompetent that he could not even answer after 24 hours notice just which coupes had been looked at by his highly paid consultants shows what an incompetent minister this is and what an incompetent government he is part of—a government that should be, and a minister that must be, censured for this fiasco.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pretty lacklustre start; lift your game.

—You might think it is lacklustre, Senator Evans, but you understand. We can see from looking from this side—Senator Faulkner cannot—the way you cringe every time Senator Faulkner attempts to answer those questions because we know that you side with Senator Collins. We know that you have no confidence in Senator Faulkner or his department.

PARA.TAB: We know that in cabinet Senator Gareth Evans sides with Senator Collins, Senator Ray and Mr Beddall to try to get some rationality into the forest industry debate. We can see from this side just how embarrassed he is by this minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The only thing I have ever cringed about is the prospect of this Neanderthal mangling the English language in front of me. That is what I react to. I do not in any way lack confidence in my minister, who is doing a fine and responsible job.
—There is no point of order.

—Mr President, you must understand that you are going to get a lot of these spurious points of order, because, as my leader says, those opposite are highly embarrassed. The last thing they want to have to do is to get into this debate, because none of them want to defend Senator Faulkner either. We know what they have said in cabinet. We know that anything they say now for the public record will hurt them very dearly.

PARA.TAB: We move this censure motion very seriously and with a touch of sadness, because the minister has shown that he is completely incapable of retaining his place in a government that is supposed to be governing for the whole of Australia. If the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had any guts, he would stand up to the Left of his party and would have sacked Senator Faulkner long ago for the complete farce and debacle that this whole process is. Mr President, they are not my words; they are the words of your colleague from Western Australia, former Senator Walsh, who calls this matter and Senator Faulkner's handling of it a complete debacle.

Not only the coalition is saying this. The Greens, for different reasons, agree that Senator Faulkner has been completely incompetent in this matter. The unionists, who the Labor Party are supposed to support and who want jobs, and the forest workers are not the only ones saying this. Senator Faulkner's caucus colleagues are also saying it. If Laurie Oakes and Glen Milne are to be believed at all—there are plenty of leakers in the Labor caucus, including Senator Collins, who are only too keen to run to Glen Milne and Laurie Oakes—we will know that the majority of the Labor caucus also agrees with us in what we say about Senator Faulkner's administration.

Senator Faulkner has earned the contempt of his party, which knows that it will be struggling in the next election. As my colleague Senator Alston has said previously, Senator Faulkner set out to be Graham Richardson but has ended up being Ros Kelly. Senator Faulkner is no Graham Richardson. The only similarity he shares with Richo is his view on the virtue of telling the truth.

I ask the Senate: for what purpose has this fiasco gone on? Senator Faulkner's department is running a particular agenda. I am pleased to see the support that he is getting from his colleagues. It lends truth to my point about their being embarrassed. We can see that.

Senator Faulkner's department is not working on a whole of government policy. It is not working in the best interests of the whole of Australia but for what suits its jaundiced view of the world and the jaundiced view of certain officers in it. How could this minister appoint Mr Toyne to give an objective view of government processes? The processes are all wrong. We understand this when we hear Mr Keating calling the Wilderness Society a Nazi front or a Goebbels organisation. Mr Toyne is very close to the Wilderness Society, yet Senator Faulkner has engaged him as the deputy secretary of the department.

Senator Faulkner has so demeaned the process that the whole conservation movement is suffering. The whole environmental situation in our country has suffered because of the incompetence of this minister trying to be too smart by half. Any action now taken by the minister or the department will be viewed with suspicion because this whole process has been so absolutely stupid that no-one will ever again trust anything this minister or the department do.

I ask the Senate to contemplate what would have happened if Mr Beddall had asked NAFI or the sawmillers to assess the coupes and had paid them $120,000 of taxpayers' money to do that. What would Australians have said, what would Senator Faulkner have said, what would the environment movement have said if the government had paid $120,000 in taxpayers' money to get the sawmillers, the unionists and the NAFI people to assess the coupes? There would have been complete outrage.

Somehow this minister snuck the money out of his own budget so that he did not have to go to cabinet, so that Senator Collins and Mr Beddall would not have a chance to stop it. Senator Faulkner paid out of his own department's budget $120,000 plus of taxpayers' money for four conservation groups to tell us what is in these coupes, things that Senator Faulkner's own department could have got out of the state department.

For the $120,000 that they got, these conservation groups have not even walked over the coupes that they have given an assessment on. They have not ground truthed them, whatever that might mean. Even though we gave Senator Faulkner 24 hours notice to tell us which of those coupes had been walked over, had been physically looked at, today Senator Faulkner simply could not tell us. I suspect the answer is that very few of them, if any at all, were walked over.

Yet this is the process that Senator Faulkner has described as rigorous. He said that it is a marvellous process—that it is rigorous, consultative, open, transparent, and, I believe, that it withstands scrutiny. It withstands scrutiny and he cannot even tell us whether the coupes were looked at. Senator Faulkner also said those areas have outstanding conservation attributes such as old growth values and wilderness values, yet his highly paid consultants did not even bother, in most instances, to have a look at them. That is the process that Senator Faulkner is trying to tell us is rigorous.

As Laurie Oakes has pointed out, because of what Senator Faulkner has done he has given Justice Sackville and the courts the opportunity to not only throw out woodchip exports but also put into jeopardy exports of coal, aluminium, uranium and mineral sands. That is, of course, why the Labor caucus is so furious with Senator Faulkner—he has brought into jeopardy not only woodchip exports but also exports of many other things which Australia requires to try to balance the foreign debt.

While Australia suffers the Labor Party plays its vicious little political game. We all know, because Senator Richardson told us on his last day, that he did not speak to Senator Faulkner for all of the time that they were in the parliament together until the last day. Why was that? It is because Senator Faulkner comes from the Left and Senator Richardson came from the Right. They would not even speak to each other for four years in this parliament. That is what this is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Senator Richardson said that in his farewell speech, Senator Collins. Senator Richardson would not even talk to him. Senator Ray sits next to Senator Faulkner, and we can see from this side that, when Senator Faulkner is answering these questions, Senator Ray looks as though he wishes he were up in one of his Blackhawk helicopters. Even though they are about to crash, he would still rather be there than sitting next to Senator Faulkner when Senator Faulkner tries to justify this. We can see from here, Senator Collins, that every time Senator Faulkner is asked a question you always find something very important to talk about to Senator McMullan. Every single time we have asked Senator Faulkner a question, you have looked the other way.

PARA.TAB: If you have a look at the lefties on the other side, you can see that they are genuinely very sorry for the way that their man has mishandled this. Senator Devereux is in fact so sorry that he even resigned from the Labor Party. We all know, because we saw it on television, that Mr Beddall and Senator Faulkner had a stand-up fight in Hobart. Everybody saw that. These are the two people who are supposed to be running the forest policy. They were almost at fisticuffs at Hobart before Simon Balderstone pulled them apart.

This is how the Labor Party runs its policy. It is all this Left-Right fighting—who is going to get ascendancy. We heard about it from Hobart. We only have to look at Port Hinchinbrook to see another instance of it. The Goss Labor government—part of Mr Beddall's faction, I might say—approved the development at Port Hinchinbrook. What did Senator Faulkner do? He came along and stopped it—not for any true conservation reason, because we know that there is an environmental disaster up there at the moment, but because Senator Faulkner wanted to pay back Mr Beddall and the Queensland right wing faction from knocking off the left wing President of the Labor Party in Queensland. That is what it is all about. Here we are, with these major issues before the Australian people, and the Labor Party, urged on or led by Senator Faulkner, is simply playing a stupid factional game.

For the way Senator Faulkner could not administer his contracts and for the way he misled the Senate yesterday, he should be sacked. For that reason alone, this censure motion deserves to be passed. A few days ago Senator Faulkner told us that `all of the acquittal processes have been dealt with'. He said, `I have them. They've all been properly acquitted.' Yet yesterday, when he was required by an order of the Senate to table not only certain information but those acquittals, he said, `I can't do it,' in spite of the fact that a couple of days before he said he had them.

There is a very important point to this: not only did Senator Faulkner mislead the Senate but he has failed to account to this Senate and to the people of Australia for the way that $120,000 was spent. It makes us wonder, senator, just what that money was spent on. We know that the dark green conservation movement has been propped up by the Labor Party with government grants for the last few years. You know that that is done for purely political reasons.

Minister, you are probably glad I am saying this because you probably think that this will put the green conservation movement on side this time when you are about to lose its support. I tell you this, senator: the people of Australia are getting a bit sick of you using taxpayers' money to prop up a political grouping in the dark green conservation movement to campaign for you people every election time. I can tell you that the people of Australia are getting very sick and tired of that. Again, this is simply what has happened with that $120,000.

I invited you, senator, to explain to us yesterday why the acquittals could not be put in, and you gave me some tripe about it not being the right time for the acquittals. Yet, the contracts clearly say that their completion date is 4 November and that the acquittals will be all audited by auditors within eight weeks of 4 November. That is somewhere around the beginning of January. But here we are, in the middle of February, and you do not have them.

Why haven't you got them? I don't know, but it makes the people of Australia very suspicious that perhaps there cannot be any proper acquittal for that $120,000. So for that alone you should be censured. You should be censured for the incompetent way you have handled this whole process and for the divisions you have brought in an industry that can be worth so much to Australia. You have completely demeaned the conservation process. You have demeaned the process for those of us who have a genuine interest and concern in conservation and in the environment.

You have cost the jobs of hundreds and hundreds of hard-working Australians who want to get work and to do it in an environmentally friendly way. For all of those things, we cannot forgive you; but, more importantly, neither can your own caucus members. They cannot forgive you either. It is for this reason that the Senate should pass the censure motion and make Senator Faulkner realise that we cannot simply tolerate this incompetence, this fiasco, this debate. Hopefully Mr Keating will then do the right thing and tell Senator Faulkner that he has to stand aside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —It probably should come as no shock to members of the opposition that I do not intend to be bullied by this barrage of misinformation from Senator Ian MacDonald and other members of the opposition in the way that I have handled my own ministerial responsibility. I have explained and answered every question asked of me in this Senate chamber. I have explained the basis of my actions. It was the 1993 decision of the cabinet that I should advise the Minister for Resources on the applicability of the national forest policy statement to the woodchip licence renewal process. That advice was prepared in a manner completely consistent with the national forest policy statement.

PARA.TAB: A key element of that policy is that old growth and wilderness areas of high conservation value should be protected until their values are assessed and until it is determined whether or not they are required for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. That is entirely consistent with the precautionary principle. But, of course, I do not think opposition senators would know a lot about the precautionary principle. Even if they did know about it I suspect they would never ascribe to it anyway.

Let me also say that the approach I have taken is very consistent with commonsense. It would make sense to very few people to continue to log areas you believed were of high conservation value while you discussed processes to assess those areas. Surely it would make more sense to protect them until their values could be thoroughly assessed.

I have made it clear that the assessment processes conducted by my portfolio were hampered by a lack of cooperation from state forestry agencies and a number of other relevant stakeholders. I must say that I did everything possible to achieve their cooperation. I informed all my relevant state counterparts of my initiative to assess areas likely to be of high conservation value and I invited their participation.

In early November I sent the reports that were prepared by the conservation organisations to the state governments, to NAFI, to the CFMEU and to the Forest Protection Society. Only Western Australia provided any analysis in relation to the merits of individual coupe assessments. I could not, and I did not, accept that this lack of cooperation should prevent my department and portfolio agencies preparing the best advice possible under those circumstances.

I will deal with the furphy that this was put forward on the back of an envelope by a few green radicals, which is the suggestion made by Senator Macdonald. The advice that I gave to Minister Beddall did not come from the conservation movement; it was not prepared by the conservation movement. The conservation councils, as required, provided an input—an important input—but only an input to the preparation of the department's advice. I believe there were 425 coupes and 11 forest blocks which the conservation groups included in their lists which were not supported by my department. The advice was prepared by the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the Australian Heritage Commission, the EPA and the forest branch of my department. It was prepared by people who I believe are competent, dedicated and professional public servants.

The portfolio undertook its assessment of the conservation significance of the areas planned to be logged in a variety of ways. Perhaps I am not able to go through all the steps involved in the time available, but there were certainly a number of very significant steps. As a first step, the geographic location of those coupes was checked. The Australian Heritage Commission checked coupes against information held on the Register of the National Estate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the Bass Strait ones.

—To take your interjection, Senator, we did find inaccuracies provided by the Tasmanian authorities. Coupes were in Bass Strait and the Southern Ocean. That was the sort of problem that we faced. The Heritage Commission checked coupes against information held on the Register of the National Estate. This information variously went to issues such as growth stage and disturbance history, presence of endangered species, and vegetation communities for the areas concerned.

PARA.TAB: The Environment Resources Information Unit—ERIN, as it is better known—used technology to map the location of coupes with information holdings on nationally threatened species, including rare species of plants obtained from the records of museums, herbaria and botanical gardens around Australia. The Australian Nature Conservation Agency plotted the location of coupes against information holdings on rare and threatened species, rare and threatened communities, wetlands of significance and migratory paths of birds. ANCA also undertook a detailed analysis of the significance of places for the conservation of biological diversity, including an analysis at a national level of the importance of regions or areas.

The conservation status of forest communities was checked by the portfolio against all available information. Where an area was considered to be poorly reserved, it was listed as likely to be of high conservation value. Analysis was also undertaken of the habitat requirements and strategies that needed to be put in place to protect species listed in the Endangered Species Protection Act. The Australian Heritage Commission also analysed the information against the national wilderness inventory. In places where the inventory is not complete, other assessments were used—notably, the New South Wales national parks and wildlife assessments of wilderness areas and the joint AHC-WA Department of Conservation and Land Management assessment in the southern forests of Western Australia.

The import of my advice was that the areas my portfolio had identified as likely to be of high conservation value should be protected until their values are assessed. A process is now in place which should allow an assessment to be completed in the course of the next two months. Those sitting on the opposition benches, forest experts to a man and woman—all of them absolute forest experts—do not need any help at all in assessing any advice on any of these issues. They are much more comfortable jumping to hasty, opportunistic, political judgments, totally politically motivated. They will be judged in the longer term by their response on these issues.

On the issue of the values that were used in the assessment—and it is an important issue—naturally enough my advice gave priority to old-growth and wilderness areas, given the NFPS requirement to protect areas of old-growth and wilderness that are likely to have high conservation values until those values are thoroughly assessed. Around 400 of the coupes on the list of 509 were assessed as having old-growth and wilderness values. But the NFPS also recognises that the Commonwealth has an obligation to protect other values as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like gravel pits!

—I know these are not important to the opposition, but Commonwealth obligations include the assessment of world heritage values, national estate values, environmental impacts and obligations relating to international conventions, including those for the protection of endangered species and biodiversity. The Commonwealth has a statutory responsibility for identifying national estate areas which, of course, involves conducting assessments for a very wide range of values.

PARA.TAB: The whole purpose of comprehensive regional assessments and the regional forest agreements proposed by the NFPS is to enable the parties to meet their obligations, that is, all their obligations, for forested areas. Therefore, in preparing my advice on the applicability of the national forest policy statement to the woodchip licence renewals process, I included an assessment of all the values relevant to the Commonwealth and its obligations set out in the NFPS.
Let me also draw attention to the slur and implication of the opposition that I should have blithely ignored assessing these really important environmental values for which—

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish!

—That was implicit in your question today, again, Senator Crane. It was implicit that I should have ignored assessing these really important environmental values for which the Commonwealth has statutory and other obligations and that I should not have had the temerity to recommend that coupes likely to have these values be set aside until their values could be more thoroughly assessed. It is a position that simply cannot be sustained by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the issue of the grants to voluntary conservation organisations, there is probably little I can add to this particular issue and what I have already put on the record about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand that.

—But I know how strongly Senator Alston and all his friends over there really object to any government grants being made to non-government organisations that have a sort of mild tinge of green. So it is probably appropriate—
—They are dark green.
—It is a very ideological response from you. There are all sorts of government grants that you approve all the time.
—Business.

—Business is okay. Business is fine. All sorts of government grants are fine but not these ones that you claim are going to organisations that you have some narrow minded, ideological objection to. That is the problem.

PARA.TAB: The four conservation councils were contracted to provide information: reports, assessments or whatever you want to call them—those opposite seem to change nomenclature about this all the time—on a range of values of forest areas proposed for export woodchip activities. That information, as it is described in the grant agreements that have been tabled, was to be in the form of substantiated evidence of the values claimed.

It was important to try to avoid the situation that was faced by my predecessor, Mrs Kelly, the year before when the conservation movement presented to her a list of coupes for protection for which very limited information was available. The justifications of those claims were limited also. I wanted to go through a more thorough and systematic approach to the identification of areas likely to be of high conservation value. I wanted to involve the states in the exercise but regrettably, for the most part, they chose not to be so involved.

This particular process, by which the portfolio ensured that the groups adhered to the terms of the grant agreement in putting together their reports, is a matter of public record. I have spoken about it before. It was an interactive process and my department and other relevant portfolio agencies were fully involved.

The actual reports that have been produced by the conservation councils were all released publicly last year, but they have now been tabled in the Senate. They were sent to the states and they were sent to the stakeholders for comment, as I have mentioned before. In fact, it is impossible in my view to have had a more transparent process than the one we have had.

I go to one particular issue that Senator Ian Macdonald has raised—that of grants to these conservation organisations. He raised this issue yesterday on the floor of the Senate and he has raised it again in this debate. I did, as Senator Macdonald would expect any responsible minister to do, take what he said very seriously. I went out of the Senate chamber following the debate and sent a minute to the secretary to my department asking him about advice of the administration of the four grants. I enclosed copies of the Hansard so that all the allegations were before the departmental secretary. I intend to table the minute I received from the secretary along with other information. The secretary's minute states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department provided grants to four conservation organisations to enable them to prepare a report justifying their views of High Conservation Values in forests in their respective States.
It outlines the moneys involved. The secretary has attached details of the time frame, as I indicated I would do, and the events surrounding these grants. I will table them soon. The minute states:
I have examined the four grants in question and measured them against:
