I table those documents and reject the opportunistic, despicable and contemptible slurs that the opposition has levelled on me and officers of my department in relation to this matter. PARA.TAB: Of course, what you are doing is just trying to scrape the bottom of the barrel in relation to this particular matter. There is no contribution to and no interest at all in the fundamental issue that we have been debating in this parliament for two weeks; that is, the future of Australia's native forests and the future of the forest industries in this country. This is a difficult issue. We on this side of the chamber know it is a difficult issue; we have been grappling with it for well over a decade. But what do you do? You just opportunistically jump on the cart and see what you can do to get short-term political benefit out of the situation. But it will backfire on you. I can assure you that this great strategic political decision that you have made will turn into a festering sore for your parties: a festering sore for the Liberal Party—a festering sore on the rotting carcass of the opposition and the others.

I promise you that what you have said will not be forgotten: the fact that you are happy to see all these old-growth forests—these important remnants of forests for future generations of Australians—logged; the fact that some of the last remaining areas of wilderness in this country have gone; and the fact that there are endangered species, important flora and fauna, which this government is committed to protecting. These are responsibilities that any fair-minded political party has to consider as it deals with these issues. You have to give consideration to these conservation issues if you are fair dinkum.

We have to take account of the fact that we are the only mega-diverse developed country in the world, and there is a commitment on the part of our community to protect and conserve the magnificent biodiversity in this country.

But, more importantly, the challenge in this debate is to find a balance—between jobs, the future of local communities which are dependent on the forest industries, and the protection of important and high conservation value native forests. You, the opposition, will stand condemned for the crass opportunism you have displayed, the disgustingly short-sighted position that you have taken in this country, as the government has looked to work through a difficult issue and find a balance.

I can tell you that, in finding our balance, we are not going to ignore the fact that, as a government, we have a fundamental responsibility to future generations of Australians to care about, protect and conserve our natural environment. You couldn't give a damn about the environment; you never have given a damn and, throughout this debate, you have proved it.

—The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has spent the best part of 29 minutes speaking and, for perhaps 20 minutes of that speech, he was telling us how wonderful the process was that delivered this result. PARA.TAB: The process we have here, which the minister has just described to us as being useful, was so useless that that specimen—the oldest living organism on this planet—still does not have the protection which it should have. I believe that that alone brings us to a position where the process should be much more closely examined.

The process really relies far too much on the input and cooperation of the states: states which can be—as in the case of Tasmania, in particular—intransigent, defiant and downright destructive. That is a process which is supported by the opposition and which the minister has spent some time telling us is a good thing.

That process then required Minister Beddall to consider that advice, and I stress the word `consider'. An extremely important part of that process was at this point—the point of Beddall's consideration.

It has already been demonstrated in the Federal Court that Minister Beddall has been incapable of following what he was legally required to do. In his consideration of the minister for the environment's advice, we can see the fault of the process. That is why the Democrats believe that it is absolutely essential that we inquire into the process.

The fault which is readily evident is that Minister Beddall has not given documentation of his justification for dismissing Minister Faulkner's advice that many, many hundreds of areas were recommended for protection. How was that advice dismissed? On what basis was that advice dismissed? It may well be that Minister Beddall found fault in some of the advice. It may well be that some of the advice was inadequate, poorly prepared or about the wrong things.

We have had these assertions in this chamber time and time again over the past few days. But to be able to determine whether that is the case or not, we really need to be presented with Minister Beddall's reasons for making those decisions. Do reasons exist? Are there documents to substantiate those decisions made by Minister Beddall? Are those documents in existence on paper? Are they tangible, or were the decisions made in a rush? Or did they, in fact, just ignore the advice from the minister for the environment?

We do not know and we cannot know unless we have a full inquiry into the process. We would then be able to determine whether Minister Beddall rejected the advice because he found fault with the areas described or any of the purported faults that have already been raised by the coalition ad nauseam in here. In fact, the Democrats, through our notices of motion, are seeking documentary evidence on the forests to be able to determine that for ourselves. We would prefer, of course, that we had the extensive powers of a Senate inquiry and we would prefer that we sought all documentation.

If there was anything wrong with the advice of the minister for the environment, and if there was anything wrong with what had been collected and collated on his behalf, then Minister Beddall should have been able to detect that when he was considering it. Did Minister Beddall carry out a proper consideration—and I stress the word `proper'—of that advice? Did he consider that advice? Did he find fault with it? If so, what were the faults? What documentation exists to demonstrate those faults? After all, that is what the coalition has been chasing for the past fortnight. What was wrong with the advice? It was Minister Beddall's job to look for that. He had to consider that. Did he consider it?

For him to stand here and ascribe the blame to the provider of the advice is, I think, sadly misdirected because the process itself was faulty. One of the players in that process is quite demonstrably incapable of following what he is legally required to do. He has been found guilty in a court of being incapable of following the legal advice. How on earth out of that shemozzle we can ascribe the responsibility to one minister, I do not know.

The Minister for Resources could at least respond to our request to document what it is that is wrong. All I am saying is that the environment minister's advice was part of the decision making process. When the Minister for Resources got it wrong, let us think about what happened then. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) entered the scene and threw in a hand grenade. He decided that a hand grenade was necessary and turned the circus that already existed into chaos. The trucks then entered the scene and another desperate solution was sought.

What the Democrats are anxious to do is inquire into the whole process so that we do not have a repetition of the circus, the hand grenade, the trucks and the decision which has left the industry unsure of where its future is, the conservation movement determined that the process should not be repeated, the coalition excited and the parliament disrupted. We do not want to see that happen again. It is not productive, it is a waste of time, it is a waste of effort and it certainly does not deliver us a nation which is honestly able to say that it has a process in place which guarantees the protection of those values which are worth protecting, a nation which guarantees the future of an industry which is valuable to the nation and which does not cause immense disruption to the law making and parliamentary scrutiny processes of the country.

Senator Ian Macdonald's motion seeks to describe and censure the actions of the minister for the environment as gross incompetence and, in relation to the nomination of forest coupes, to ascribe to him responsibility for undermining the protection of high conservation areas and putting in jeopardy the jobs of forest workers. It is our contention that it is a far wider responsibility that must be addressed. We believe that the Prime Minister's hand grenade was just as responsible for all those problems described there and that it was Minister Beddall who stuffed it up to start with. It would be most irresponsible for us as a chamber to ascribe that responsibility to one minister in particular and to censure him.

We will not support the motion. We believe, maintain and will insist that the proper way to address this is to have a full Senate inquiry and not seek half the documents or double the documents. After all, we have had some coalition members asking for half a set of documents, others asking for a full set of documents and others asking for documents which are not the ones that we really want. That is not the way to address the problem. The way to address the problem is to have a full inquiry into the whole process and, rather than seeking to blame somebody and take a scalp, to get about setting up a process which delivers proper outcomes.

I have mentioned what the environmentalists and people concerned with forests want. They want the certainty that these areas that deserve to be protected will be protected. The timber industry wants a policy position which will provide an underpinning for growth and certainty in that industry as well.

I will outline the federal coalition industry policy in respect of forests. I will read the last and most important paragraph. This policy, which was published in 1993, has not yet been changed. I have checked that it has not even been amended by any public statements that have been made in the last two weeks when endless opportunities have been available to make them. It says that the coalition will place no time limits on the export of woodchips from Australia.

Senator Abetz now has a classic opportunity to say that it has changed. I will be delighted to hear him clarify it. I will read it again. The coalition's policy, as printed and unamended, is that the coalition will place no time limits on the export of woodchips from Australia.

Senator Gibson is a thoughtful man. He may be able to contribute to this matter because of his interest in the law. The policy says, `Regional strategies which are drawn up and implemented according to Commonwealth approved procedures by providing legislative backing.' That is what should happen to forests. So the opposition says that the states should continue to run them under regional forest agreements according to Commonwealth approved procedures. But in this policy the opposition then takes away the one single lever the Commonwealth has, which is export controls over woodchips.

The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made a very significant contribution to this debate in announcing a percentage scale-down of these woodchips. Why is that important? I will tell the Senate why. Because for the first time in this debate it has focused the attention on every player in the debate to finally get these regional agreements developed.

Last year, a lot of time was wasted. As I have said, the Commonwealth has to take our share of the blame for that—it is on the public record—but it has been a joint problem. We have to deal with six state governments and a territory government plus, properly, a whole range of other affected agencies. In terms of developing these all-important guidelines, they go backwards and forwards at bureaucratic level for a year. Before we know it, a year has gone. The Prime Minister fixed that in his statement. He has announced—this is important—that there will be a scale-down of these woodchips, which the opposition's policy says there will be no time limit placed on.

You in the opposition should take the opportunity this afternoon—Senator Alston and Senator Ian Macdonald have not—to tell us whether you still have a policy that there will be no time limit placed on how long woodchips are exported from this country. I will tell you this as a matter of fact: if you place no time limit, you will never get these regional agreements signed. The only reason we now have, for the first time, state governments, the timber industry and a lot of environmentalists saying let us do it is because of that scale-down.

I will tell you why. The timber industry was dragging its heels on these regional agreements. Why? Because it feared that putting them into place would mean that trees would be protected. The environmentalists were dragging their heels on these agreements because, by finally signing off on them, it would be a concession that some trees would be cut down. The state governments were dragging their heels on it because they did not want to cede any degree of power to the Commonwealth for what is their constitutional responsibility, and that is to manage the forests.

What has changed all that? I will tell you. The Prime Minister has changed all that. It is a fact. Now they know that there will be a percentage scale-down, starting now, of chips. Everyone is now absolutely focused on the need to get these regional agreements signed.

As I said, Senator Alston said two things that made sense. He asked whose fault it was and said the process is at issue here. He is dead right on both counts. This is not a problem of the decision making of either the minister for the environment or the Minister for Resources. The problem here is the process. We all know it; we have known it for years. We initiate it, despite the fact that we have only export controls over woodchips. We are given the responsibility of controlling this particular dog, but we have it by only the tip of the tail. That is all we have.

To our credit, we took the initiative to construct a national forest policy agreement that will provide managed forests in Australia for all time, for everyone's sake. But we wanted to do it by agreement. In my view, that agreement is now going to be forthcoming for the first time. The reason is that the Prime Minister has now put a real deadline on the process. So now, in all of the discussions I have had with the state ministers, with the industry, with the environmental groups, everyone has agreed that this will become the major focus.

TALK.START.PARA: —And about time.

—I agree with you—about time. This is not a matter of condemning Senator Faulkner. I must say I give credit to Senator Bell. He raised the same issues. The process is flawed here. We are in this particular problem at the moment and it is attracting our attention, but have a look at the public record. Every year at this time this debacle comes around when this crazy coupe by coupe process gets under way. We have to get away from it. Now, thanks to the initiative of the Prime Minister, we will get away from it. That process has now started. Everyone knows that if they do not get down to this now those woodchip exporters will concentrate their minds on doing it.

PARA.TAB: Can the coalition force that result with its current policy? No, it cannot. Why not? Because it has a formal policy of placing no time limit whatsoever on the export of woodchips from this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table that?
—Table it? It is your policy document; I am happy to table it. It is tabled. It will be the first time you have read it, so I am happy to table it.

PARA.TAB: What I want from you this afternoon is what the timber industry and the environmentalists are waiting for—a real policy statement. Does this stand? Does this no time limit position on exports stand or will you impose a time limit and force these regional agreements? I say again that the fault is not with either minister; that is a fact. It is with the process which the Prime Minister has now corrected.

I have here the way of the future for this industry. These are the draft documents—thousands of hours of work have been put into them—for the south-west forest management for Western Australia, which Senator Macdonald would not have even opened the cover of. This is an agreed document, as Senator Macdonald would not know, between CALM, which runs the forests in Western Australia, and the Australian Heritage Commission, which is responsible for assessing those things that should become part of the national estate.

I will tell you how it is done. First of all, there is agreement reached between the Heritage Commission and the Forestry Commission as to what will be the criteria to determine the assessments. That is agreed. Secondly, the actual assessments are done, and here they are, area by area with conservation values assigned to them. That is done. Secondly, the Heritage Commission—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell Faulkner!

—Senator Faulkner supports this process, and he is on the public record as doing so. The Australian Heritage Commission then produces its document as to how these areas must be protected. The Forestry Commission then produces this document. Read this stuff. I know none of you have read it. If you read this you will see that there is a detailed response from the managers of the forests as to how they will do this, going into the detail of how many fringe areas they will leave on each side of streams, and so on. These two documents are put together and a management plan for those forests is then produced, and here it is in draft form.

PARA.TAB: I am not suggesting that you cannot make changes to the criteria that we use. This was done in 1992. But this is the process that must be adopted. What you then have at the end of it is a forest which has a management plan for all time, that will preserve forever those areas of conservation value that should be preserved. People concerned with the environment know it and will preserve forever a sustainable base for a logging industry to continue without affecting those environmental values. That has to be done now across the rest of Australia, thanks to the intervention in this debate by the Prime Minister.

I have to say the one positive thing that has come out of this has been that intervention and the Prime Minister's announcement that there will be a real scale-down of woodchip exports from this country. I now know from personal conversations that we will achieve this across Australia for the first time. The sooner we do it, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to follow my colleague Senator Alston in supporting Senator Ian Macdonald's motion, which reads:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate censures the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories for gross incompetence in the exercise of his ministerial responsibilities in relation to the nomination of forest coupes which have undermined the protection of high conservation areas and put in jeopardy the jobs of forest workers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, who has tried to fill the shoes of the environment's hero, Senator Graham Richardson, has found his feet have turned to clay. It takes more than a yes man who is at the beck and call of the environment movement, who feeds the greenies with so-called consultancy fees, who panders to the environmentalists' every wish, to become a hero. In the eyes of fair-minded Australians who want sustainable development, real jobs preserved and our environment protected by legitimate environmental management, the minister has dismally failed.

PARA.TAB: There could be no greater example of a soft and unaccountable government than Senator Faulkner's management of the ongoing debacle in his so-called assessment process. Senator Faulkner is not fit to be a minister for the environment. Like Ros Kelly, he has tried every avenue to weasel his way out of the mess, but at dusk his political scalp is waiting to be taken.I know that he is fidgeting a lot in caucus these days.

Senator Faulkner is now the fallen hero of even the extreme forest ferals. His charade has been exposed. Up until now Green groups have had the ears and eyes of the public, with their emotive and hysterical protests sitting on tripods, being seen carried kicking and screaming into the back of paddy wagons. These emotive scenes have been captured on our televisions and radio sets for years.

This was until last week. This was the week when the timber industry was able to go toe to toe with the environment movement. It gave the public a demonstration that made us all sit up and think. The difference was that the timber industry had the facts to substantiate its case.

The media at first trod warily. Then, when they could see that what the timber industry had been saying in an unemotive way for years made sense, this was a turning point for the timber industry. It was able to demonstrate that Senator Faulkner's assessments were carried out sloppily and in a way that completely made a rort of the assessment procedure. Senator Faulkner was shown to be incompetent and biased, to say the least.

Even the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has now woken up to the fact that the environmentalists have been filling him and his government with indefensible propaganda and making fools of them. He has now deserted you, Senator Faulkner—realising too late that the government's decisions were based on lies and distortions. Like a little boy who cannot be trusted, the Prime Minister pulled the minister off the job and brought in Senator Collins—the big job clean-up man—to broker a deal to limit the political morass into which the whole team had been thrown. In a letter to the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) dated 7 December 1994 submitting the first instalment of his now infamous forest preservation list, Senator Faulkner said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in preparing my advice I have been rigorous in identifying forests of high conservation value.

Later, in the Australian of 3 February, the minister again claimed that he had undertaken the most rigorous assessment practicable on the basis of the information available. These statements are the low water mark of Senator Faulkner's competency and accountability. These statements make his holding of this important portfolio untenable. These statements have now been proved to be untrue.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister subsequently reduced this rigorously determined list from 1,300 coupes to 509—or should it be 511? No-one knows. That is how incompetent the procedure was. At the Prime Minister's press conference he said, `Let's call a spade a spade. If 200 or 230 coupes had been reserved before Christmas, the environment movement would have thought they'd kicked a tremendous goal.' The goalposts have been continually moved in this debate.

I say to the minister that his assessments and lists were based on little scientific evidence. They were purely political decisions, and they have satisfied no-one. Senator Faulkner has had many opportunities over the last two weeks to explain the transparent lack of rigour in his lists, and he has failed to do so. He set up the process and he has demeaned the process. Senator Faulkner has done irreparable harm to the legitimate concerns of the conservation movement. I think that is worth repeating: he has done irreparable harm to the legitimate concerns of the conservation movement. He has done irreparable harm to the timber industry, and he has done irreparable harm to the nation's economy during a period when our current account deficit is running at an all-time high.

Pathetically, the minister has attempted to continue to defend a list that is shonky and indefensible. The caucus is publicly giving the same message. Mr Barry Cunningham, the member for McMillan, said, `We are moving away from good government.' Harry Quick, the member for Franklin, said, `I think it will have to be at least recognition that the process used may have had some errors in it and will have to be addressed.'

The evidence of this disillusionment is simple: in Victoria at least 10 of the coupes are non-existent. I have heard about the ghost gums, but now we have the ghost coupes. We have had the extraordinary case of environmental groups being funded to advise us on what areas are likely to be of high conservation value. Imagine the outcry there would have been if the timber industry had funded Minister Beddall's determination of woodchip licences.

Some plantations, both pine and eucalyptus, have been included in the original list. Talking about the pine and eucalypt plantations, I have received a flier from Senator Murphy's old union—the CFMEU. I do not know whether Senator Murphy's old union would recognise him. He has had a very distinct change of image in this place over the last two weeks. The problem with recognition would be quite extreme. If the union looked through his dental records—even taking his thumb print might be appropriate—it would be able to recognise him. This particular flier from the CFMEU, from Senator Murphy's old union, depicts the minister with his head in the sand. It tells an interesting story. The caption reads `Why Senator Faulkner can't tell a GUM tree from a PINE tree'. This comes from his mates. It reads:
We can't work out whether the Environment Minister, Senator John Faulkner, has his head in the sand or in the clouds.

The decision to renew export woodchip licences has provoked outrageous controversy, all because of Senator Faulkner's report nominating 1300 timber harvesting coupes as having "High Conservation Values".
It's the biggest load of bulldust we've ever seen.

Barely 20% of those 1300 coupes could possibly be said to have any special conservation values. Let alone "high" ones. For a start, many of them are regrowth forests: that is, forests that have been logged, then grown back again. And one, located near Gloucester in NSW, actually contains a pine plantation!

Obviously Senator Faulkner can't tell the difference between a gum tree and a pine tree. But 60,000 timber workers can. And they won't let any crackpot rabid green ideology or fabrication of facts dud them out of their jobs.
So come on, Senator Faulkner.

SPEECH.PARA: Get real. You do your job properly, and let us keep ours.

Then we discover the casual transfer of some 50 coupes from politically sensitive Tasmania to Victoria. This was revealed by the forest spokesman of the Tasmanian ALP, Mr Paul Lennon, on 27 January.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the guidelines to the national forest policy had been set out months ago, it would have saved a great deal of heartache and certainly most of the controversy that surrounds this issue. The national forest policy is the key to ecologically sustainable forest management. Senator Faulkner has promised, after two years of procrastination, that he will release within days the guidelines for regional forest agreements. We are watching and waiting, Senator Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner, you will not be allowed to renege on this one. You have blatantly misled the Senate by insisting that you have been vigorous in identifying forests of high conservation value. You have falsely asserted that an abundant forest species is a nationally rare plant in order to stop logging. Worst of all, you have imperilled thousands of families who work in one of Australia's most important export industries. Minister, you have publicly demeaned high conservation values and discredited all those who are committed to finding sensible and scientifically based solutions to issues of sustainable development.

The entire debate has evolved far beyond woodchipping. I clearly remember Port Hinchinbrook, as we all do. In that instance the minister cost hundreds of jobs by the stroke of a pen. The debate is now about this parliament calling the minister to account for the waste of taxpayers' dollars and for his failure to follow the government's own procedure. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it somewhat amusing to get up and to enter into a debate about this issue yet again two weeks after the commencement of the parliamentary session for the New Year and when the opposition—being totally demoralised—has returned after electing its third leader in less than 12 months. I can understand the joy you must have found in the ring of log trucks—not that you care about forests or forestry, because you do not. I will demonstrate the fact that those opposite do not. In relation to their stated policy, not only do they not understand anything about forests but they do not care about them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Gibson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gibson, I would not make too much noise if I were you because you, as a managing director of a company in your previous life, oversaw one of the most demonstrable destructions of forest in Tasmania you could ever believe. We have to look at what this debate is really about. Senator Ian MacDonald gets up in here and moves a censure motion against Senator Faulkner. The shadow minister for regional development and infrastructure has not made too many issues about regional development since he has been in here, and he is not in here now. He has not raised any issues about regional development in this country.

PARA.TAB: Last week the opposition jumped up and down and ranted and raved about the national forest policy statement—something we brought about—and kept telling us that it is such a great thing. Senator Crane came in here today with one page. I saw Senator Panizza with another page the other day; yet I have not seen any of the others with any pages. Senator Crane, for all intents and purposes, wanted to use that one page—that is probably about all he has read—to support his contribution to the debate.

Last week the opposition chose to make the issue about export woodchip licences. It came in here and said, `Terrible, terrible, terrible. All these jobs are going to go because of the fact that these export woodchip licences are not secure.' Let me tell you that the one very important thing in this debate that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said is that there ought to be a reduction in export woodchips. There is no doubt about that because there are no social and economic benefits for us to continue to export woodchips out of this country, particularly when we have a trade deficit in forest products and commodities which makes up 13 per cent of our trade deficit.

Those opposite have a policy of continuing export woodchips indefinitely. That is what they want to do. They want to continue to export the forests out of this country in woodchips and not make one ounce of contribution to the wellbeing of the workers they hypocritically in the extreme pretend to represent. You have no hope of representing workers of this country and, more importantly, representing workers in this industry. For the benefit of those opposite, I will read from the national forest policy statement. The foreword states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Statement has been jointly developed by the Commonwealth, States and Territories through the Australian Forestry Council and the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council in consultation with other relevant government agencies, the Australian Local Government Association, unions, industry representatives, conservation organisations and the general community.

It sets out a process through which we will get the very important protection for some of our natural heritage, much of which has been taken away in the very short time we have been in this country. We will also deliver through it a forest industry—one which I stand up for very much, but which needs some changes. The industry does not need a policy that says, `Export woodchips forever.' This policy will bring about some stability to an industry that can deliver to this country and to the people who work in the industry more security in terms of jobs, more security in terms of development and long-term security in terms of the supply of resource, because we will have forests that will be managed on a sustainable basis forever.

PARA.TAB: I want to again raise the hypocrisy in the continuation of this opposition's pursuit of this issue. We have had a forest industry since the year dot. We have had export woodchips since the 1970s. We have had a national forest policy statement since 1990; yet not once before last week did the opposition come in here and attempt to secure any input into the process. Not even at the last election did it have a policy that would make any contribution at all to the long-term future stability of the industry or, indeed, of the environment.

I do not know who represents you lot over there on forests, but you have really sent in the heavyweights today. You got your shadow spokesman for regional development to bowl the balls, or we thought he was going to bowl some balls. I can remember an incident where one of the Chappell brothers bowled a ball underarm once. I have to say that Senator Ian Macdonald's underarm ball did not even make the other end of the pitch. Senator Alston, the communications spokesman, was also sent in to bat. He still has a view that this is a woodchip policy. He is confusing that with the opposition's policy, because it has a woodchip policy. We have a policy about delivering a sustainable industry that actually returns some benefit to the community.

I am pleased to hear that the Democrats are not supporting this ridiculous censure motion which is of no relevance whatsoever. Those opposite believe that this motion is delivering some political benefit to them, but that is the most stupid thing they could ever think of because it clearly demonstrates the fact that they really have not come out of the coma they were in before Christmas and prior to their choosing a third leader in 12 months. They still have not come out of that to make any reasonable contribution to the political debate of this country—they just simply cannot do that.

I want to raise a couple of points with regard to the position of the Democrats. Whilst I agree in part with Senator Bell that there is, and has been, a problem with the process, it cannot be levelled at any particular person or area. There is a range of people who are involved in the national forest policy statement and bringing it together needs the participation of the states. Senator Bell said he found fault with the process. He did not say that he found fault with the process when he thought the 1,300 coupes were relevant and/or to be protected. He did not find fault with the process when he said he was going to go out and raise money to mount legal challenges to the current export woodchip licences. Indeed, I do not know whether he has found much fault with the process when he says he is proposing to introduce a bill to ban woodchipping altogether. So I do question the validity and the credibility of some of the things that Senator Bell has said. Senator Abetz has been contributing to this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.

—Absolutely. I would like to look for a moment at the credentials with which Senator Abetz comes to this place. On 29 April 1993, Robin Gray, the former Premier of Tasmania and now the Minister for Primary Industry and Fisheries, said this about Senator Abetz:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Abetz's contribution to the Liberal Party of Tasmania has been a negative, culminating in the grand defeat of the Liberal Party at the 1993 election—

Mr Abetz has had a record of interfering in the affairs of the Parliamentary Liberal Party, making inopportune comments—
this is important—
about the policies of the Parliamentary Liberal Party, and adopting a position of the extreme right in his attitude towards liberalism in Tasmania.

Yet, Senator Abetz comes in here shouting, ranting and raving about looking after the interests of workers. Let me ask you, Senator Abetz—I asked you last week and I ask you again this week—where were you when your Liberal Premier in Tasmania sacked the construction workers at a great cost to the state of Tasmania? Where were you defending the workers then? You were nowhere, the same place you are now. You have no credibility when it comes to protecting the interests of workers.

PARA.TAB: I will come back to a point that Senator Sandy Macdonald made just a moment ago about the shadow forest minister in Tasmania, Paul Lennon. He has somehow got his wires crossed totally about what Paul Lennon said about 50 coupes—which is a further demonstration of the opposition's inadequacy and total inability to understand what forest issues are about. The 50 coupes that the Tasmanian shadow minister was talking about are coupes that were on the register of the national estate. They are totally separate from the 509. So, Senator Macdonald, if you are going to come in here and make claims about members of parliament in other places, claims about what they said, and try to interpret what they said, I suggest that you get your facts straight. I referred earlier in the week to the intergovernmental agreement as it relates to the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did aNiMaLS provide you with that?

—It is in the national forest policy statement, Senator Abetz. The opposition obviously did not listen. Senator Macdonald obviously did not listen because he keeps calling on the Commonwealth to issue some criteria on comprehensive regional assessments. The fact of the matter is, for your benefit, Senator Macdonald—
—For your benefit.

—maybe for your benefit as well, Senator Ian Macdonald, the states are the people to invite the Commonwealth. The criteria is to be agreed criteria. If the Commonwealth had said, `Here is the criteria and you will abide by it,' the first people to be jumping up and down in this place would have been the opposition. They would have been ranting, raving and screaming about states rights and the fact that we have overridden the states and done all sorts of things. Senator Sandy Macdonald does not believe that. You say that we should say what the criteria is, don't you? Is that right? You want the Commonwealth to set the guidelines? I would have to say that the silence from the other side is an indication that that must be right.

PARA.TAB: Where do we go with this ridiculous censure motion? After two weeks, you got Senator Ian Macdonald to come in here and move a motion of this nature. I would have to say it is a clear demonstration of the inability of the opposition to get into this debate and to come to grips with this issue in a way that will enable it to make a contribution of a positive nature. Whether or not you agree with the areas nominated by the conservation groups and whether or not you agree with the process is not necessarily all that relevant. I would have thought that conservation groups in this country have a vital role to play in the protection of the environment. I do not think anyone in this place would disagree that, over time, they have made a significant contribution in bringing the importance of the environment to the attention of the Australian public.

If it is the case that you think that they are wrong, that is okay because Australia is a democracy and we are all entitled to our opinion. Whether or not these things are accurate, it would be difficult—on the basis of some of the state government information that they are supposed to have and are supposed to provide—for anybody to be accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Here it is. Look at what they did. This is just for eight coupes.

—Senator Macdonald, I am pleased. I hope that you have read it all. Those people, for all intents and purposes, probably made their best effort to make that information as legitimate as they could. If it is not, so be it. It will be proven to be so.
—Why did you waste the money?

—No, Senator Macdonald. The assessments that the government has now entered into will prove one way or another whether or not the first claims on coupes have been accurate in their environmental values. Again, for the benefit of the opposition, the national forest policy statement sets out that there has to be a process of assessment—and there is going to be one.

PARA.TAB: The only thing I would like to say in closing in this debate is this: I wish the Prime Minister had said that the wind-down of export woodchips would not be the subject of regional forest agreements. I cannot accept the fact that a country that has 13 per cent of its trade deficit made up of imported forest or wood products should be exporting six million tonnes of woodchips. That is abhorrent, it is ridiculous and it should be brought to an end. We should make the participants in this industry either get in and do something about it or we should give that resource to somebody who will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a motion by Senator Ian Macdonald—probably the most extreme right wing representative and anti-environment representative of the opposition—to censure the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner). There are two reasons why one should consider censuring a minister. One of those reasons involves technical competence and the other one is to deal with the way in which the issues, namely the portfolio responsibilities, are handled.

PARA.TAB: In the case of the first one, the technical competence of the minister, the situation is quite clear because the matter has in fact been tested in the courts. Mr Justice Sackville found that the incompetence lay with the Mr Beddall in the administration of his portfolio. I will return to that in a moment. There was no fault found in that hearing against the minister for the environment.

The substantial issue here is the administration of his portfolio responsibilities—he is the minister for the environment looking after the environment. One can well understand Senator Macdonald having a disagreement there because Senator Macdonald would totally disagree with any ministry at all which was designed to protect the environment.

One need only look back through the Hansard record to see the way in which, at every opportunity, any suggestion that the environment be protected has been resisted and opposed by Senator Macdonald. In recent days there have been debates on greenhouse emissions and the suggestion that we might do something about it by putting a resource tax on carbon based fuels. There was opposition to that. Senators will recall the attempt to do something in the transport area, to find a substantial source of an alternative transport fuel for Australia—the use of ethanol. Senators will recall Senator Macdonald's opposition to that bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell lies. You are a liar.

—I ask your colleagues to go back and look at the Hansard record of exactly what you said in that debate. It is there in the record. The reason this motion has come up this afternoon is abundantly clear. When you look at the developments—
—I raise a point of order. I object very strenuously to Senator Macdonald saying to Senator Coulter or any other senator, `You are a liar.' I ask that he withdraw those remarks.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Yes, it is unparliamentary. I ask Senator Macdonald to withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what it has to do with Senator Crowley. I withdraw as you ask. But I will not sit here and have Senator Coulter or anyone else completely and maliciously misrepresent what I say, and I will not have him call me an ultra right wing something or other, which again is completely untrue. If he wants to get into the name calling he will have to take a bit back. Come on, Nazi, it's your turn.

—It is spurious of Senator Macdonald to wonder what relevance it is to me. Any senator at any time can draw attention to what is unparliamentary by common agreement in this place and by standing orders. I do not believe that Senator Macdonald assisted his case by using the word `Nazi' as he sat down. Again, I would ask him to withdraw that.

—If Senator Crowley, in her position at present of representing the government, is going to adopt the position she has with her first and second points of order with regard to my colleague Senator Macdonald, she should have first asked Senator Coulter to withdraw what he said about Senator Macdonald. If you are going to apply one rule to the goose, you also have to apply it to the gander. I suggest that if Senator Macdonald is going to be forced to withdraw because he responded to outrageous provocation, then you ought to also pull Senator Coulter into order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—My ruling is that I would have to again ask Senator Macdonald to withdraw the word `Nazi'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I will do that. I really don't know why I respond to Senator Coulter; nobody else takes any notice of him.

—I know why Senator Macdonald responds. It is because what I have just said is very close to the truth. Again, I invite anybody to look back through the Hansard record at Senator Macdonald's record with respect to debates on environmental matters. He has always taken an anti-environmental stance.

PARA.TAB: If you look back at the reasons for this particular debate this afternoon and you look at what has happened over the last couple of weeks, you will find that my colleague Senator Bell, who spoke earlier this afternoon, attempted to get an inquiry into the very matters about which the opposition has been seeking a great deal of information. It would have been a proper inquiry which could have looked at the whole process, looked at all the facts, and out of that we could have formed an opinion as to whether the process was faulty, as to whether Minister Faulkner or Minister Beddall or both were at fault.

What we heard from the opposition was: `We don't want an inquiry; we have the government on the run. This is a political matter. We are going to pursue this matter through political means.' That is the reason the opposition did not want a proper inquiry. Having the government on the run, as those opposite think, they are pursuing this matter in the absence of a great deal of information which they themselves have asked for, information which is not yet available. Surely they should have waited until that information was available before proceeding with a censure motion such as this. This is a political move and should be seen simply as a political move, not as an issue to bring out facts in relation to the substantive issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just toadies for the Labor Party.

—Again, Senator Macdonald, the substantive issue is the proper protection of the forests and the establishment of a sustainable industry, not simply scoring political points by trying to move censure motions against the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. That is your concern.

PARA.TAB: There have been numerous motions in recent days asking for information which would allow the Senate to properly consider all the facts in relation to the process which we have seen here. Many of those motions have been put by the opposition. The opposition has often asked for information to be supplied within a very short time frame. We have supported many of those motions. We ourselves have three notices of motion which we will be seeking to move as formal tomorrow. We give the government until 1 March to provide that information. In the light of that information, we will then make up our mind. It is clearly a political move not aimed at improving the substantive matter here, the proper management of forests, but simply to get at the minister.

In our view, looking at the evidence that has been properly tested in the courts and upon which Mr Justice Sackville has given judgment, it is Mr Beddall who has failed in the proper following of the procedures which are set down. Whether those procedures are faulty or not is Mr Justice Sackville's opinion.

The opposition has repeated this afternoon and on a number of other occasions that if an area of forest has in some way been damaged then it is automatically ruled out from having value which would cause it to be protected. That is absolutely a non sequitur. It would mean that one could go into any area of forest and once that area is minimally damaged it would deserve no protection and progressively you would wipe out all forests in Australia.

My colleague Senator Bell gave an example the other day of an area of forest in the south-east of New South Wales, which I visited several years ago, in which 22,000 koalas were shot in the 1920s before there was koala protection. There are no koalas in that area now and the New South Wales Forestry Commission has said, `That is not koala habitat; therefore, it can be logged.' If one accepts that sort of logic, one would say that that area will continue to be logged. It will never again become koala habitat, yet clearly it has the potential to be an excellent koala habitat. Therefore, that area could play a very valuable role in the protection of threatened species. Here is an area which has been damaged, yet clearly it has value sufficient to warrant its protection from further logging.

One could look at many other areas. Senator Bell has given an example this afternoon of possibly the oldest living thing, plant or animal in the world—a Huon pine in Tasmania which is estimated to be at least 10,500 years old. If that area had been in some way damaged, by the opposition's logic it should not be on the list; therefore, it could be logged, and that tree could be cut down.

That is the logic of those opposite. Basically, they are not interested in the substantive issue, which is, on the one hand, the protection of important areas of forest in Australia to preserve those values—forestry protection, wildlife and threatened species protection, recreation value protection, protection of waterways and supply of water and the aesthetic values which forests contain—and, on the other hand, building a sustainable forestry industry in Australia, which we do not have that at the moment.

The forest industry in Australia has soaked up more than $5 billion worth of debt, public moneys which have been put into the forest industry. Surely that is something the opposition would object to. Those opposite object to public subsidy in every other respect, yet here they are trying to protect an industry which has soaked up such an enormous amount of public subsidy. Surely that should be rooted out. We have an industry which is still totally out of balance with respect to the balance of trade. Surely, again, we need very substantial expansion of plantation forestry in Australia so that we do become self-sufficient in forest products, so that we do supply all those things, so that there are secured jobs.

As far as the 509 coupes or the 1,300 coupes are concerned, it is an absolute lie that the removal of those coupes would have made any difference whatsoever to any employment this year. The 509 coupes, as I asked the minister the other day, involve one-fifteenth of one per cent of Australia's forested area, half a per cent of the forest available for logging, and roughly five per cent of the area which was in fact marked out for logging in 1995. The removal of five per cent of that area could easily have been substituted for another five per cent, other coupes which were available for logging.

The argument that there was suddenly going to precipitate a decline in employment in the forestry industry simply is not true. There has been a decline in employment in the forestry industry—from 55,000 in 1971-72 to 32,000 in 1991-92—but against that, the production from Australian forests has gone up from 11 million cubic metres to 16 million cubic metres. The reduction in employment has not been accompanied by a reduction in production. In fact, it has been accompanied by a substantial increase in production.

The efforts of conservationists to protect old-growth and important forests have not been accompanied by a decline in the availability of timber. The loss of jobs has been due, quite simply, to the increased capitalisation of the industry and the shift from sawlogs to woodchips. The claims being made in relation to workers, unions and so on are really without foundation.

There are a number of other points. Several speakers from the opposition have mentioned greenhouse this afternoon in quite a spurious way. I think Senator Alston brought the issue of greenhouse into the debate. Senator Boswell earlier this afternoon asked a question about greenhouse. Senator Boswell, in his question, made it quite clear that he did not even understand the basic elements of the carbon cycle. Relating this to forests, he argued that there should be a tax rebate to those who grow trees and those who plant sugar cane. If you take the logic of the latter—

TALK.START.PARA: —How is this relevant?

—Ask Senator Boswell; he raised it this afternoon. The relevance is that Senator Alston dealt with this matter at some length during his diatribe. If one were to offer a tax rebate to those who grow sugar cane, then when that sugar is consumed by humans—of course, it is turned back into carbon dioxide—you would be taxing them for eating it. I suggest that Senator Boswell follows the logic of his argument through. It indicates just how little the opposition really understands many of these issues in relation to forestry.
—Say what you understand about jobs, John. Nothing.

—I have already indicated that there has been a substantial decline in the forestry industry, not due to any of the efforts of conservationists to protect old-growth forests or forests of important environmental values but due to the industry itself, due to the failure of successive governments, both Commonwealth and state, to adequately plant plantations. Again I stress that South Australia has the only forestry commission which actually runs at a profit. It has been based on plantations for a very long time.
—How much natural forest compared with Tasmania?

—Thank you, senator. You make my point exactly. The other states should have been planting plantations over many decades. There would be more employment in the forestry industry and that forestry industry would be sustainable.
—Thirty-three per cent of my state is locked up from logging. How much from South Australia?
—If there were adequate plantations you would not be going into those.
—How much from South Australia? You won't answer that, will you?

—Softwoods from South Australia provide a very substantial portion of all of Australia's sawn log. I return to the point at which I began; that is, if there is any proved fault in any minister in relation to this whole process—I go back to the legal decision given by Justice Sackville—it lies with the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall. Therefore, I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit "Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner)", substitute "Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall)".

SPEECH.PARA: I think in the Minister for Resources we have a target about which there is a substantial area of proof. I think that is a far more appropriate motion given that the opposition has asked for a great deal of information and has not yet received that information.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is making this attack on the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories on the run. If, following the supply of that information, which will only become available over succeeding weeks, they wish to proceed with a censure motion further on, then that will be considered on its merits. But it is clearly a political move now and therefore is not to be supported, particularly—I repeat the point at which I began—given the direction from which this motion has come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues, particularly Senator Ian Macdonald for his censure motion against the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. We have seen here in Canberra for the last two weeks an absolute mess over this issue of Australia's native forests. The real culprit for bringing on this mess and getting the government into trouble is Senator Faulkner. He has shown complete incompetence.

PARA.TAB: It is not long ago, only last year, that Senator Faulkner became Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. One would have thought that one of the first things he should have done when he became minister was engage competent staff to look after him because it is obvious he knows nothing about environmental issues. One would have thought he would have engaged good staff to help him so that he could get proper advice. He also ought to have been aware that his department had been politicised for years, started off by Senator Richardson and carried on by Ros Kelly. It got to the stage where absolutely no-one, not even the conservation movement, would trust what came out of that department. Senator Faulkner has really taken this matter of trees to heart and thought he could do a Richo, as Senator Alston pointed out before.

When Senator Faulkner issued his environment policy statement in the middle of last year, he basically sketched a scene of his doing many things. But what has happened? The only thing he has concentrated on is trees, the forests. He has been playing with the forests and pandering to the extreme greens. In recent times we have seen these chickens coming home to roost. He has actually handed out $120,000 to the green groups to help him politicise decision making by the government on an annual basis, which is again a sham and a nonsense, for the export woodchip industry.

Let us step back and see what this argument has really all been about. The woodchip licence debate has been a politicised debate organised by the government to play green politics in suburban Melbourne and Sydney against the interests of conservation and the forest industry. The real argument for many years concerning the native forests has been how much park there should be, how much reserve there should be and how much forest should be used for multiple use in Australia. The argument has been going on for many years.

Several years ago, in the late 1980s, then Prime Minister Hawke engaged the Resource Assessment Commission to do a study to settle once and for all these arguments advanced by the greens, the industry and the various state departments, who, after all, have responsibility for running these lands, as to what the truth of the matter was. What came out of that was a report which indicated that there was no reason why the native forests could not be managed, as they were being managed, on a sustained basis to produce multiple products—wood, water, recreation and conservation values—provided also that there were proper reserve areas, preserved and left intact; in other words, our parks and proper conservation areas.

The real argument is: how much park and conservation area; and, how much multiple-use forest? That is what it is really all about. The woodchips are really just a diversion, a political diversion. It has been a diversion that has been used deliberately by the federal government each year in this annual export licence process to try to play politics for suburban Melbourne and Sydney.

Following the Resource Assessment Commission report and after lots of argument each year with the states, again, what happened was that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at long last was forced into signing a national forest policy statement in December 1993, just over two years ago. That was a statement signed by the Prime Minister and most of the states; in fact, there has been general agreement by all the states on that forest policy statement. That statement is about how to finally decide at the margin, only for a small proportion, what of the remaining native forests should go into park—what small proportion should go into park, and what should be left alone for multiple use.

In south-east Australia—that is the southern states of New South Wales, Victoria and Tasmania—about half of the native forests are already locked up in parks and reserves of one sort or another. So the argument is what to do with the other half. How much of it, perhaps a few per cent, should be added after proper scientific study into the parks and reserves? But no, what have we got? We have got the extreme green movement pushing to have the whole lot, 100 per cent of all the forests, locked up forever and to have ordinary Australians paying higher prices via imports for forest products—forest products coming from forests in other countries that are not as well managed as they are in Australia. There are no forests anywhere in the world as well managed as the native forests are here in Australia. So we had this silly argument about woodchips.

Two years ago the Prime Minister and most of the premiers signed this agreement to settle this argument once and for all and to go ahead with the studies to find out what small proportion of the remaining half of the forest of this part of Australia should go into parks. There was agreement that that should be done on a cooperative basis. It required good faith, cooperation and trust by all parties.

What has happened over the past two years? The environment department of the Commonwealth government continued its long period of attempts to stop settlement of this longstanding dispute and kept working against the interests in the settlement of this dispute. If you go and talk to each of the state governments and the state government departments responsible for this matter, they will complain bitterly to you, and have done so out on the public record, about the lack of cooperation from this department and the ministers: starting off with Senator Richardson originally, then Ros Kelly and now the current minister, Senator Faulkner. Unfortunately, poor Senator Faulkner walked into all this not understanding it all. I assume that he has not had the staff to basically guide him through all this mess. Regardless of that, he is responsible; so we have this terrible mess.

It is true that the department is not trusted by anyone in the responsible land management agencies throughout Australia. Minister Collins mentioned CALM before; that is, the Western Australian department's process. Each of the states has gone through a very similar process. Senator Ian Macdonald has copies of the documents from the south-east of New South Wales, from the Eden area. The same thing has happened in my state in Tasmania.

There have been long and detailed processes of looking at what parts of the native forests should go into park and what should go into multiple use. Virtually all of the work has been done; what we are arguing about is just the little bit at the margin. That is what the Prime Minister put in his statement. It was about wanting to ban woodchips on the bit at the margin, not on the total situation. But Senator Faulkner has encouraged his department to go ahead on this basis of looking at the woodchip licence situation at the end of last year, and what did he do? He went and encouraged the green groups to produce this mad list of 1,300 coupes and do it with a payment of $120,000. It has been shown in this chamber and in the other place over the last fortnight that that whole process was an absolute shonk, that there were dozens of coupes that were absolute nonsense. They were not of high conservation value.

Another very important matter arising from that national forest policy statement—which, again, I remind you was signed by the Prime Minister and the premiers—was the moratorium clause. Senator Faulkner and, I assume, his department have misinterpreted that moratorium clause. The moratorium clause is all to do with the final assessment of wilderness and old growth as to what parts of old growth and wilderness should be added to the park system. It was not to do with other issues. That was the thing that had to be settled. That is what the premiers and the Prime Minister signed off on. Senator Faulkner, I believe, has deliberately misinterpreted that clause in the forest policy statement and he has deliberately encouraged the green groups to run off and chase other things; hence we have this terrible mess.

That is basically what has happened. It has been incompetence by the minister which has led to this mess. Why is it that the Prime Minister had to intervene last week? Why is it that Senator Collins is now running the show? Because there has been incompetence by two ministers: Minister Beddall and Senator Faulkner. But the prime culprit is Senator Faulkner. He engineered it. He deliberately went out and encouraged the extreme greens to come up with this wish list instead of going the professional route and going to the land managers in the states that had the detailed information.

Why do some of the land managers not trust his department? Because his department over the last several years has sold them down the drain, has not cooperated with them and will not provide the criteria for doing these assessments. Why? Because the department is basically run by extreme greens acting on an extreme green agenda. They do not want this issue settled once and for all. They want the crisis to continue year in, year out, hoping they will get more forest locked up.

I am pleased to have heard Senator Collins say this afternoon that the government is committed to getting this fixed up once and for all. The opposition policy is to have the matter fixed up once and for all. That is our firm policy. Senator Collins cannot say he does not know and the industry does not know what our policy is. Last Monday I was with the two shadow ministers and our leader who went and addressed the group here at Parliament House and pointed out that we were in favour of the national forest policy. We are in favour of those regional agreements being settled once and for all and quickly so that we can get on and have multiple-use forests and also conservation areas.

Senator Faulkner, by carrying on in the way he has in pushing this extreme green process, has demeaned the whole process of looking at conservation areas. He has demeaned that process and has really sold out all Australians, including all of us who are concerned about true conservation areas. All of us, certainly in the coalition, want a basis of proper reserves of the forests throughout Australia. That is what needs to be fixed and fixed once and for all. I support my colleagues in the censure motion of the minister.
Debate (on motion by Senator Crowley) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that Senator Faulkner has carried out his responsibilities as the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories; I believe that he has done it very well. I am disappointed though in Senator Ian Macdonald. I am reminded of a notice of motion which Senator Ian Macdonald moved recently which related to damage which was being done to the Barrier Reef by Asian fishermen in their use of cyanide to remove valuable fish. In clause 4 of that notice of motion, he said that the effect of the chemical sprays on the reef is equivalent to `a holocaust'. I agree with him, and I agree with the contents of his motion which was calling on the government to do something about that particular illegal activity.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ian Macdonald, nevertheless, does not recognise that certain logging methods and behaviour of certain loggers in coupes in Australian forests have also had the effect of a holocaust on those forests. While some people log in a way that is certainly environmentally less damaging than others, some are very careless with the future of the environment. I believe—and I have heard people from both sides of the parliament say that they also believe—in the protection of the environment, and that is it is vital to the Australian community, and in particular to its young people to whom the future belongs.

John Faulkner, as the minister, certainly operates on that basis. It is his responsibility to look after the environment; that is what he has been put there for. I believe that he brings to the office the particular determination of making use of people who are qualified, as accords with the list that Senator Crowley has just tabled in the parliament, and that he has come down with a view about the coupes that should be protected, based on reality and expertise. The groups that are involved in real confrontation over the use of forests are the conservationists and the people who log forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Workers—unionists!

—They can be described as trade unionists; you can describe some of them as small businessmen and others as large companies. It would seem to me that, to look at this matter in an objective way, one cannot accept as fact every thing that either side says. Each side has its certain bias and they both make the best of their arguments, sometimes using extravagant language, as opposition members have done here today. However, what is needed is to look at the long-term future of the forest and of the environment.

PARA.TAB: The loggers talk about protecting the forest, but their role is to remove trees and destroy the forests. They talk about regrowth which, in my experience and from what I have observed, certainly does not fit the bill. There are those people in the logging area who traditionally have, over the years, planted trees for plantations which will be harvested at a later date. I know there are paper manufacturers in Tasmania, for instance, who have been planting trees probably for the last 70 years; I respect that. I think they have found the correct way to go and are continuing on that path. But there are other people in the industry who have been chipping logs and trees for at least 20 years; they have not planted one tree but they talk about regrowth as being the way to go—that that is the answer.

We have had people come to the parliament surrounding the place with trucks and people, putting whatever pressure they could on the government to reverse the decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

TALK.START.PARA: —Unionists.
—Some unionists, some small businessmen, and other people sent there from big companies.
—Stand up for the workers.
—All people who work. Senator Macdonald, I have been standing up for the workers for at least 40 years. I have not heard you stand up for workers in the way that I have.
—You weren't last week.

—I was standing up for the workers; I will stand up for them when they are right and advise them when they are wrong. The facts are that there has been talk of jobs really being the whole issue. All of my working life, I have been concerned about jobs—for myself and for other people. I would not consciously want to see any job go that could be retained—any job that is productive and reasonable in terms of giving some satisfaction to those people who carry out the work. There are some jobs obviously that, because of their nature, everybody agrees should be eliminated and other methods found.

PARA.TAB: But we are part of a world economy that is changing every day—not only every week but every day—in terms of the nature of work, the way in which we organise companies, the way in which we manage, the way in which we produce goods and the way in which we create wealth. People have said—and I agree—that there has to be some balance between the creation of wealth and protection of the environment. If we look at the issue of jobs, it has been the opinion of people on the other side that, for instance, the waterfront was over staffed, that jobs should go and that we should become more efficient.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that was Collins's view.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That has happened. The Labor Party as a government, for instance, decided that—
—What was that, Crowley?
—no longer should Australia be burdened with a steel industry that was inefficient, that was obviously not attrac tive—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I do not really wish to interrupt again—and I will not—but Senator Macdonald was using a name and not the title, which he knows is unparliamentary. Could you remind him of his obligations in this matter?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Yes. Senator Macdonald, I ask you to call people by their correct titles.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the government provided $500 million to assist the steel industry to become more efficient. As you would recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, BHP as a company agreed to spend some millions of dollars to upgrade its facilities and methods of production. Indeed, the move was so successful that BHP finished up spending almost twice the originally agreed amount. But in the process, there were many tens of thousands of jobs destroyed.

PARA.TAB: Most people in the community said—and I am sure people on that side of the chamber said—that that was necessary because we had to compete against world class production methods, and we had to be able to compete with our exports of steel and also provide a component into other industries at the cheapest possible price. So it was seen as necessary that thousands of jobs should go.

My position was very clear: I did not disagree with that, but we certainly had to make provision to retrain those people so that they could try to find other jobs. I find that the position is the same in the forest industry. To protect the forest and the environment, we will have to look at retraining and other jobs. If we do say that the issue is jobs at all cost or any cost, we will be failing the future generations in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not saying that.

—I am saying that it is being said. The assistant secretary of the union said, `We are leaving here now; if one job is lost, we will be back.' So they will bring 300 to 400 trucks back if a job is lost. The point I am trying to make is that, right throughout the community, we have a situa

SPEECH.PARA: Achieving these goals will require the application of Commonwealth resources, financial, administrative and scientific. We will make the necessary contribution to achieve success within time deadlines agreed with the States and Territories. The Australian Heritage Commission will continue its valuable contribution to this process.
Forests

There has been no greater source of conflict over environmental issues in Australia in recent years than in forests. It is here that the concept of sustainable development has one of its most acute tests, due to widely differing views over the logging of native forests.

It is important that this issue be resolved as soon as possible, and conflict either eliminated or greatly reduced. The recent development of a National Forest Strategy (not yet fully agreed to by all governments), has taken much of the heat out of the issue. Nonetheless much more needs to be done.

Australia needs to conserve its native forests consistent with its objectives for biological diversity. At the same time the timber industry, one of Australia's most important resource and manufacturing industries and providers of jobs and sustenance to a large number of small isolated communities, must be encouraged to thrive, expand and be sustainable.

Thus on the one hand there needs to be security of protection for biological diversity, and on the other hand security of tenure and access to resources for the timber industry. It is a classic case of the balance needing to be struck for ensuring sustainable development. Both Commonwealth and State Governments must accept the responsibility for striking this balance, knowing that no one will be entirely satisfied with the decisions made.

The Coalition supports the National Forest Strategy, and will provide Commonwealth legislative endorsement of State or regional forest strategies which meet approved standards. Without such endorsement potential investors in the timber industry will not have the security of access they need for sound investment. Without more investment the benefits in jobs and in the wider economy will be lost. Also the timber industry will not have the financial strength to meet the conservation objectives that are a critical element in its operations.
The expansion of plantations, especially of hardwoods, will be encouraged. Specific measures to encourage plantations are outlined earlier in this policy statement.

As part of our Fightback! plan the Coalition will also be encouraging the States and the private sector to carry out the microeconomic reform measures in forestry and timber production needed to achieve best international practice. Better information on the economics of the industry flowing from these reforms will also help to resolve arguments over the most effective use of our natural resources.
WORLD HERITAGE LISTING

The Liberal and National Parties support the inscription of appropriate sites on the World Heritage List in recognition of their outstanding value to all the peoples of the world. We will not propose sites for listing without the fullest consultation and without the co-operation of the State or Territory Governments.

In order to avoid future conflicts, the incoming Coalition Government will give priority to finalisation, in consultation with the States and Territories, of a comprehensive indicative list to identify any sites in Australia which might in future be considered for World Heritage Listing as satisfying the criteria laid down under the Convention for the Protection of World Cultural and Natural Heritage. Any sites proposed for further consideration will be evaluated by a Joint Commonwealth-State and local government study and an early decision made about their future in relation to World Heritage Listing. This will include obtaining agreement on a plan of management which will make clear what uses will be allowed in the future and what administrative arrangements will apply.
