DEVELOPMENT OF ADVICE TO THE MINISTER FOR ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES ON A STRATEGY AND PLAN OF ACTION TO PHASE OUT HARVESTING OF HIGH CONSERVATION VALUE FORESTS BY THE YEAR 2000: THE ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC IMPLICATIONS
(1) BACKGROUND

The National Forest Policy Statement (NFPS) includes, inter alia, a strategy for the protection of old-growth forests and wilderness and the development of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system. The NFPS envisages the undertaking of comprehensive regional assessments and the negotiation of regional forest agreements as the primary mechanisms by which the conservation and ecologically sustainable use of forests could be achieved. To date progress on the conservation elements of the NFPS has been disappointingly slow.
The Prime Minister, in his statement on woodchip exports of 22 December, announced a program to phase out the export of woodchips from native forests by the year 2000.

The Environment portfolio considers that the conservation elements of the NFPS and the Governments export woodchip phase out policy can be effectively implemented through a comprehensive strategy to phase out harvesting of high conservation forests by the turn of the century and the ecologically sustainable management of other areas of native forests for domestic uses. Such a strategy must address the environmental, social and economic implications and involve an implementation action plan.
The immediate priority is to develop a summary strategy and implementation plan for consideration by the portfolio Minister. This could form the basis of and/or contribute to future work.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this censure motion was introduced by Senator Ian Macdonald, I listened very carefully because I think it is very serious to have a motion of censure against a minister or anybody in the government. It is something that deserves consideration. While he was talking about his reasons for the censure motion, I was trying to work out what we were censuring the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) for.

PARA.TAB: I listed a number of things. Firstly, it seemed to me he was being censured for doing his job—for looking after the environment. I know it is unusual to have an environment minister who actually does look after the interests of the environment. If you are from Western Australia, it is an utterly alien concept because we have not had environment ministers who really did the job. We have not had an environment minister in this parliament who has been doing his job thoroughly in relation to this matter and other matters for quite some time, certainly outside my experience. So I could not agree with that reason if that was the reason Senator Ian Macdonald was introducing the motion.

The second reason Senator Ian Macdonald seemed to be giving was that the minister for the environment had given money to the voluntary conservation movement. I believe that there has been a reasonably full and open account of the money given. If there are any concerns about the process I am sure we have the ability to scrutinise that process when the documents get tabled. However, if it is just the principle of allowing funding for people when you are asking them to provide some kind of responsible and thoroughgoing analysis and advice, then why should they not receive the funding that allows them to do that?

We have to remember that it is a voluntary conservation movement. They have to be able to gain the advice of experts and look at matters that are outside their normal jobs. It is outrageous to suggest that they should not receive funding. If the conservation movement had paid Senator Faulkner for doing the assessment, that could be a different matter again. However, I support the fact that the movement was asked to provide some advice to a process. It is a stakeholder in that process and it has a right to see some support for it. It is totally different. We have industry funding. We have industry subsidies. We know that the forestry industries are considerably well subsidised by the community for their operations already. I think it was perfectly appropriate for that to be done. So I did not support the motion on that account.

The third reason that Senator Ian Macdonald mentioned got quite close. He said that he was condemning the Minister for the Environment for not succeeding in protecting the old growth and high conservation value forests. That would have to come close to a sympathetic hearing with the greens and with me because I feel that there has not been a sufficient capacity demonstrated by this federal parliament to protect old growth and high conservation value forests. When you go into a process and you identify those high conservation value areas and yet you do not demonstrate any political will to protect them from being logged, from having roads cut through them, from having their conservation values destroyed, then you are failing in a capacity to protect those forests.

So I could have said yes, maybe for that one because there is some merit in the argument that there has been a failure on the part of this minister for the environment to protect the native forests that are being sought for protection. However, it is scarcely fair to put the blame entirely on him because he is part of a cabinet, he is part of a government, and he is part of a political party. It would be the same for the opposition environmental spokesperson. I note that the opposition environment policy has been one of looking at the dangers of clearance. A connection needs to be made between clearance that has destroyed the agricultural capacities of this country and the logging that goes on in our native forest areas.

The next reason that was raised was that there had been incompetent handling of the process. The Minister for the Environment seems to have followed quite closely the process that was laid down in the national forest policy statement. Both the major parties support the national forest policy statement. I cannot say that the Greens do. We have very strong reservations about it because the national forest policy statement has never succeeded in protecting high conservation value forests. It has never acted on its moratorium clause to prevent the logging and destruction of high conservation value forests before they have been properly assessed. I might divert here and say that, if it is going to criticise the minister, the opposition needs to do its homework a bit better.

In comments that have been made in various speeches, opposition speakers have shown their lack of comprehension of this area. They laugh when people say forests will be gone forever. Yet that shows that they do not know what forests mean, what forests are and the difference between an old growth forest and a regrowth forest. They laugh when the minister for the environment comes up with the perfectly appropriate term `megadiverse'. Australia is, in the world, a unique example of a megadiverse system. Opposition members laugh when wetlands are talked about as being included in areas of coupes that are for protection. They laugh when there are airstrips in the areas. The reality is that the boundaries of those coupes are not determined by the minister for environment; they are determined by the state forestry agencies. It is not up to the environment movement to determine the boundaries of those coupes. It is simply up to them to work on those boundaries and say whether anything within those boundaries has the values that have been listed in the national forest policy statement as being worthy of protection. So I believe that the process has been handled as competently as it can be but I still have strong reservations about it.

The final point was that the minister had divided the community. That is true and it is very sad because there are genuine concerns on both sides of this debate. The government and the opposition need to take the responsible step of stepping back and listening to the truth on both sides. There is no doubt that there are grave concerns for the future of our native forests because of the inroads the woodchipping industry has made into them. There is also no doubt that there are difficulties within the industry amongst the workers who have been losing their jobs for 30 years—not as a result of the greens or any conservation process but simply because of mechanisation, market forces and the way the industry has been structured. So the division of the community cannot be laid solely at the feet of the environment minister by any means. It lies with all of us to look with respect at the division that has been raised and seek to resolve it in the most positive way possible for all parties.
That is what I thought the censure motion was about. So I was very relieved when after a while the actual wording was circulated and I received the motion, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to move a motion to censure the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories for gross incompetence in the exercise of his ministerial responsibilities in relation to the nomination of forest coupes which has undermined the protection of high conservation areas and put in jeopardy the jobs of forest workers.

I thought that was very clever phrasing. As Senator Macdonald knows, I have made no secret of the fact that if you have a process which identifies old growth and high conservation value areas without the political will to protect them, then you render them vulnerable. You devise a hit list for the industry so that it knows and, believe me, that is the basis on which the industry has been operating for quite some time now using the information in the CALM/AHC agreement. It has been quite capable of determining those areas which may one day, if it is ever protected, be placed under protection and it has. I can hardly blame them for that. It is their own self-interest that motivates them. They have targeted those areas and they have got to them first. Why would they not go for those areas which they know may not be available later?

PARA.TAB: To actually identify areas and then fail to protect them is to be responsible for their destruction. I think Senator Macdonald was very clever in putting in that part of the motion, because he knew it would extract a degree of sympathy from me. It is quite definitely the view by Australia's leading forest ecologists that there needs to be better protection of our forests. I incorporated a document into Hansard during a speech I made yesterday. I note in that document the comments of seven ecologists from all different states of Australia who say:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's forests will never be managed sustainably if Governments continue with the present piecemeal approach of assessing individual compartments and coupes. Proper planning and management requires the comprehensive assessment of forests at a regional level.

PARA.EMPHASIS: We continue to maintain our aim, stated on 1 July 1994, that the purpose of our action is to protect the forests AND to lay the groundwork for a sustainable timber industry with sustainable jobs.

Dr Hamilton goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: .employment in most timber towns depends much less on continued access to native forests than is generally believed.

.in the longer term, the employment impact of the 509 decision will be significantly less than redundancies due to continuing structural change in the industry. The smooth transition to a sustainable industry will depend on the implementation of the Regional Forest Agreements.

PARA.TAB: Basically, the two points in the censure motion have some merit. They warrant some consideration and not just dismissal on the political grounds of who one supports or does not support. I feel that it is the responsibility of this government to look at both sides of the issue and to sort it out in a really constructive way. It should do justice to the conservation issue, which is very important, and the future of those workers in the timber industry who may well be jeopardised by a proper approach to our high conservation forests.

I would have been glad to put the Prime Minister's name on the motion and then support the motion, because nobody is now sorting out the issue in a constructive way. We have to put the responsibility for these decisions on the government and the Prime Minister. I believe that the environment minister has done his job. I am not happy with the result and the compromises that have been made for political reasons by the Prime Minister. It is a tragedy that the people who are going to be left to sort it out are the people who are trying to prevent those 509 areas, 222 of which are national estate listed, from being destroyed right now while the government makes up its mind.

I will now report on the impact in Western Australia. I mentioned yesterday that in Western Australia the Conservation Council put forward a compromise list of 29 forest blocks for protection. It was not an ambit claim because it had to exclude many heritage listed areas because it lacked sufficient information to warrant their inclusion. Of the 29, Senator Faulkner then recommended that 21 of them be protected, the Minister for Resources listed two and the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has raised that number to 12. As I have already said, that fails to protect them because access to them has not been protected, roads are being made and disturbance is continuing.

What we have in Western Australia is a state environment minister who has ordered Western Australian loggers to ignore the bans on logging in the Rosa forest block, south of Nannup. Yesterday CALM logging and road preparation of the Jane forest was prevented only by an injunction that was brought by the local community. That is what it is left to. Instead of the Prime Minister doing this job, it is left to people in the community. But mark my words: the majority of the community do not want our high conservation value forests logged for woodchips. They are very sympathetic to the cries of the workers in that industry, who deserve and demand a transition strategy but they want those high conservation value forests protected. Make no mistake about it.

There has been a semi-official union picket in place at the Jane forest in Western Australia. I have to point out the plight of some of the local community people in that area. Mr Robert Daubney, who is one of the local people from the Northcliffe community and is from a pioneer farming family, has been involved in a recently formed group, the Friends of Jane Forest, which has been trying to prevent the construction of a logging highway through Jane forest, which is on the national estate and is listed amongst the 509 areas for protection. A press release states:

SPEECH.PARA: Robert Daubney, who owns a dairy farm adjoining Jane forest, said that the magnificence of the old growth Karri forest juxtaposed with the devastation caused by the logging road has hardened the resolve of local people to protect one of Northcliffe's greatest natural assets.

"No studies have ever been done in this area", said Mr Daubney, a descendent of Northcliffe's first European settlers. "Surely we must have learnt something since the thirties. They don't even know what is being destroyed."

That man, apparently because of his courageous stand, has had a semi-official union picket in place. He has lost 14,000 litres of milk and it has cost him $500 a day. He has had to spill the milk on to his farm because of a blockade by the industry which has prevented him from going about his business.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to report that the picket has been lifted and a tanker got through yesterday morning. I am very grateful that some reason has prevailed in that place. I know that people are distressed, and I think it is very important that, as well as the conservationists and the local community getting injunctions to prevent logging in old-growth forest, this government does its job.

I heartily urge the opposition to reconsider the political opportunism it has taken from this issue and support the government in sorting it out. Whether you want to come out on the side of the workers in the industry or on the side of those who value our forests enough not to see them destroyed, do it with integrity and in such a way that Australia will be a better place and will not suffer from it.

I think you will have gathered from my speech that I do not intend to support this motion to censure the minister for the environment. But I do urge that, because it is a matter of importance that Senator Macdonald has raised, we actively work to resolve this difficult issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank Senator Chamarette for telling me right at the end what she is doing. I had not quite understood where she was going to. She seemed to have two bob each way.

PARA.TAB: You always know when Senator Faulkner is in trouble and concerned. He floats into the chamber right at the death to do nothing else but try to sweet-talk the Greens. He came in a little while ago and floated around.

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon!

PARA.TAB: To have this motion passed would be a damaging and telling blow to Senator Faulkner. Please don't pass this motion. I'm in enough trouble.' As I said, I do not impugn any motives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald—

—As I have been addressed in the chamber, I would like to say, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that I object to the tenor—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Are you making a personal explanation?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a personal explanation.
—I think you need to wait until after Senator Macdonald has finished.
—I just wish to say that I object strongly to the tenor of his remarks. I ask him to desist, otherwise it will make my explanation much longer at the end.

—Senator, you can speak for as long as you like at the end. I did say that I did not impugn you for being overcome by his protestations to you. But it is fairly clear that he comes into the chamber and moves around, sits on the armchair and pleads his case. I suspect that it would not have particularly moved you one way or the other, although from the way you spoke I took it that you were undecided and had two bob each way. Perhaps Senator Chamarette, being the kind, gentle sort of person she is, did not want to embarrass Senator Faulkner any more than he has already been embarrassed.

PARA.TAB: This is why the process is wrong. Senator Faulkner has proceeded with a process that is completely flawed, made a laughing stock of the process, and made a laughing stock of people who are genuinely interested in and have a genuine concern about the environment.

Senator Chamarette should have a look at these. These are some documents done by the New South Wales government. They are beautifully presented and very detailed documents into all those coupes. I cannot table them, unfortunately, because they are the only copy I have, but they are public documents. These documents contain all the information that Senator Faulkner needed. They are accurate, reliable and precise. Yet Senator Faulkner went on with this flawed process that has everybody from environmentalists, to forest workers, to journalists, to members of the Labor Party caucus laughing at the system that he has introduced when it was all done for him.

That is why the censure motion should be passed. The information was all there for Senator Faulkner if he was genuine, if he was not just playing green politics to try to get the second preferences of the Green parties at the next election. That is what it is all about. The process is not genuine. Everybody can see that, including members of the Labor Party caucus. I am disappointed that you cannot see it and cannot understand the need to censure Senator Faulkner for his incompetence in the way he has handled the matter.

I have taken some time to try to explain to Senator Chamarette why the motion should be supported. I do not bother with the Australian Democrats. We all know that the Greens will make a considered judgment on this because they are concerned about the environment and they think these things through. However, you know that with the Democrats the Labor Party just says, `Jump' and they say, `How high?' You know that every time the Labor Party needs a bit of support, needs a vote or two, they just click their fingers to the Democrats and the Democrats will support them as a matter of course. They are in fact the left wing of the Labor Party—the far left wing, I might say.

Bob Brown, the West Australian Greens—those sorts of people—do think seriously about this. They work out what they think is best for the environment. We do not always agree with them, but at least they do think about it. But the Democrats think about the politics of it. If the Labor Party wants them to do something, they do it. If the Labor Party says, `Vote with us,' they vote with it. If the Labor Party says `Don't censure Faulkner,' they do not censure Senator Faulkner. The Democrats gave some arguments, but I do not think anyone took any notice of them. They were very difficult to understand.

I can never quite understand what Senator Coulter is on about. I think he is looking forward to the thrashing that the Democrats will get at the next election by the Liberal and National Parties, and I suspect by the Greens as well in various southern states, because Senator Coulter can then turn the tables back on Senator Kernot, who knocked him off for the leadership. If the Democrats do as badly next time as everyone thinks they will, maybe Senator Coulter can have another go at being leader. I suspect that, in Senator Coulter's contributions, he was aiding the Democrats' fall so that Senator Kernot will be discredited as the leader and he can have another go.

I am not surprised that the Democrats yet again do what the Labor Party says. I wish Senator Coulter and the Democrats would consider these things. The environment and conservation are very serious matters. I know the green movement, Mr Brown in Tasmania, the West Australian Greens and the Liberal and National Parties very seriously consider these things. They do not just play politics like you people. They have an independent view. We decide these things on merit and do not do just what the Labor Party tells us to do. I am sorry that the Democrats have taken that approach.

Apart from that, nothing they said requires a response. There are other days when I can defend myself against the things Senator Coulter has said. They were so ridiculous—and, as I say, no-one takes any notice of Senator Coulter—that I will not waste the time of this debate in even referring to them any further.

My colleague Senator Crane has indicated our approach to the forestry policy. We support the national forest policy statement. That has been made quite clear. That was our policy at the last election. Senator Crane has quite clearly explained that. I might say that Mr Ian McLachlan, the coalition's environment spokesman, is a very genuine and concerned conservationist. He has put down a policy which I think everyone will concede is a very sensible and caring document and one that shows a genuine commitment to the environment—not just the type of commitment that Senator Faulkner has in following former Senator Richardson in trying to get the second votes of those who would not normally support the Labor Party. Mr McLachlan's policy is a genuine one. I do not think any serious, fair-minded and sensible person could ever say that the coalition is anything but genuinely concerned for genuine environmental issues and conservation generally. We prove our point. We do it because it needs to be done—not because there are votes in it.

I briefly want to touch on the acquittal reports. I suppose they are matters that we will deal with more fully in estimates committee hearings next week. I must say that the pieces of paper that were tabled today just exacerbate the incompetence of the department in the way it has handled all this. I see that the letters referred to are signed by the secretary to the department, Mr Stuart Hamilton—a man who has become famous for the way he will refuse to give out any information at estimates committee hearings and refuse in any way to assist the process of information gathering. It was he who fought all the way to prevent us from getting information on Mrs Kelly in answering the reasonable, lawful and legitimate questions that were asked. I see from the information he has given today that he is doing the same with Senator Faulkner. I regret that, but I will take that up with him directly in the next estimates committee hearings.

I also want Mr Hamilton and Senator Faulkner to tell us why they have deliberately, it appears, not enforced the contracts that were made with the conservation movement and why this parliament is yet again being prevented from seeing how those funds that were granted to the conservation movement were acquitted. It is interesting to note that it seems, from the material tabled, that the only time the department has asked for the acquittals is the day after those acquittals were supposed to be tabled in this parliament.

The letter to the conservation groups from the acting secretary of the forest branch which asked them for these acquittal reports is dated 3 February—the day after Senator Faulkner was ordered by the Senate to table those acquittal reports in this chamber and several days after Senator Faulkner, in a throwaway line, said to us that he had all the acquittal reports. I think that alone deserves censure of Senator Faulkner and his department. It certainly is something that I will pursue further in estimates committee hearings.

I have mentioned the New South Wales documents and what should have been done. Senator Faulkner has completely demeaned this whole process and brought into disrepute the conservation movement and all those interested in the environment. He has been insensitive to the jobs that his incompetence has caused. For all those reasons, and for the reasons that were very clearly explained in the debate by my colleagues Senator Alston, Senator Sandy Macdonald, Senator Gibson and Senator Crane, Senator Faulkner should resign or should be sacked. By supporting this censure motion the Senate can assist in the process of getting rid of a minister who has proved himself to be so incompetent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Wheat Board has been chaired by Clinton Condon for quite some years. He was appointed the chairman in April 1986 but he has been a board member since 1979. Tonight the industry is giving him a dinner, which unfortunately I will not be able to attend. I would like to place on record the work that he has done as chairman of the board. Just quietly, I have not always agreed with him, and I might elucidate on a couple of those points on which we have not always agreed.

PARA.TAB: He has done a good job. He has given a great deal of time and service to the Wheat Board. I wish him a happy retirement out of the industry and hopefully he will enjoy his time away from it. He started off in Queensland as a wheat grower and has spent a lot of time in recent years living in Melbourne. I do not want to be derogatory about the Victorians at all, but really he was living in the purple in the Queensland wheat area, and to go down and live in Melbourne was a sacrifice in itself.
I would like to make a couple of points about the report. Under the heading `In partnership . . . with the domestic market', it reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The organisation has strengthened its relationship with the stock-feed market by appointing a national feed-grain manager and dedicated merchants in each state.

With my pecuniary interest as a grower of grain in the north of New South Wales, I find that the Wheat Board quite often undercuts summer crop prices at this time of the year through to June because of contracts it has entered into with the stockfeed market, especially in the feedlot industry. I wonder sometimes whether the Wheat Board has lost its mandate as a single desk seller. If that does change, we would have to think about it very seriously. It is trading on the domestic market, trying to be the best seller of the grain for the producer, and buying grain at the best price to make a profit on the domestic market. It makes me wonder how the Wheat Board can be all things to all people. I believe the Wheat Broad was put there to look after the growers and to put a stable price into the industry.

PARA.TAB: In the report the Wheat Board talks about its grain crop proposal, which is going to be subject to ministerial approval and referred to the Trade Practices Commission. At this stage, the Trade Practices Commission does not agree entirely that the Wheat Board could take over the handling authority, or be a partner in the handling authority, because it would become a monopoly. I refer to the Booz Allen report which says that the benefits of the single desk selling system for wheat appear to outweigh the costs at this particular time.

The key issue which dictates the future of people in the grain industry, and really the whole grain industry, is to decide whether or not it should continue. I believe it has served us well over the years and I cannot see any reason at this time for doing away with it. When Minister Crean was the minister, he suggested that, when GATT came to fruition, we do away with it. I caution against that because I do not know whether it would be better to keep with what we have got at the moment and not throw the baby out with the bath water because, if we do, we might find we do not get the benefits of the World Trade Organisation reforms, and we will have lost the benefit of single desk selling.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some remarks about the Australian Wheat Board. In doing so, I would also like to offer my congratulations to Clinton Condon, the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board. He has been a member of the Wheat Board since 1979, as my colleague Senator Brownhill has said. He has done an excellent job, and I wish to take this opportunity to wish him a very happy retirement.

PARA.TAB: The 1993-94 annual report of the Australian Wheat Board reveals that the Wheat Board is doing a very good job. Its growers are receiving payments promptly, protein levels are being lifted in the national crop through Australian Wheat Board programs, and 50 per cent of the wheat import growth in our core Asian markets has been captured by Australia, with participation in new feed growing business established in Asia. We have also established ties in Asia by opening an office in Hong Kong, and a partnership with Goodman Fielder and the Vietnam Food Industry Company has been entered into for a new flour mill in Vietnam.

I would like to refer to two areas: the continuing practice of the US to use its export enhancement programs to steal our traditional grain markets in Asia; and the position taken by the Trade Practices Commission to prevent the amalgamation of the Australian Wheat Board with the New South Wales Grain Corp, which also puts under threat the merger between the AWB and Queensland's Grainco.

To deal firstly with the threat of further US subsidies, it seems that the US has entered a further game of claiming new markets before the cut-in date of 1 July this year, when the Uruguay Round agreement on subsidy reduction comes into effect. The GATT Uruguay Round decision was welcomed by Australian grain growers as putting an end to the damage done to the industry through the US-EC trade war; in particular, the damage done to the Australian grain growers since the introduction of the US EEP program in 1986. That damage has been immense.

According to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, it has cost Australian grain growers an 11 per cent reduction in world grain prices, or $300 million a year since 1986. We saw incidents like the Bush Administration in 1992 subsidising its entire export crop to the tune of $1.4 billion. As a result, the US entered our Pakistan and Indian markets and, despite assurances from former President Bush and President Clinton that they would not do so, the US has continued to steal our traditional Asian markets with their highly subsidised export programs.

In an act totally against the spirit of the Uruguay Round, the US dairy export subsidy scheme is stealing $20 million of our Asian dairy market before crunch time on 1 July. Today Senator McMullan acknowledged that they may do the same with our traditional Asian wheat markets. The US action must be stopped, and the Australian government should pull out all shots available to it to prevent the US treating their allies in this appalling way.

The other great threat to the future of the grains industry lies in the Trade Practices Commission's tunnel vision in preventing the further commercial growth of the grower owned Australian industry. I know it took the industry by surprise to have the merger of the AWB and the grain corp rejected.

The tabling of this report comes a matter of days after the issue of a major report into the grains industry commissioned by the industry itself. The Booz Allen and Hamilton report points out that the Australian Wheat Board would need to undergo significant changes and broaden its narrow business base if, when the market was deregulated, it were to survive against companies like US giant ConAgra, which has offices in 26 countries, sales of $US6.9 billion, 34 flour mills and 4.6 million tonnes of storage.

Today we are told that our companies have to be competitive. We are facing competition such as Cargill, which has received over $1.2 billion in US EEP subsidies over the last six years. The other company involved was Louis Dreyfus, a French based company, which received nearly $1 billion of EC subsidies. Yet the Trade Practices Commission is not allowing the efficiencies to be promoted in the grain industry. That would have let the amalgamations take place and that would have allowed the wheat board to be competitive against these hugely subsidised companies. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Grape and Wine Research and Development Corporation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The wine industry and the grape growing industry are great employers of people. They are good for tourism and value adding but, unfortunately, they are the milch cow of this government. Basically, they have the problem of high interest rates that impact so heavily on the industries because they have a long lead time. They have the problem of first of all planting their vines, then they have four years before they come into good production. It costs about $10,000 an acre to get a vineyard going.

PARA.TAB: With interest rates like they are, and we were told at the conference in the last couple of days that they are likely to rise another three per cent, they will impact very heavily on the wine industry. Once the producers have grown their grape—it takes a year to grow the grape—they have to crush it, put it into bottles, then they have to put away the good wines that we all enjoy drinking so much to mature. The interest is accruing the whole time on the industry. There is a tax as well on the stock that is actually put down. So there is a long lead time, and high interest rates will kill this industry which gives us so much enjoyment and gives us so much export income as well.

The high value of the dollar at the moment is causing problems for the wine industry as far as exports are concerned, and there is also a wine tax. This government says, `Hear, hear! The wine industry is good for us and wine is good for our health.' But the government is going to raise the wine tax from 24 to 26 per cent. R&D, which this report is all about, has always been dollar for dollar. It is mooted, talked about, that this government is most probably going to change that. So instead of there being dollar for dollar for R&D, the government might put in $1 for every $4 that the industry puts in. Maybe the parliamentary secretary might be able to deny that in a moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.
—Shame on them. Dead right.
—I will make a comment about it.

—He will comment. If he wants to slug them again, that is it. But this government is slugging the wine industry with transport costs as well. Wholesale taxes have gone from something like $3 billion tax take to nearly $13 billion tax take in the time this Labor government has been in power. Wholesale taxes impose such a big cost on the transport industry because everything in the transport industry is tied up with that.

PARA.TAB: The government is talking about raising fuel excise again and maybe it will raise it again. That is another impost on the wine industry. As well as all those problems, competition is coming on stream from Chile. Chile has resewn all its vines, the more modern type vines. South Africa is coming onto the market now as well. Another big competitor to the Australian wine industry is New Zealand just across the Tasman. Of course there are improved techniques in Europe and things are freeing up there.

So the wine industry is an industry we think we should look after. I believe we should. This side of the chamber has an interest in it. We have an interest in R&D for the wine industry. We will look after the wine industry, whether it is now or in the future. I wonder whether this government will look after it as well as it should and not make it the milch cow which it has in the last little while and which it looks as though it will in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just returned from a wine symposium and, happily, a wine tasting at the ABARE conference being held in Canberra.

PARA.TAB: Senator Brownhill also referred to the government mooting or talking about changing the dollar for dollar allocation for research and development. —You know as well I do that neither you, on behalf of the opposition, nor I, on behalf of the government, can give any indication of what will be the outcome of the Industry Commission report. PARA.TAB: You are quite right to point out the problems we face in the world markets not just with Chile and South Africa but also Eastern Europe. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —In question time today the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) answered a dorothy dix question regarding the issue of Russian authorities launching a missile from Australian soil under a proposal by the Australian Space Office. In answering that dorothy dix question, the minister attacked a press statement which I put out last week, on 2 February, and a subsequent newspaper article that eventuated from that press release. He falsely attacked both my press release and that newspaper article. I think it is important to note that Senator Schacht continues to mislead this chamber about the true nature of this proposed launch of a Russian missile.

PARA.TAB: The minister was quick to espouse the virtues of wide industry support for this bizarre plan, but what he has failed to tell us is that the proposal has been rejected by two of the leading industry groups—BHP and Transfield—who declined to attend a meeting in Adelaide to discuss this very project. Such was the lunacy of the project and the proposal that even these two major space industry companies are unenthusiastic about the government's plan.

Senator Schacht claimed that my allegations of secrecy regarding this proposal are spurious. The fact is, had it not been for my efforts in uncovering the proposal, Senator Schacht would still be trying to keep a lid on the project because of its political sensitivity. He knows full well that industry groups think very poorly of the Russian involvement, not to mention the fact that if this project were to go ahead Australia would be in breach of the missile technology control agreement, the MTCR.

I remind the minister that Australia's involvement with the MTCR agreement is to prevent sensitive missile technology from falling into the wrong hands, such as hostile countries. Russia is not a signatory to that agreement and Australia's involvement under the Australian Space Office's proposal would result in our breaching this agreement with the United States, Europe, Japan and other countries.

Senator Schacht is also attempting to play down the significance of the Russians bringing in one of their START mobile missile launchers to fire a missile into orbit over Indonesia and Malaysia. It is somewhat amusing that the minister tries to couch the term `missile' in a press release which he put out also on 2 February, in response to my press release and which he again mentioned in his answer today, calling it instead a `START space vehicle'. What hilarity!

TALK.START.PARA: —A giant rubber band!

—It really would be a joke if it were not so serious, Senator O'Chee. Anyone in their right mind would know that the actual vehicle he is talking about is a Russian START missile, which has military applications. The only minor difference is the software and a space re-entry vehicle. The fact remains that Senator Schacht is not telling the whole truth because he has been caught out embarking upon a most dangerous and bizarre space proposal which has serious implications for our Asian neighbours and for the United States.

PARA.TAB: When it comes to space, Schacht is lost. Everything the space minister touches either gets lost in space, as we have seen recently, or crashes to the ground. We have seen that not only with his involvement with the space industry but also with the customs department.

My support for the revitalisation of the space industry in Australia, particularly with a base in South Australia, is crystal clear and has been so ever since I served on the Senate inquiry into this matter two or three years ago, an inquiry on which Senator Schacht also served. But the revitalisation of the space industry in Australia will never happen under this government which, to date, has failed absolutely to show any support for the space industry by failing to provide the required funding.

Again, it is crystal clear—and it was right from the time that Senate committee conducted its investigations and made its report—that the only way we are going to get a space industry off the ground in Australia is if the government provides the funding for the first two rockets. Then, and only then, will those with expertise in the space industry in the private sector, who would seek to launch satellites and so on, make a commitment to invest private funds in this industry. That has been the experience right around the world: unless a government is prepared to make a commitment, then you simply do not have a space industry.

Before Christmas we saw Senator Schacht take his proposal from the Australian Space Office to the cabinet, and it was rejected out of hand. The proposal for government support to get this industry off the ground in Australia was rejected out of hand. Ever since then we have seen the minister scrambling around Australia trying to encourage the private sector to invest its funds in this industry without any commitment whatsoever from the government.

I do not appreciate this half-baked attempt by Senator Schacht to mislead both the public and honourable senators about his dismal performance. This minister, who prides himself on being the minister for space, seems hell-bent on taking the Australian Space Office down the road to destruction, to try and get a few runs on the board through this very dangerous proposal so that he can then perhaps go back to the government and see if he can make a better fist of obtaining the necessary funds to revitalise this industry.

As I said, he will fail in that regard. The only way we will succeed in revitalising this industry is if the government determines that it is prepared to make a commitment and provide that initial funding. Then you will see the private sector only too willing to come to the party and be actively involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter of concern to me relating to security clearances in government agencies. It is a matter I raised at a Senate estimates hearing on Friday 3 February. Senator Evans appeared to share my concern that Austrade makes decisions on the security clearances of its employees and that those security decisions are not subject to the sort of appeal that is available to security matters resolved by ASIO. In fact, there is no proper appeal process, apart from merit protection review arrangements which do not deal with the subject of security.

PARA.TAB: It seems extraordinary that there are government agencies which deal with the matters which determine someone's security standing but do not have the same appeal rights as exist when ASIO does the security clearance. This strikes me as absolutely extraordinary.

I note that the government's response to recommendations made by the Joint Statutory Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization was that it did not accept the recommendation of the committee that provision should be made for an appeal to the tribunal by any person aggrieved by a decision of an agency head. The government response stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Not accepted in relation to making provision for appeal from an access decision of an agency head. There is already suitable provision for the review of decisions relating to employment of Commonwealth employees. They have a right under Division 3 of Part III of the Public Service Regulations to request the agency head to review a decision.

It does not say on what basis the agency head must review it. It does not say, for example, that the agency head must at least have the decency to interview the person aggrieved or to hear him or her, or his or her legal representatives, on the matter.

PARA.TAB: In fact, in the case of Austrade, the agency head gave what is farcically referred to as `a review of a decision' without interviewing the aggrieved person. The decision was made overnight in response to a submission made by the aggrieved person on one day, and a letter went out the following day purporting to be the result of a review by the agency head. Anyway, I will read on:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to request the agency head to review a decision (including security clearance decisions). If the complainant is still dissatisfied, he or she may apply to the Merit Protection and Review Agency . . .

So it goes on. That is simple bunkum. I can establish that by reading this extract of a Merit Protection and Review Agency decision in relation to what appears to me to have been a disgraceful decision on security matters relating to an individual. The Merit Protection and Review Agency quite properly says:
. . . the main question for MPRA is whether the decision to terminate—
this gentleman's—
employment with AUSTRADE was fair and equitable and taken or made in accordance with sound personnel management practices . . .
That is its view. The MPRA then goes on to say this:
.. rather than whether—
the gentleman—
is in fact a person qualified for a security clearance.

In other words, the appeal mechanism does not deal with the substance of the problem, which is whether or not the aggrieved person qualified for a security clearance. In other words, the system that is established to protect the rights of people subject to security clearance examinations, and who fail that examination for one reason or another, does not apply to those agencies that operate their own security clearance arrangements. I must say I am intrigued to know why Austrade feels the need to run its own little empire in this matter, but it is extraordinary that in such a situation those rights are wiped out. There is a farcical proposition that an agency head can `review' the problem without even hearing the aggrieved person.

PARA.TAB: I might say that I have no idea of the merits or otherwise of this person's security status or standing, although I have to say that what I have read in the Merit Protection and Review Agency report leads me to the view that this is a particularly sloppy and incompetent exercise by Austrade. I notice that the MPRA says this:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the security business is concerned, it may well be desirable for the jurisdiction of the Security Appeals Tribunal (or, possibly, that of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal) to be expanded to include appeals against decisions of agency heads in relation to security clearances . . .

I say amen to all that, if we are going to have this kind of activity. I am not saying that the actions of the agency are mendacious; all I am saying is that it is self-evidently incompetent and improper in terms of preventing an aggrieved person having the same rights of access as exist elsewhere. It is intriguing to note that the Merit Protection and Review Agency says:

. . . it was not appropriate for MPRA to request that this matter be first re-investigated by AUSTRADE, as would normally be the case with the general run of grievances handled under the Public Service regulations.

This is despite the fact that the review by the head of the agency was, self-evidently, grossly inadequate and grossly improper. I should then add another point made by MPRA in its report to this individual:

The Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979 regulates ASIO's role and makes provision for independent review, by the Security Appeals Tribunal, of ASIO's security assessments but does not generally apply to actions by other Commonwealth departments and agencies . . . ASIO provides advice when requested in accordance with Part IV of its Act, but the heads of Commonwealth departments and agencies alone are responsible for access decisions.

That means they have a particular need to ensure that the rights of individuals, which are protected in relation to ASIO assessments, are equally protected in relation to their own. Mr Evans of Austrade has failed to protect the rights of one of his employees. The Merit Protection and Review Agency then goes on to reveal what is clearly an absurd situation in which Austrade appointed a person to a job, subject to his security clearance, and it was a long time after that appointment that the security clearance was ultimately refused. I might say that there was deceptive device by
Austrade. It had a second interview with the person involved at which, on 1 September 1994, he was told:
. . . the [further] interview is a routine procedure to finalise the security clearance arrangements . . .

Instead of that, in fact, he was vigorously interviewed for eight hours with a 10-minute break. This kind of straight dishonesty by Austrade is unpardonable. What I notice it does say is that this man's employment relationship with Austrade has now been irreparably damaged, according to the MPRA. It says that surely Austrade can improve its situation where it provides security clearances, or does the work on a matter of security clearance, before it employs the person. But this man's reputation has been destroyed by an incompetent administration, by an Austrade organisation which does not provide the same protection to other Commonwealth employees and which I believe has behaved disgracefully. I have not revealed the name of the person involved because I do not want to add further damage to his reputation that this, I believe, totally disgraceful behaviour by Austrade has already done to him.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 21 November 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Government entered into a labour agreement which restricts the number of qualified overseas doctors from entering and practising in Australia; if so, what are the major points of this agreement.
(2) Why is it necessary to limit the number of overseas qualified doctors from entering and practising in Australia.
(3) Is the Minister aware of complaints from any provincial cities, rural and remote areas of Australia of the inability to attract Australian qualified general practitioners.

(4) Does the Minister agree that a qualified entry of overseas trained medical practitioners could be used to provide medical services to those areas unable to obtain the services of general practitioners.

(5) Does the Minister agree with statistics which show that the national average of population per registered general practitioner is 764, whereas for Brisbane the figure is 648 but for Townsville it is 1 242 people.
(6) Is the Minister concerned at this inequality.
(7) What does the Minister propose to do to alleviate such an imbalance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, agreements to reduce reliance on temporary resident doctors have now been concluded between the Commonwealth and most States and Territories. Specifically, formal labour agreements have been signed in Queensland and the Northern Territory. New South Wales and Tasmania have signed memoranda of understanding, while Victoria is operating under a statement of principles agreed with the Commonwealth. Western Australia, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory have not concluded agreements of any form at present.
The major objectives of these various agreements are to:
progressively reduce the number of medical practitioners entering Australia as temporary residents to meet needs-based health service requirements in the medical workforce;

facilitate the temporary entry to, and stay in, Australia of an agreed number of medical practitioners from overseas to provide medical services in public or private health services, medical clinics or practices, or in locum agencies or medical deputising services;
overcome skilled personnel shortages particularly in areas of special need and in rural and isolated areas in the medium term;
ensure that medical practitioners from overseas are targeted to the areas of greatest need and possess the required skills;
promote arrangements to reduce long-term reliance on medical practitioners temporarily resident in Australia; and
encourage education and training to enhance skills of Australian medical practitioners and medical practitioners from overseas who are now resident in Australia.

(2) In April 1992 all State and Territory health ministers agreed to adopt a national medical workforce strategy to address the over-supply of doctors in the Australian health-care system. The doctor:population ratio had increased from 1:720 in the early 1970's to 1:430 in 1992 with a commensurate increase in health outlays, but with little discernible improvement in the overall health status of Australians and little improvement in the geographic and sectoral distribution of the workforce. A number of reports, including the 1992 Report of the Medical Workforce Data Review Committee to the Australian Health Minister's Advisory Council, identified overseas trained doctors as a significant determinant of the size of the medical workforce.

In response to this oversupply in Australia, all health ministers agreed in April 1992 to adopt the National Medical Workforce Strategy. One component of this strategy was to reduce reliance on temporary resident doctors to one third of 1992 levels by the end of 1997.
(3) Yes.

(4) In adopting the National Medical Workforce Strategy in April 1992, health ministers were well aware of the problem of attracting and retaining the services of general practitioners in rural areas and stated in their original decision that "the principle of equity across Australia is followed, particularly in isolated areas". For this reason the Commonwealth has been flexible in its approach to the agreed annual reductions of 20% in temporary resident doctor usage and has taken a longer term perspective to these reductions so that they can be achieved by the full term of the agreement.
Local committees have been established in each State and Territory with an agreement. The role of these committees is, amongst other things, to determine areas of greatest need.

(5) and (6) Statistics based on the most recent population estimates and Medicare data indicates that the national average of population per registered general practitioner is 746; for Brisbane the average is 632 (based on 1993/94 Medicare data for the Brisbane statistical division as defined in the ABS Australian Standard Geographical Classification and ABS population estimates for 1993); and for Townsville it is 613 (based on 1993/94 Medicare data for the Townsville statistical sub-division as defined in the ABS Australian Standard Geographical Classification and ABS population estimates for 1993).

(7) The Government's General Practice Strategy is designed to address the maldistribution problem of general practitioner oversupply in the city and undersupply in rural and remote areas. The objectives of the Program are:
to improve access of rural and remote communities to general practice services;
to assist in the delivery of high quality general practice services by supporting appropriate training; and
to foster recruitment and retention of rural and remote general practitioners by provision of grants for the five components of the Program.

The five principal elements of the Rural Incentives Program (RIP) are grants for relocation, training, remote area practice, continuing medical education/locum support and undergraduate initiatives. $15.1 million was allocated to the RIP in 1993/94 and a total of $15.3 million has been allocated in 1994/95.

To 30 October 1994, 81 general practitioners have relocated and 62 general practitioners have undertaken training for rural practice through the Rural Incentives Program. Continuing medical education and locum support grants have been allocated to all States through the Rural Division Co-ordinating Units. Eight medical schools have accepted grants to encourage medical students to pursue careers in rural medicine and all States and the Northern Territory have been offered grants to co-ordinate student placements.

The Government's Rural Health Support, Education and Training (RHSET) program is also making a significant contribution towards improving access to effective health services in rural and remote Australia. This program is designed to improve the recruitment and retention of health workers through increased education, training and support opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 December 1994:

PARA.TAB: What were the `time constraints of one kind or another' which prevented the following Government decisions from being considered by Cabinet: (a) the new cable television rules; (b) the ditching of the open skies agreement with Air New Zealand; (c) the Australian National Line rescue package; and (d) the Creative Nation commitment to assist in the site preparation and development of a movie studio in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) I refer the honourable senator to the answer Senator Evans provided to his question (Senate Hansard, 28 November 1994, pages 3312-4).

(b) The Government has not "ditched" its 1992 Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the New Zealand government. Substantial progress towards a single aviation market has been achieved over the last two years. Air New Zealand was granted additional beyond rights from 1 November 1994, allowing the airline to fly 12 services per week between Australia and the Asian and United States markets. Further work is being undertaken by officials to establish immigration pre-clearance and common border arrangements to streamline passage between Australia and New Zealand. However, domestic access by New Zealand airlines will not proceed.

(c) The Government considered the position of ANL Limited at a Cabinet meeting on 22 August 1994 and agreed to appoint a new management committee to replace the existing board of ANL, with a charter to restructure the company. The Government indicated its intent to provide the guarantees necessary for the continuation of ANL's business and agreed to examine the position of ANL again within the next six months.

(d) My 18 October Cultural Policy Statement made clear that the Government's offer of assistance for site preparation and development was subject to further discussions with the NSW Government on suitable site locations. The question of the level and type of Commonwealth assistance is a matter that may be appropriate for Cabinet consideration, should the NSW Government accept 20th Century Fox as the preferred tender for the movie studios.
